story:
Nu•ance Theatre Company gives you the HAMLET Shakespeare envisioned!

Help us tell the story you always thought you knew,
in a way you never imagined it could be told!

With HAMLET, Nu•ance once again delivers a fresh and ambitious theatrical experience with  unexpected elements of real illusions, immersive staging and design beyond the expectations of their intimate space.

Audience members will find themselves propelled into the world of 1513 Denmark, within  the cold, dark walls of Elsinore Castle, complete with drawbridge and ramparts, witnessing a tragic tale of retribution as lives become entangled in destiny from a stolen crown, the death of a king and his unyielding ghost.

With your help, we can present something no one
thought possible for a theatre of our size.

We have an extraordinarily gifted cast of actors, exceptionally talented and inventive designers as well as a brilliant and committed directing and production team, all of whom are bursting with ideas that will heighten and inform this haunting story.

  • You might see a can of paint and some lumber - We see a Danish castle shrouded in corruption.
  • You might see a pile of fabric - We see Hamlet's golden cloak of melancholia.
  • You might see lights and wires - We see the dim corridors and glow of the ramparts.
  • You might see an empty doorway - We see the King's Ghost.

Help us build it, and we'll take you there!

YOUR CONTRIBUTION - WHAT WE NEED

Producing a play, building a castle, clothing 24 characters and conjuring a Ghost is no small feat.  To bring our unique deeply haunting vision to life, we have enlisted the skills of an Illusionist, along with a superb team of the most devoted actors, designers and directors at the peak of their craft.  Now we need to fund it all!

The money we raise will go directly to the cost of set construction, costumes, makeup, props, lighting, sound, ghost effects, filming, actors, designers, promotion and rental of rehearsal and theatrical space.

WHAT WE CAN GIVE IN RETURN

By donating money at any level, YOU not only become an integral part of making this production come to life, we have concocted a whole host of special gifts to show our gratitude! Each level contains its own extra something...so view the contribution options (located in the right column) in more detail and select the perk that you will be excited to support!

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Spread the word! Help comes in as many shapes and forms as there are hands to give it!

You can do us the best of turns by spreading the word: by word of mouth, by social media, by interpretive dance, by carrier pigeon, by telepathy, by semaphore...however you speak best, you have our greatest thanks for simply letting others in on what we've got in store...

Please use the SHARE feature on this site, and don't be shy about getting LOUD!

NU•ANCE THEATRE COMPANY ...WHO ARE WE?

'nu·ance'  ˈ(n(y)o͞oˌäns)
Expression or appreciation of delicate shades of meaning, feeling, or tone: a subtle quality.

At a Nu•ance play, you can expect to see old treasures  and modern drama with new eyes...we create in every work a particular, unexpected element of innovation to surprise, delight, illuminate and ignite your mind and heart. 

We pride ourselves on our innovative approach to staging; creating a world in which the life of the play, in all its subtlety and truth, can emerge.  In past productions, we have made it rain onstage, built an entire tenement apartment complete with creaking floors and evening meals, and brought audiences to their feet with the cries of a warehouse union hall, still echoing today...

...and now - with your help -  Hamlet's Ghost will haunt the Nu•ance Theatre stage.

THE IMPACT

"How far that little candle throws his beams! So shines a good deed in a naughty world."

In today's world, we're often isolated by the same technology which claims to "connect" us...that's why we at Nu•ance believe that there is more than ever to be gained in live theatre, and all of its raw, unfiltered humanity, its immediacy and its beautiful imperfections. Our greatest treasure is our imagination, our sincerest connection is storytelling...and today, there is true bravery in simply stepping into a theatre, and giving yourself over to whatever happens on its stage, heart and all!

Nu•ance Theatre Company has a growing history of contribution in this effort. Our two stages are located in the heart of Manhattan's theatre district, in the Times Square Arts Center, the last all-arts building remaining in New York City.  We believe in fostering and launching young, talented designers and technicians early in their careers, as well as creating a thriving hub for actors, directors, playwrights, and other creators, both new and veteran. 

Your involvement will keep our door always open for those with a story to tell.

Our sincere thanks for reading about our campaign and your support.

See you at the theatre!

story:
The Story

"Take One" is the untold story of the creative struggles of:

  • God;
  • Michelangelo; and
  • Richard Rodgers

in the forging of their greatest works. Their failures and frustrations -- again, hitherto undisclosed -- lead to life-changing insights and about 22 catchy songs.

The Festival

The show has a cast of seven in triple roles. We're about halfway through casting (3 1/2 actors hired as of this writing) and are delighted with the people we've snagged. We've also roped in a superior music director, stage manager, company rep, and lighting, prop and scenery designers. We hope to be staffed up completely and start making payroll by early July.

That's also when we'll learn our theatre assignment and performance dates.  We'll perform the show five times between August 12th and 28th. Obviously you will get updates as soon as we have them by dint of being a supporter of the production.

Marlins

We're also planning some modest stage effects that will add to both the cost and the "wow factor." Chief among these is a 70-gallon tank full of live marlins, which must all be trained. A further expense are three Apache helicopters -- and as you know, if you show the hellfire missiles, you have to fire the hellfire missiles, and that, too, runs into some serious scratch.

So thanks!

The whole team will be very grateful if you can help "Take One" happen, and we hope we can thank the hell out of you at the theatre.

story:
Please take a moment to read on, and help us to reach (or exceed) our goal! Please lend your assistance in continuing to provide high-caliber ballet -programming in Washington, DC.

Your support is critical in fulfilling our objectives.....EVERY amount helps and we are grateful for your support.

Our 2nd FALL SEASON features coveted performance opportunities at Dance Place on Sept. 17th and 18th, showcasing two full evenings of the work of Stuart Loungway; as well as a return engagement at VELOCITYDC Dance Festival on Oct. 8th and 9th.

TFDT and the work of Stuart Loungway, over the course of the past year, has quickly made a mark on the dance-landscape of Washington, DC, and become a benchmark of innovative and high-caliber programming in dance in the DMV-region.  

Our work and company have been received with critical and audience acclaim, and Mr. Loungway has cemented his reputation as a beloved teacher  in the region at The Washington Ballet, CITYDANCE, Jones-Haywood and beyond.  In addition, Mr. Loungway is the recipient of the OUTSTANDING CHOREOGRAPHER AWARD, from Youth America Grand Prix, in recognition of the high merit of his choreography, as set on CITYDANCE artist, Lara Segrillo. Come experience our creative endeavors....we invite your support.

What better way to launch our unique, high-octane signature flair than to share our selection to the region's premiere dance happening,  at DANCE PLACE  on Sept. 17th and 18th awarded by DANCE METRO DC, in recognition of the merit and quality of our choreographic work; as well as our return to VelocityDC Dance Festival. TFDT was selected from a highly-competitive field of applicants to perform at both of these events this season, and we couldn't be more thrilled!

We are looking forward to continuing to pioneer our way down the path to our new home, and "colonizing" the DC-dance landscape....but we can't do it alone. Your contributions will provide direct and concrete support, and underwrite the dancers of TFDT; rehearsal space; travel and lodging and creative production development.

On Sept. 17th and 18th  2016, the dancers of Mr. Loungway's company, Terra Firma Dance Theatre, joined by selected professional aspirants of the acclaimed CITYDANCE will take the DANCE PLACE stage by storm, in  full-length evening/s of  his work.  A significant occasion to launch and introduce new audiences to the award-winning work of TFDT, providing a catalyst to further opportunity for the upcoming season.  In addition, we will perform for our second season at the VelocityDC Dance Festival.

Your assistance has a deep, far-reaching and long lasting impact and extends far beyond just the scope of these performances, continuing to enable us in providing no-cost to low-cost tickets to underserved audiences to our upcoming performances; remunerate world-class dancers and choreographers that are featured in our season; deepen, broaden and diversify our community outreach efforts;programming and expanding our arts-education programs.

 Kindly consider supporting STUART LOUNGWAY/Terra Firma Dance Theatre, and know that your contribution assists in ensuring arts-accessibility and programming that is of the highest caliber.  All contributions are tax-deductible, and we extend the utmost gratitude.


WHY YOUR SUPPORT MATTERS

Thanks to your past valued support in past seasons, we were able to create a solid foundation that will serve as a springboard as we continue to fulfill our mission objectives in providing affordable and accessible dance of high-artistic merit. 

To share a small sampling of what your past support has enabled:

-VELOCITYDC Dance Festival 2015 Company Premiere

-Kaatsbaan International Dance Center Residency 2014; producing and performing two critically-championed works.

-We successfully met our fund-raising goals; presenting a full-Spring season featuring the work of Artistic Director, Stuart Loungway; former Cedar Lake dancer, Manuel Vignoulle; and recent Princess Grace-fellowship recipient Loni Landon

-Traveled to Poland, by invitation, to perform at Krakow Nights...an annual arts festival

-Educational-development and outreach projects with Helen Pickett in Forsythe-improvisational techniques.

-Shared the stage with stars of NYCB and ABT in relief efforts for the Philippines, coordinated by Ashley Bouder-NYCB principal

....and much much more

 In expanding the breadth of our activities during the 2015/16 season we invite your support as we undertake this treasured opportunity to immerse ourselves fully in the creation of a new work, and utilize it as a catalyst to expand our ambitious programming and objectives for the following season in our new home.

TO LEARN MORE ABOUT TERRA FIRMA DANCE, please visit www.tfdance.org 



·     

About Terra Firma Dance Theatre

 Terra Firma Dance Theatre (TFDT), under the guidance of Artistic Director, Stuart Loungway, serves as a cultural think-tank for the dance landscape of Washington, DC and beyond.

Promoting an environment that cultivates dialogue and the exchange of creative ideas as exemplified through our dance performance, educational outreach and experimental theater initiatives. Our primary focal points are underserved populations and non-traditional theatergoers in order to introduce them to the power of the arts as a life changing force. As a rapidly rising contemporary ballet company, the core of our work focuses on movement as the primary language of basic human interaction and communion.

In providing a risk-free environment of diversity, TFDT emphasizes the value of dance as a medium to enrich, empower and engage all members of the community via its high-quality, accessible and affordable programming.

As vanguard caretakers of the art form of ballet, we actively seek to promote new audiences and heighten their awareness and willingness to move away from “traditional and typical dance models”. With a responsible eye to the future of ballet, we work to provide a progressive and contemporary experience, with the understanding that ballet will not look as it once has.

The interwoven philosophical, societal and political issues of the 18th and 19th centuries, that once informed and governed the creation and understanding of new dance work and art in general, no longer exist. It is with this notion in mind that we embark upon our mission to present a new and viable model that preserves ballet as a current and relevant art form, which carries the potential to provide a deep and long lasting impact upon its audience members

Terra Firma Dance Theater is comprised of 5 high-caliber dancers: Izabela Szylinska (formerly of Polish National Ballet), Lester Badenoch (former dancer w/ Atlanta Ballet, American Repertory Ballet, North Carolina Dance Theatre), Tiffany Mangulabnan (current soloist, Ballet Next; former Principal- Philippine Ballet Theatre); Holly Curran (freelance dancer, Metropolitan Opera Ballet, New Chamber Dance); Jessica Miller (recent SUNY Purchase graduate)

The company has steadily increased in its capacity with the generous support of the Geraldine Dodge Foundation; New Jersey State Council for the Arts; Hyde and Watson....and supporters such as YOU!

About the Director

Stuart Loungwayis the Founder/Artistic Director of Terra Firma Dance Theatre. His training began with Tania Lichine, Irina Jacobson, and John Clifford before receiving a full scholarship to the prestigious School of American Ballet. He began his professional career performing with the Houston Ballet and Joffrey Ballet, before joining San Francisco Ballet Company and continuing as a Principal Dancer with American Repertory Ballet. He has performed soloist and principal roles in work by David Bintley, James Kudelka, George Balanchine, William Forsythe, Mark Morris, and many others. Mr. Loungway maintains an active schedule as a master teacher, choreographer, performer, and served on the dance faculty at Mason Gross School of the Arts, Rutgers University. Selected as “Who’s Hot” by National Dance Critics Association Chair Karyn Collins, Mr. Loungway’s choreography, as expressed by Robert Johnson of Dance Europe, is “elegant and evocative” and “bodes well for the future of dance.” His work and company have been featured in the national dance publication Pointe Magazine.

His work has been featured at Ballet Builders/New Choreographers on Pointe. He is the recipient of the Individual Fellowship in Choreography, awarded by the New Jersey State Council for the Arts ( a branch of the National Endowment for the Arts), in recognition of the high artistic merit of his work. He has served as an Artist- in-Residence at Rutgers University, Desales University, and most recently choreographed work for the students of SUNY PURCHASE.  He has served as the Ballet Master for Roxey Ballet; as well as a principal faculty member at Joffrey Ballet School , in addition to teaching ballet technique and contemporary ballet at Steps and Peridance. His work and company were selected to be featured at Jacob’s Pillow. He currently is on the faculty of the Peridance Certificate Program; where he also teaches numerous advanced and professional-level ballet classes; he also serves as a company teacher for the Washington Ballet, as well as a faculty member in the schools of The Washington Ballet, CITYDANCE, Jones-Haywood.  He most recently was awarded Outstanding Choreographer at Youth America Grand Prix.

story:
Spanish Dance & Me

I am a Spanish Dance Instructor. Spanish Dance is predominantly a percussive dance; the dancer is also the musician, creating elaborate rhythms and counter-rhythms using castanets, footwork, clapping, finger snaps and an assortment of other methods.

There are four main categories of Spanish Dance, namely: Escuela Bolera, Clasico, Regional, and the most popular Flamenco. ​Spanish dance has since taken on various influences and expanded into a form with immensely diverse and distinctive styles. 

Soul of Spain

This is a lecture demonstration on Spanish Dances, designed to introduce audiences to a wide range of dance genres from Spain, including but not limited to Flamenco. It covers not only the different categories of Spanish Dance, but also the use of unique props (eg: castanets, bata de colas). This provides audiences with a broader view of Spanish Dance and the understanding that there are many different areas of dance that a practitioner may choose to excel in.

Invited speaker Mdm. Deanna Blacher shares her insights and knowledge on the culture and evolution of the various Spanish Dances, assisted intermittently by Van Su Yun as her dance demonstrator. It takes place on 13th October 2016.

Costs & Funding

"Soul of Spain" is being held as part of the Got To Move 2016 programme, and therefore has free registration. However, I still need a lot of help to cover the costs of presenting "Soul of Spain"!

I'm looking to raise roughly SGD 4300, or USD 3200 (original budget was SGD 4800; SGD500 has been granted under the GTM2016 programme). This will go towards paying first and foremost for items such as: Mdm. Blacher's fees, rehearsal space, flooring, technicians' cost, and programme collatorals. I'd also like to be able to pay for a guitarist, and to leave something aside for the production team, who would otherwise be doing this without compensation.

I committed to this project despite limited funds and the heavy risk as I believe that there is much that needs to be done to dispel misconceptions about Spanish Dance, as well as to show the different nuances and evolution, and there is no better person to helm it than Mdm. Blacher, who has had over 60 years of experience in this field.

Other Ways You Can Help

Not all of us are in a position to contribute, but that doesn't mean we can't help! Get your friends and family on board and share this campaign!

Invited speaker Mdm. Deanna Blacher shares her insights and knowledge on the culture and evolution of the various Spanish Dances, assisted intermittently by Van Su Yun as her dance demonstrator. It takes place on 13th October 2016.
Costs & Funding
"Soul of Spain" is being held as part of the Got To Move 2016 programme, and therefore has free registration. However, I still need a lot of help to cover the costs of presenting "Soul of Spain"!
I'm looking to raise roughly SGD 4300, or USD 3200 (original budget was SGD 4800; SGD500 has been granted under the GTM2016 programme). This will go towards paying first and foremost for items such as: Mdm. Blacher's fees, rehearsal space, flooring, technicians' cost, and programme collatorals. I'd also like to be able to pay for a guitarist, and to leave something aside for the production team, who would otherwise be doing this without compensation.
I committed to this project despite limited funds and the heavy risk as I believe that there is much that needs to be done to dispel misconceptions about Spanish Dance, as well as to show the different nuances and evolution, and there is no better person to helm it than Mdm. Blacher, who has had over 60 years of experience in this field.

Other Ways You Can Help
Not all of us are in a position to contribute, but that doesn't mean we can't help! Get your friends and family on board and share this campaign!

story:
Short Summary

Based off the tragic incidents of the LRA army in Uganda, Nankunda is a short story about a boy who is captured by the LRA. This tragic incident leads to the awful moment where he must decide to either kill his mother or watch her be killed before he dies as well. This moving story reflects the true essence of a mother's love and the sacrifice that is more powerful than hatred.

About The Director:

In the past seven years, Alyssa Sprague has traveled to China, Rwanda, Kazakhstan, and the Philippines where she’s gotten most of her inspiration for her stories. Her first book, A Step Outside is scheduled to be published within the next five months with Tate Publishing Company. She was assistant director of Willy Wonka at BellMar Theatricals and dance director for Alice and Wonderland at Hillcrest High School. She is an experienced dancer who started in gymnastics at the age of six. She’s trained in acro, tumbling, jazz, contemporary, hip hop, ballet, lyrical, modern and musical theatre. She performed in musicals like Chicago and A Chorus Line with BellaMar Theatricals where she directed her own original dance show, A Step Outside. She was also a member of the hip hop crew Natural State and did a series of choreography projects throughout the Inland Empire. Currently, Alyssa dances with the Blackbird Dance Company in Hollywood and is building a number of online markets. She lives in Fullerton with her husband and it looking forward to the prospects headed her way.

Alyssa Liu is a dancer and writer, with a heart of gold. She has made it her mission in life to help the children in undeveloped countries. She wrote Nankunda to raise awareness about the hardships that children in  Central Africa have to endure.

 

  • We are producing Nankunda to be a stage play, where many influential people will be invited to the premiere. We are confident that everyone in attendance will love the show, and our hope is that this will raise awareness for the cause. 
  • If the play is well received and we are able to raise enough funds, the next step in the plan will be to turn Nankunda into a feature film. This of course, would be the ultimate way to help the children as a substantial portion of the proceeds from the film will go to organizations like UNICEF which dedicate themselves to helping children in these impoverished countries.

Did you know...

-Because of a poor distribution of wealth, the Uganda government spends only 1.9% of it's GDP on health

-Uganda's GDP per capita is only $332, marking it as one of the poorest countries in the world.

-There are only 4 doctors and 28 nurses per every 100,000 people in Uganda.

- 23.1 million Ugandans are likely to fall into poverty and about 8.4 million are trapped in absolute poverty.

 

What We Need & What You Get

You can help us turn this project into a reality, no matter how much you give:

  • We need at least $3,000 to rent a theater for a night. Everyone will be invited to come free of charge.
  • We would like to feed our guests as well. This will cost an additional $1,500.
  • Currently, the dancers and choreographers are rehearsing the play without getting paid for their time. If we can raise another $3,000 we can pay each dancer at least for doing the play.
  • If we can produce another trailer with footage from the actual play when it takes place, this will generate a great deal of energy and help us raise the necessary funds to turn the play into a movie! Production of another trailer will cost us $4,500 for a professional-looking video.

Of course, we have perks for those who help the cause!

  • If you give $30, you will get a ticket to the show
  • If you give $50, you get a pair of tickets to the show
  • If you give $100, you get a pair of tickets, plus a pair of limited edition Nankunda t-shirts
  • If you give $250, you will get a 4-pack of tickets, a 4 Nankunda t-shirts, and a special mention before the start of the show and on social media
  • If you give $500, you will get all of the above, plus a chance to come up on stage and speak. If you cannot attend the event, we will be glad to display a video of your speech.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to contribute right now, there are other ways you can help:

  • Please share this campaign with all your friends on Facebook, Instagram, twitter, etc.
  • Make sure to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you so much for your time. We hope to see you at the show!

If you give $250, you will get a 4-pack of tickets, a 4 Nankunda t-shirts, and a special mention before the start of the show and on social media

Other Ways You Can Help
If you are not able to contribute right now, there are other ways you can help:

Please share this campaign with all your friends on Facebook, Instagram, twitter, etc.
Make sure to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you so much for your time. We hope to see you at the show!

story:
ANNE BOLEYN FOR PRESIDENT OF CLASS OF 2014

Transport Anne Boleyn to a cutthroat liberal arts college. Enter Henry (the Eighth) – bro with a heart of gold and President of the all-powerful Student Council. Enter Catherine (Queen Catherine, that is), decked out in Lily Pulitzer and the Holy Bible. And enter Anne’s ladies (in waiting), who help her enforce the feminist agenda, with the hopes of landing one of them in the White House. Yes, that White House. In the new millennium, see if Anne’s mystical beauty, incessant drive, thirst for power, and daring lust can bring the Queen (Bee) to the top of the food chain. 

Team

Playwright/Co-Producer................................................ Gina Doherty

Director.............................................................................Katie Lindsay

Co-Producer...........................................................Gabrielle Nieporent

Creative Consultant....................................................Amanda Nelson

CAST

Anne (Boleyn)...................................................................Gina Doherty

Henry (the Eighth)...................................................Billy Berger-Bailey

Marcella..........................................................................Avery Deutsch

Julissa..................................................................................Diane Chen

(Queen) Catherine.......................................................Rebecca Sands

ANNE BOLEYN FOR PRESIDENT OF THE CLASS OF 2014 is the inaugural production of our company: Off With Her Head Productions. Inspired by the tragic ends of women like Anne Boleyn and Marie Antoinette, the mission of this company is to take stories about women and re-imagine them, whether that be by placing classic stories in a modern setting, or taking stereotypes of women that have pervaded until today, and turning them on their heads. We are also interested in exploring the ways that women have and can break out of social constructs that have been imposed on them. Check out plans for our future projects, and learn more about the team behind ANNE BOLEYN... on our website:

http://www.ginadoherty.com/off-with-her-head-productions.html

https://www.facebook.com/offwithherheadproductions

We Need Your help! 

This first production at Dixon Place is a workshop to help us see how full realized technical elements will help enhance and enliven the overall vision of our play. We're hoping to raise money for these things:

  • Stipends for Director, Actors, Production and Design Team
  • Rehearsal Space
  • Set, Costumes, Visuals, and a bathub! See the show to find out why!
  • Marketing materials

Other Ways You Can Help

We recognize that not everyone is in a position to donate. You can also help us out by spreading the word! Please share our indiegogo with all of your friends and like our Facebook page. Most importantly, please support us by coming to see ANNE BOLEYN FOR PRESIDENT OF THE CLASS 2014 on Tuesday, November 29th, at 7:30pm at Dixon Place (161A Chrystie St, New York, NY). Or buy tickets to see the show here: http://dixonplace.org/performances/anne-boleyn-...

story:
What is "Voyager" 

Neshamah, a New York based company that explores metaphysics through dance, is currently focusing on crafting an evening length piece in collaboration with AirSticks co-creator Alon Ilsar. We’ve titled this new piece “Voyager”. "Voyager" uses the narrative and sounds of NASA’s Voyager I and II to explore the shoreline where science and art converse.  As a company, we’ve been studying many examples of those shorelines. We’ve also been using excerpts of Carl Sagan’s book “Cosmos” to lead our inquiries. 
 

What We Need & What You Get

We need funding to do a works-in-progress showing in January 2017. This showing will include a performance of the piece, a talk-back session with Neshamah's Founder and Artistic Director Hannah Cohen and Alon Illsar, and a discussion about the shoreline between science and art lead by a panel of scientists and artists including Kiran Rajagopalan - a behavioral neuroscientist and classical Indian dancer. 

Once we’ve performed we will condense the footage, feedback, and images into grant proposals to fund future performances, rehearsals, and tours. 

We’ve already secured a performance space in the heart of New York City called The Kraine Theater and will be performing on January 10th but we need $10,000 for costuming, the performance venue, lights, advertisement, staff and performer wages, video documentation and editing, etc.

Based on your donation level you will receive certain perks including:

  • A free Neshamah company dance class
  • A Neshamah long sleeve shirt
  • Tickets to our show at The Kraine Theater on January 10th, 2016
  • A personalized Thank You card signed by the cast
  • A copy of Carl Sagan's book "Cosmos"
  • A special Thank You on the Playbill
  • A producer credit
  • A shoutout at the performance

The Impact

We believe a conversation between the arts and the sciences is an important exploration and that through the medium of dance we can inspire a lasting dialogue.

We are already committed and locked down to this performance but we need YOU to help ignite its potential. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help!  Please share our campaign and get the word out!

story:
About The Show
A Heart At Sea is an epic musical folktale told on a miniature scale. The show uses haunting live music to tell the story of a young Boy who bottles up his heart and throws it into the sea. Original song-writing (Avi's job!) is set to breathtaking visuals centred around a beautifully carved wooden chest (Peter's creation!) that holds the secrets to the story.
 
Intricate puppets are swept through a transforming wooden world created by the spectacular chest. Backdrops flip up, pirouette and change, sending the Boy tumbling through danger and discovery. Puppets roam on this unique contraption to recount the story of whales, tiny boats, sea captains and beards.
  
A Heart at Sea was launched in April 2016 in a secret garden, in the pilgrim’s city of Canterbury at the WiseWords Festival. Since then it has embarked on a Spring 2017 Tour, was nominated for Les Enfants Terribles LET AWARD, and landed a spot in The Pleasance programme at the Edinburgh Festival 2017. The production was grown out of a love for storytelling, live music and puppetry.



Why The Edinburgh Festival?

The Edinburgh Festival is the worlds largest Arts Festival. Being a part of the festival, means having the unique opportunity to showcase your creative work to programmers, press and agencies. Out show will be on at highly credible venue, The Pleasance: Courtyard, and you can find our listing here. For us, this ultimately means the chance to reach more and more audiences with A Heart At Sea, in Edinburgh, in the UK, and internationally.

As many of you will know, taking work to the Edinburgh Festival is no small feat. The costs are high, and the only means to make your money back is tickets sales. It is hard to break even, and we are aware of the risks. The biggest way to get people through the door to the show, is to hand out flyers on the days. Our goal with this campaign, as well as the hard work we put in in the three weeks we are performing, is to help us do the Edinburgh Festival without making a loss.

This is where your contribution comes in!

Important Contribution no.1:  We need help to foot the cost of posters and flyers, so we can  hand out flyers everyday to families, passersby, and audiences for other theatre shows. Pete has already designed a strategic flyer-ing schedule, to make sure we can maximise our audiences, but we need the print itself. The money raised in this campaign will cover the cost of printing thousands of flyers to help us sell the show.

Important Contribution No.2: A bed for Peter. As we're sure you'll agree, a roof over the head is better than no roof over the head. Particularly when performing. For 26 days straight. SO we figured we should probably pay to put Pete up somewhere, as well as our lovely lighting designer Ines, and the few volunteers who are helping us flyer. Very Important! So the rest of the money will go towards the cost of accommodation for these lovely folk.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We Need

  • £300 - Flyer and Poster Printing 
  • £900 - Pete & Ines' Accommodation

You Get!

  • Our deep gratitude, thanks and appreciation!
  • Rewards Rewards Rewards - please see right hand banner for details on the wonderful rewards we have on offer.


Meet The Team
Peter Morton: Artistic Director of Half A String
Visual Artist, Performer & Puppeteer



Peter is a visual artist who specialises in intricate puppet design and physical performance. He trained at the University of Kent in a Masters in contemporary performance and has since worked with a number of companies including Stuff and Nonsense, Sparkle and Dark, ​Theatre Témoin, Wide-Eyed, and The Big Reveal whilst also training with the National Theatre’s War Horse. Peter is also Joint Artistic Director of Knuckle and Joint Theatre Company who create fun, dynamic puppetry performances ranging from large outdoor shows to intimate cabarets.

Avi Simmons
Associate Artist
Performer, Collaborator, Musician and Writer



Kent based singer-songwriter Avi Simmons has been captivating audiences for over 6 years, performing beautifully crafted original songs, combining acoustic guitar with delicate but powerful vocals. Her performances create a uniquely intimate, emotionally charged and joyful atmosphere like no other. ‘Avi Simmons is something special, not to be missed!’ Gulbenkian 2015. Her debut EP ‘You Said Live' was launched at the Gulbenkian Theatre in 2016, and captures the spirit of her stunning performances. Her songwriting for 'A Heart At Sea' tells the epic tale with intricacy and drama.​

story:
Short Summary

  • Little Epic Theatre are Naomi Carter and Vince Stadon.  We met in 2011 when Naomi joined the cast of The Bristol Sitcom Trials, which Vince produced for 4 years. Naomi wrote and starred in several winning scripts (one of which made the finals of So You Think You Write Funny? at the Gilded Balloon), and as Vince branched out into writing and producing comedy plays (including Checkpoint Dave and Sherlock Holmes and the Devil's Whisper), Naomi wrote and starred in Barbara and Jeffrey, her first one act play, which was a hit in Bristol and Bath.  Vince and Naomi bring hilarious new writing to stages across the south west, without breaking any laws.  Well, not many.
  • We want to workshop key moments from our latest play, an ambitious two act comedy with four interlinked stories and complicated slapstick sequences.
  • Workshopping new writing is vital to the process because without seeing what the play looks like on its feet - with actors performing key moments - we have no real idea of what we've written, or how it can be staged.  We need to see bits of our play to understand it.  And perhaps to understand ourselves.  I mean, we wrote this thing.  What does it say aqbout us?  We urgently need to know.  Our Therapy depends on it. 
  • Plus, filming/photographing the workshop is part of our pledge to share with the public every part of the process of writing and staging a play.  You can read all about the writing of the play on our blog here: http://littleepictheatre.blogspot.co.uk/

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need £500 to pay actors, hire a space, feed our cast and film the workshop.  We have a cast of twelve, but for the workshop we'll need only seven or eight actors (there will be some doubling-up of roles).  We need these actors for two days - we're looking at a weekend in November - and we'll need to pay them for their time and feed them while they do what they do so brilliantly. We'll be looking to hire a space in central Bristol (at £50 per day), and we'll record everything on camera, including the tantrums that inevitably erupt when we run out of biscuits.
  • We have unique perks to offer our backers!  We could have been lazy and just had a load of cheap mugs and t-shirts printed with the Little Epic logo, but we've gone that extra mile for you and we're creating unique items! (Plus, we couldn't get cheap mugs and t-shirts printed with the Little Epic logo). From sending you insulting letters, to singing songs about you, painting your portraits and remaking your favourite movies, we've got a personalised perks package tailored to our backers - you won't want to miss out!
  • If we don't reach full funding, we'll film ourselves crying.  But we were going to do that anyway (crying with tears of joy and relief), so you might as well give us the full funding.  If we don't get it all, we'll put whatever we have reached towards the workshop, fulfil the pledges, and we'll look to other means of reaching the full amount. 
 

Risks & Challenges

  • Getting new theatre made is very difficult.  By and large audiences prefer to go and see plays they've heard of starring people they've heard of, in theatres they've heard of.  The Bristol Old Vic, for instance, could stage The Importance of Being Earnest, starring Nigel Havers, forever and ever and ever, and sell out every night.  People really love Nigel Havers.  We have written something new, something complicated to stage, something that's a big risk.  We've staged new plays in small theatres above pubs, and it's been great fun - but with this play we need a bigger stage, which means we'll need to attract bigger audiences, and that's increasingly difficult.  The workshop will provide us with a wealth of visual material (including clips) that we can actually show to people in the industry to get feedback, and/or eventually funding and staging.  It's risky, but we have faith in our play, and we're determined to bring The Art of Getting Unlucky to the best theatres in the west country, and bring in the audiences that make the endeavour successful. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. And we mean that literally - get yourself a megaphone (everyone should have a megaphone!) and shout, "Little Epic Theatre need your help!" to people on buses and in chemist's.
  • And remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you for your help - you're very kind and we're very grateful.
story_txt:
Short Summary

Little Epic Theatre are Naomi Carter and Vince Stadon.  We met in 2011 when Naomi joined the cast of The Bristol Sitcom Trials, which Vince produced for 4 years. Naomi wrote and starred in several winning scripts (one of which made the finals of So You Think You Write Funny? at the Gilded Balloon), and as Vince branched out into writing and producing comedy plays (including Checkpoint Dave and Sherlock Holmes and the Devil's Whisper), Naomi wrote and starred in Barbara and Jeffrey, her first one act play, which was a hit in Bristol and Bath.  Vince and Naomi bring hilarious new writing to stages across the south west, without breaking any laws.  Well, not many.
We want to workshop key moments from our latest play, an ambitious two act comedy with four interlinked stories and complicated slapstick sequences.
Workshopping new writing is vital to the process because without seeing what the play looks like on its feet - with actors performing key moments - we have no real idea of what we've written, or how it can be staged.  We need to see bits of our play to understand it.  And perhaps to understand ourselves.  I mean, we wrote this thing.  What does it say aqbout us?  We urgently need to know.  Our Therapy depends on it. 
Plus, filming/photographing the workshop is part of our pledge to share with the public every part of the process of writing and staging a play.  You can read all about the writing of the play on our blog here: http://littleepictheatre.blogspot.co.uk/



What We Need & What You Get

We need £500 to pay actors, hire a space, feed our cast and film the workshop.  We have a cast of twelve, but for the workshop we'll need only seven or eight actors (there will be some doubling-up of roles).  We need these actors for two days - we're looking at a weekend in November - and we'll need to pay them for their time and feed them while they do what they do so brilliantly. We'll be looking to hire a space in central Bristol (at £50 per day), and we'll record everything on camera, including the tantrums that inevitably erupt when we run out of biscuits.
We have unique perks to offer our backers!  We could have been lazy and just had a load of cheap mugs and t-shirts printed with the Little Epic logo, but we've gone that extra mile for you and we're creating unique items! (Plus, we couldn't get cheap mugs and t-shirts printed with the Little Epic logo). From sending you insulting letters, to singing songs about you, painting your portraits and remaking your favourite movies, we've got a personalised perks package tailored to our backers - you won't want to miss out!
If we don't reach full funding, we'll film ourselves crying.  But we were going to do that anyway (crying with tears of joy and relief), so you might as well give us the full funding.  If we don't get it all, we'll put whatever we have reached towards the workshop, fulfil the pledges, and we'll look to other means of reaching the full amount. 

 
Risks & Challenges
Getting new theatre made is very difficult.  By and large audiences prefer to go and see plays they've heard of starring people they've heard of, in theatres they've heard of.  The Bristol Old Vic, for instance, could stage The Importance of Being Earnest, starring Nigel Havers, forever and ever and ever, and sell out every night.  People really love Nigel Havers.  We have written something new, something complicated to stage, something that's a big risk.  We've staged new plays in small theatres above pubs, and it's been great fun - but with this play we need a bigger stage, which means we'll need to attract bigger audiences, and that's increasingly difficult.  The workshop will provide us with a wealth of visual material (including clips) that we can actually show to people in the industry to get feedback, and/or eventually funding and staging.  It's risky, but we have faith in our play, and we're determined to bring The Art of Getting Unlucky to the best theatres in the west country, and bring in the audiences that make the endeavour successful. 

Other Ways You Can Help
Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

Please get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. And we mean that literally - get yourself a megaphone (everyone should have a megaphone!) and shout, "Little Epic Theatre need your help!" to people on buses and in chemist's.
And remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you for your help - you're very kind and we're very grateful.

story:
The Project

In “Elizabeth Wants a Sword Fight” a young girl sets out in search of adventure, as embodied by a real sword fight. She journeys through strange lands and wanders in and out of various Shakespeare plays. She meets Rosalind and Celia (from As You Like It) lost in the Forest of Arden, takes an ocean cruise with Prince Hamlet and his best friends Rosie and Gil, is drafted by some Scottish witches to replace a missing member of their trio. She fights Bohemian bears, tangles with pirates and knights, and lands right in the middle of the political intrigue surrounding the Empty Crown. And all the while, her nemesis is lurking in wait.

 

The original play, written by company co-founder Alan Irvine, combines both physical comedy and wit with high-energy action and sword play. We are currently hard at work preparing the play for its world premier at the 2017 Pittsburgh Fringe Festival March 31-April 2.

 

Your Help

As a small company, we work hard to keep expenses low. Performing at Fringe Festivals helps with that. For example, we don’t have to rent an entire venue by ourselves. But we do need to cover our application and performance fees with the Fringe. And we always discover that we need  some props or costumes that none of us have stashed in our closets. And we want to publicize the show so that audiences can find us. The more of these costs we can cover up front, the more ticket revenue can go directly to the actors. And then they can buy things like food. Well fed actors give better performances.

 

 

Who is Brawling Bard?
We are a small company. Some of us are full-time performers, some of us combine performing with other occupations. Once or twice a year we come together to work on a new show. We do original works, written by company co-founder Alan Irvine, that mix comedy, Shakespeare, and stage combat. Since many members of the company have been with us since the beginning, Alan can write parts for specific actors, matching the characters to each actor’s strength and style, just as Shakespeare himself did. At the same time, we always look for new actors to invite in to join us. With two stage combat professionals in the company, we strive to include plenty of high quality, high energy, high enjoyment fight action in all our shows. And most important, we work hard to make sure our audiences have fun.

 

Our first show won the Audience Choice award at the 2014 Pittsburgh Fringe Festival, our second show won the Golden Crow (Spirit of the Fringe Award) at the 2015 Pittsburgh Fringe Festival, and our third show won the Best Ensemble Award in 2016. With your help, our 2017 show will be even better than these.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Janet Aisawa and I created, direct and perform in "Them,"   a multimedia dance that will be presented by The Performance Project at University Settlement.   After twelve years, “Them” will finally be complete.  It will include interviews with my aunts, uncles, and their friends, Japanese Americans, who were forced from their homes and placed in concentration camps in the United States during WWII.  

This project is important to me because it passes down these stories to a new generation.  I hope it will start conversations and questions about what it means to be “them” and “us”  and about seeing people as people, rather than "others" or enemies. 

Yuko Takebe’s film, “Shadows of Hiroshima” will be shown with the dances.  The film asks, “How do we live in the world today with the atomic bomb?"

At the end of June, two new dances will be added to complete “Them” at the performances at University Settlement.  We will also have an exhibit of pictures, historical items, and some additional video interviews that are not included in the performances.  The exhibit will be shown on the second floor of the University Settlement and will give background to the dances in "Them."

Before the performances the audience members will be invited to make origami cranes containing their wishes for peace as part of the Cranes for Peace Project.   I will place a string of 1,000 of the cranes on Sadako’s Children’s Memorial in Hiroshima, Japan in August, to commemorate the 72nd anniversary of the atomic bombing of the city.  Sadako was a little girl who survived the blast but died at the age of 12 from leukemia caused by radiation from the bomb.  The cranes are a symbol of her legacy for hope and peace. 

I want to express my deepest gratitude to all who have supported my efforts to tell the stories in “Them”.   This support has made a huge difference in the process of creating “Them.”  Now in order to complete this work, I am asking for additional significant support. 

What We Need

Your contribution will help pay the amazing performers that are working on this piece with me - Osamu Uehara, Sumi Matsumoto, Boonyarith Pankamdech, Keely Dana, Jessica Madera, Jake Park, and Emily Winkler-Morey.  I am raising money to pay these dancers, whose tireless dedication has made this piece a reality.
I am also seeking donations to help pay for theater rental, publicity, studio rehearsal rental, videography, costumes, and production costs, such as those associated with the magical lighting of John Nichter.

The Impact

Your contribution will help to create a continued awareness of the ongoing prejudices that continue to repress us today.  Last winter I was able to speak with students at Stuyvesant High School about prejudice and the immigrant experience and included the video interviews from “Them.”

Challenges

The challenge is to get as many people as possible to come to the performances of "Them" at the end of June and to come to see the historical exhibition.  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help:

Please help by sharing this campaign with others through Facebook, Twitter, or your email contacts.  And please come to the show!

story:
Can we have a serious conversation about a problem and still be able to laugh? That’s what we here at kamrDANCE are asking in our upcoming premiere of our newest work “Catch 22”, a satirical piece about the double bind that exists for women in society, especially in positions of power.

My name is Alexis Robbins and I'm the Artistic Director and choreographer of kamrDANCE, a tap and contemporary/modern dance company. We have been making work and performing in NYC and Massachusetts since 2015 and we are currently embarking on our biggest project yet - premiering a 35 minute piece at Dixon Place called "Catch 22"! This campaign is important to us because we believe the message of this work is a vital conversation to be had. We also plan to continue creating new comedic, satirical, and important work to bring to as many audiences as possible. Any donation amount is helpful and will help us move forward in our preparation process for "Catch 22".

kamrDANCE is looking to raise $950 which will cover rehearsal space, costumes, stage manager compensation, and most importantly, dancer compensation. Often today, dancers in emerging companies have to rehearse for free due to lack of funds and with your help our dancers will be compensated the rates they deserve. As a company we rehearse for this show specifically 1-2 times a week for 2-3 hours at a time. Rehearsal space can cost anywhere from $15-30/hour. Any amount is helpful and will go directly towards the above mentioned places. If you want to help but can't donate you can aid us by sharing our campaign, following us on social media and sharing the show information, or by coming to the show and giving us feedback!

Thanks in advance,

Alexis Robbins/kamrDANCE

story:
All the world's a stage...

Rochester Community Players is excited to present Shakespeare's As You Like It, directed by Maria Scipione, running July 14–29 in Highland Park. This year marks the twentieth anniversary of RCP's Shakespeare Players program producing free Shakespeare in Highland Park!

Shakespeare’s witty comedy subverts the rules of gender and romance. The play contrasts the regimented court of Duke Frederick and the Forest of Arden, where freedom provides relief from fraternal conflicts. As You Like It already embraces the power of freedom, love, and rebellion, and our production will highlight those themes by setting the story within the musical backdrop of Woodstock.

Your support makes it possible for us to present the show for free and to share our work with thousands of people in the Rochester community.

And thereby hangs a tale! (Jaques, Act 2, scene 7)
 


A crowd gathers for Free Shakespeare at Highland Bowl 
A Midsummer Night's Dream, 2014
(photo by Annette Dragon)

Risks & Challenges

Putting on a show of this scale is always expensive. Some of our expenses include:

  • $3,000 sound rental
  • $1,000 set building
  • $1,000 costumes
  • $2,000 rehearsal space 

Without ticket sales to underwrite our costs, we rely on your support!
 

Adopt-a-Character

This year we are introducing a new fundraising format: adopt-a-character. Your contribution will help "clothe" (costume) and "shelter" (set) the characters of your choice. In addition to perks to help you enjoy the show, like enjoying free popcorn every time you see the show, you will be thanked in the program and in a thank you letter from your character! 

Meet the groups:

  • The Court: the bastion of traditional values, lead by Duke Frederick, this group includes Oliver, Jaques de Boys, Le Beau, and Charles.
  • The Foresters: the exiled court, enjoying the freedom of their sylvan retreat; lead by Duke Senior, this group includes Amiens, Adam, and Hymen.
  • The Shepherds: the local rustics, whose lives are upended by all the visiting courtiers, this group includes Corin, Audrey, Silvius, Phoebe, and Sir Oliver Martex. 

Artists Poster

Each adoption includes a copy of the show poster signed by the artist, Matt Moore. 

  • You will be able to claim your poster at the concessions stand during any performance. If you prefer to have your poster mailed, there will be a $5 shipping fee. 

Popcorn Wars

Everyone who donates above the $10 level will receive the perk of free popcorn every time you come see the show!  

  • Claim the most popcorn to win a poster signed by the cast! And because we love our dedicated fans, in the event of a tie we will give multiple prizes!

Additional rewards will be unlocked as we reach fundraising milestones. Stay tuned for more details!

Rochester Community Players is a non-profit, 501(c)3 organization. All donations are tax-deductible to the fullest extent allowable by law, and all supporters of the campaign will receive a donation receipt for their records. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word about the show, and bring a chair, a blanket, a picnic supper, and your sense of humor to Highland park, and join us for free Shakespeare under the stars!

From painting the set to hanging posters to selling popcorn, we have lots of opportunities to help out behind the scenes! Join our volunteer team to get updates on all the projects that need your help: http://www.rochestercommunityplayers.org/help-wanted/

Is your business looking for a community outreach opportunity? We are also selling advertisements in the program, which we expect will reach an audience of 4,000. Please email us at rochestercommunityplayers@gmail.org for more information. 

 

O wonderful, wonderful, most wonderful wonderful, and yet again wonderful, and after that, out of all whooping!

 (Celia, Act 3, scene 2)

story:
Hello, I'm Laure Courtellemont!

 

Originally from France, I am an international choreographer currently residing in Los Angeles. I’ve dreamt of bringing my ideas and visions to life while inspiring others to do so by collaborating and spotlighting amazing dancers. I discovered Dancehall 20 years ago in France. Since then I’ve taken on this mission to bring this amazing dance and culture to the forefront by teaching and traveling professionally all over the world. I’ve trained and studied the history of Dancehall and its core with all my heart, love, and respect for over two decades. Today, I can say that I am the woman I am largely because of this expression!

- MY GOAL

One of my great dreams for this Jamaican originated art form is to give it an opportunity to be displayed on a live stage with some of the best dancers and actors of its kind. I want to showcase this passionate dance in all its glory in a way that any other well-respected dance should be shown. The Show will be held at Movement Lifestyle in North Hollywood, on June 17th,  2017.

 

The Impact

 

1- PLATFORM OF EXPRESSION

I want to give Dancehall a strong platform to show its power and potential to the world. Showcasing an amazing dance expression and spotlighting great talents.

2- DIVERSITY

Born and raised in France, I am strong in my identity as a European dancer and choreographer having been immersed in a multi-cultural environment. I want to apply this by bringing together dancers from different countries onto one stage to find the delicate balance between the foundation of this dance and its artistic potential. I want to help create the path for Dancehall to find its place from the street to the stage. The show will be filmed and also live streamed in multiple countries.

3- A SHOW FOR UNITY

This show will bring worldwide personalities of this dance form on one stage to remind all of us the power of unity! Different minds, energies, and flavors from all around the world connecting around the same love for dance. This organic African descent expression is a powerful dance rooted in meaning and passion. This show will bring attention to the dance industry and all lovers of dance a huge understanding and appreciation for this often misunderstood art form.

4- GIVING BACK

I want to give back to Jamaica and its incredibly rich culture by crediting a full-length showcase of Dancehall with some of the best of this genre.

A week before the show, on June 17th, the international dancers of the show will teach a one-day workshop and lecture about Dancehall and its Culture. All the proceeds from this workshop will be sent to children in need in Jamaica.
 


What We Need & What You Get


- WHAT WE NEED

  • My funding goal is $27,500 to cover all costs of the show including rental space for 2 weeks of rehearsals, full day rental of the venue to hold 2 showings, production (including lighting, equipment, crew, security, staff, designer, producer, assistant, make up artist, hair stylist), filming and editing, live-streaming, etc.
  • Dancers from all over the world will come to North Hollywood for 2 weeks of intense training and rehearsals to create this platform to represent what we believe and live for. Their hard work and commitment will all be to prepare for this one night. Their passion will show the world the power of this art form, the power of making children's lives better, and the power of unity. These dancers will be coming at their own expense, however with your precious help, we can reach beyond this goal and assist them with their expenses.

 

- WHAT YOU GET

  • I am deeply THANKFUL to all my supporters and followers; And to all the dreamers and those who help the others dream! I cannot say how grateful I would be if this project could come to life! It's about the Dance, the Culture and the Community! It's about opening new doors and dreaming bigger. It's about working passionately together on the same project, beyond nationality, background, or skin color. 
  • The perks are thought out and created to let you the contributor be a part of this special project! From private classes, limited show merchandise, special backstage footage, an exclusive "road to the show" mini-series so you can follow the growth of this project, and more! You can find all the perks on the right side of the screen. Any contribution big or small is extremely appreciated. Without you, this project won't be possible!

 

Other Ways You Can Help


Please help spread the word about Dare To Dancehall Show!  You can do this by telling your family, friends, colleagues about this project and sharing this Indiegogo fundraising campaign with them!  We appreciate every post, support in any kind, any gesture made on our behalf.  

 

 

Check out and share the website!  http://www.laurecourtellemont.com/

LIKE on Facebook! https://www.facebook.com/LaureCourtellemont/?fr...

FOLLOW us on Instagram!  http:/www.instagram.com/dare_to_dancehall_showla

FOLLOW on Instagram! http:/www.instagram.com/real_laurecourtellemont

Subscribe to the Youtube Channel!  http:/www.youtube.com/CourtellemontLaure

 

 

THANK YOU ALL SO MUCH FOR BEING A PART OF THIS PROJECT! It's going to be a great adventure! Dare To Dancehall will be a huge dream come true for not only me, but all the international dancers wanting to show the world how no matter where you're from, dance is what drives us; it is who we are. WE DARE TO DANCEHALL. Laure Courtellemont.
story_txt:
Hello, I'm Laure Courtellemont! Originally from France, I am an international choreographer currently residing in Los Angeles. I’ve dreamt of bringing my ideas and visions to life while inspiring others to do so by collaborating and spotlighting amazing dancers. I discovered Dancehall 20 years ago in France. Since then I’ve taken on this mission to bring this amazing dance and culture to the forefront by teaching and traveling professionally all over the world. I’ve trained and studied the history of Dancehall and its core with all my heart, love, and respect for over two decades. Today, I can say that I am the woman I am largely because of this expression!- MY GOALOne of my great dreams for this Jamaican originated art form is to give it an opportunity to be displayed on a live stage with some of the best dancers and actors of its kind. I want to showcase this passionate dance in all its glory in a way that any other well-respected dance should be shown. The Show will be held at Movement Lifestyle in North Hollywood, on June 17th,  2017. The Impact 1- PLATFORM OF EXPRESSIONI want to give Dancehall a strong platform to show its power and potential to the world. Showcasing an amazing dance expression and spotlighting great talents.2- DIVERSITYBorn and raised in France, I am strong in my identity as a European dancer and choreographer having been immersed in a multi-cultural environment. I want to apply this by bringing together dancers from different countries onto one stage to find the delicate balance between the foundation of this dance and its artistic potential. I want to help create the path for Dancehall to find its place from the street to the stage. The show will be filmed and also live streamed in multiple countries.3- A SHOW FOR UNITYThis show will bring worldwide personalities of this dance form on one stage to remind all of us the power of unity! Different minds, energies, and flavors from all around the world connecting around the same love for dance. This organic African descent expression is a powerful dance rooted in meaning and passion. This show will bring attention to the dance industry and all lovers of dance a huge understanding and appreciation for this often misunderstood art form.4- GIVING BACKI want to give back to Jamaica and its incredibly rich culture by crediting a full-length showcase of Dancehall with some of the best of this genre.A week before the show, on June 17th, the international dancers of the show will teach a one-day workshop and lecture about Dancehall and its Culture. All the proceeds from this workshop will be sent to children in need in Jamaica. 
What We Need & What You Get
- WHAT WE NEED
My funding goal is $27,500 to cover all costs of the show including rental space for 2 weeks of rehearsals, full day rental of the venue to hold 2 showings, production (including lighting, equipment, crew, security, staff, designer, producer, assistant, make up artist, hair stylist), filming and editing, live-streaming, etc.
Dancers from all over the world will come to North Hollywood for 2 weeks of intense training and rehearsals to create this platform to represent what we believe and live for. Their hard work and commitment will all be to prepare for this one night. Their passion will show the world the power of this art form, the power of making children's lives better, and the power of unity. These dancers will be coming at their own expense, however with your precious help, we can reach beyond this goal and assist them with their expenses.
 - WHAT YOU GET
I am deeply THANKFUL to all my supporters and followers; And to all the dreamers and those who help the others dream! I cannot say how grateful I would be if this project could come to life! It's about the Dance, the Culture and the Community! It's about opening new doors and dreaming bigger. It's about working passionately together on the same project, beyond nationality, background, or skin color. 
The perks are thought out and created to let you the contributor be a part of this special project! From private classes, limited show merchandise, special backstage footage, an exclusive "road to the show" mini-series so you can follow the growth of this project, and more! You can find all the perks on the right side of the screen. Any contribution big or small is extremely appreciated. Without you, this project won't be possible!
 Other Ways You Can HelpPlease help spread the word about Dare To Dancehall Show!  You can do this by telling your family, friends, colleagues about this project and sharing this Indiegogo fundraising campaign with them!  We appreciate every post, support in any kind, any gesture made on our behalf.    Check out and share the website!  http://www.laurecourtellemont.com/LIKE on Facebook! https://www.facebook.com/LaureCourtellemont/?fr...FOLLOW us on Instagram!  http:/www.instagram.com/dare_to_dancehall_showlaFOLLOW on Instagram! http:/www.instagram.com/real_laurecourtellemontSubscribe to the Youtube Channel!  http:/www.youtube.com/CourtellemontLaure  THANK YOU ALL SO MUCH FOR BEING A PART OF THIS PROJECT! It's going to be a great adventure! Dare To Dancehall will be a huge dream come true for not only me, but all the international dancers wanting to show the world how no matter where you're from, dance is what drives us; it is who we are. WE DARE TO DANCEHALL. Laure Courtellemont.

story:
Short Summary

Sharon and Kara met two years ago at a write-a-thon at Epiphany Space – a coworking office in Hollywood. We instantly hit it off, and have continued writing and brainstorming together ever since. The inspiration to work together on a play for Fringe came at a Christmas party last December, and next thing we knew, we were at one of the first Fringe Q&A events to learn exactly how to make this crazy idea happen!

About the show

Our show is an immersive comedy experience where the audience becomes part of the show. They'll move through three different rooms and see two different stories unfold, interact with the actors, complete tasks and laugh their way through the production that takes place in a real-life Hollywood co-working office.

The first play, written and directed by Kara Christensen is called “Rainbow Bright Power Naps.” It's a madcap comedy, where everything that can go wrong during a board meeting does.

The second play, written and directed by Sharon McKay is titled “John Stamos is My Baby Daddy.” It's the story of Audrey, who plans to make a big announcement when she throws a 4th of July party for her family and friends. But absolutely nothing about this party goes according to plan. This comedic play delves into the feminist ideal that women can have it all.

How your contributions will help

  • Putting on a play is more expensive than we expected, even at a fringe festival!
  • Your support will help cover costs such as fees and insurance, props, costumes, food for our talented cast and crew, marketing, and a donation to Epiphany Space - our wonderful venue that brought us all together.
  • Through your support, we will be able to provide our audiences with the highest quality experience, one that will leave smiles on everyone's faces - even yours!

What We Need

What our budget looks like:

  • Insurance for the actors and the audience members ($450)
  • Registration fee for Fringe ($250)
  • Costumes, props and consumables (office supplies, party supplies)
  • Meals for our cast and crew
  • Donation to the Non-Profit Epiphany Space for generously letting us use their facilities
  • Marketing: Flyers, Posters, and Postcards
  • Indiegogo Fees

What You Get

  • We have a bunch of fantastic rewards and perks available, such as advance tickets, VIP experiences, and special interactive behind the scenes sneak peeks! Check out the variety right here on the page. 

The Impact

Today, making art that comments on our society is more important than ever. This project brings together a group of Hollywood creatives to achieve this goal,

  • Two writers\directors
  • A group of talented actors
  • A fabulous stage manager
  • And the supportive and wonderful co-working office, Epiphany Space.

Risks & Challenges

Our biggest challenge for our project is that even if every performance sells out, the proceeds won't cover the cost of our production. 

This is because of the unique immersive experience, and the non-traditional venue where our show will be performed. To give our audiences the best possible experience, and due to space restrictions, we have a maximum capacity of 20 seats per performance. 

If we are unable to reach our goal, the funds we do raise will go towards the essential costs:

  • Fringe registration
  • Insurance
  • Donation to Venue

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to donate to our campaign, there are many other ways you can help! 

  • Share our campaign on your Facebook, Twitter, Instagam, Snapchat, blog. Use the buttons conveniently located next to that big pink "Back It" button at the top of the page!
  • Tell others about our show: http://www.hollywoodfringe.org/projects/4343
  • Like and share our Facebook page: http://www.facebook.com/AwkwardHugProductions/
  • If you're local:
    • Drop off food to feed our cast
    • Ask us about being a test audience member

Thank you so much for your help - you don't know how much it means to us. But you will. We promise!

story:
So here’s why we need your help:


We’ve leveraged favors and credit and put it on the line to make this happen.  With Your help, we can pay the artists and cover costs of transportation and materials.  Will You take that walk with us?

This is not the first and probably not the only crowdfunding plea You have received lately.  We can assure you though, that this is by far one of the most artistically ambitious and conceptually far out.  We’ve never backed down from the impossible, unbelievable, or spectacular, and if we can reach our goal, we will have put on an amazing show and provided Us All—audience and ritualist/performers—with one of the most unique and powerful performance experiences of our lives.


There are several thresholds of contribution.  The most basic contribution secures Your admission to the event.  You can select admission for one, two, or all three nights for Your contribution.


Contributing at a higher thresholds provides You with a candle or candles to use in a ritual installation at the performance or take home to continue the ritual in Your own space.  With Your contribution at other thresholds, we will create a custom candle for You and either light it at the appropriate altar at Samhain 2016 or it can be shipped to You so that You can illuminate Your own space with the connection and ritual energy of Samhain 2016.


Once we reach $3121 (minimum to cover production and travel, and yes that number is also tribute to the Prince album) in contributions we will unlock another special threshold of perks, which will provide a lasting memory for participants and ritualists near and far.


Here’s what You do:
1) Chose Your day(s) of attendance
2) Decide the number of candles You want to reserve for the ritual
3) Additional donations above the threshold will bring special gratitude and rewards at the ritual or through post if You are participating from a distance
4) If You cannot attend, choose Your ritual participation, and donate at the threshold to receive Your candle charged with Samhain 2016 energy and intention for Your own altar.
5) Click the donation button and make Your donation!

 

Budget Overview:

Travel for Artists:

  • Brandon Perdomo, NYC, USA—$200 for travel
  • Agnete Bjønbakken, Lillehammer, Norway—$800 for travel
  • Raquel Punto, Mexico City, Mexico—$600 for travel
  • Jelili Atiku, Lagos, Nigeria ( Jelili will not be flying in for the event, but will be performing by remote video installation.  This contribution is for his return in April 2017 in further performances.) —$1,200

Artist Payments:

  • 14 Artists x $200 each = $2,800

Production Costs:

  • Location costs, costs of supplies for event - $300

About the artist fees:
In previous years, we have not had a budget to be able to pay our artists for their time or materials.  This is the first year where we are pursuing the goal of paying each artist $200.  Sometimes, people only think of the artist’s work in terms of their actual performance time.  In this case, each artist has, during the course of the 3 days, 12 hours of performance time.  We ask You to also consider that each artist has 12-20 hours of get in time to set up their ritual/performances in the space.  In addition, each artist has spent a MINIMUM of 50 hours preparing themselves and their work for this event.  So essentially, we aim to pay each artist $100 for their outlay for materials for the event, and $100 for 64+ hours of work!

Can You dig it? 

Would You help Us reach this goal?

Thank You!!

story:
kaycruddenco is a new york city based dance company engaging audiences through pointing and looking. looking, pushing, falling and walking.

with a vision built on generating questions about the daily embodiment of the human experience, kaycruddenco embraces discomfort and duration. the work is interested in realizing the arbitrary nature of our mutual understanding and assumptions by connecting the audience with movements humans do every day, taking a simple nod of the head out of context provokes thoughts about the socially constructed way we move through life without second thought.

in 2017 we will be touring to atlanta and premiering a new evening length work. help us bring these ideas to life!

what we need: $5000 will help us to cover the cost of:

travel to atlanta, housing in atlanta, space for premiere of the new work, space to hold free body image movement workshops for women in conjunction with our newest work, and payment for dancers.

what you get:

besides the heartwarming feeling you will get after supporting the arts…

$5: thank you card from the company

$25: thank you card from the company and a homemade cookie!

$50: thank you card from the company and a dozen homemade cookies!

$100: thank you card from the company, a dozen homemade cookies and behind the scenes rehearsal footage!

$250: thank you card from the company, a dozen homemade cookies, behind the scenes rehearsal footage and 2 tickets to the premier of our new work!

$500: thank you card from the company, a dozen homemade cookies, behind the scenes rehearsal footage and 4 tickets to the premier of our new work!

can’t make a donation?

come see us perform, give a hug and stay tuned to come take a free workshop (:

story:
Jessica Kurtzman, 23, and Ryan Evans, 20, both Santa Barbara natives, have collectively been part of the theater and dance communities of Santa Barbara for over 20 years. They have grown from performers to producers, directors and choreographers in this time, and have had the mentorship of many adults they respect over the years. Now they are ready to take on the role of mentoring others.

Jessica has trained in dance in the Santa Barbara community since she was four years old. She began her training with Steven Lovelace, whom she now counts as one of her mentors and best friends of almost 20 years. Her involvement in theater stretches from Stage Left Productions to choreographing and performing in the Santa Barbara School of Performing Arts' productions of RENT (2014) and Swing! (2015). Jessica served as Steven's dance assistant at Stage Left and later became an Assistant Choreographer. She has since become an integral part of the Stage Left family. She studied dance at University of Washington and hopes to work in the entertainment business after college.

Ryan Evans has been involved with theater from a young age and hopes to pursue theater production as a career. He is currently a second year student at SBCC and will be transferring to Marymount Manhattan College to study Producing and Management in the fall. Ryan studied performance with the Dos Pueblos Theater Company, and Stage Left Productions, in addition to many other companies. He served as a co-producer at SB TIYA for Swapped 2016, and as assistant producer at Stage Left Productions in 2016. 

Jessica and Ryan have fostered  a great working relationship, in addition being close friends.

The Arts, in its multiple forms, has been an outlet and a safe haven for many young people. Jessica and Ryan would love to create the same environment for other young performers in our community. RENT, the show they have chosen, is the type of production that will change a performer's life.  This show means a lot to them and they would love to see it get off the ground and brought to life. 

One important aspect Ryan and Jessica are passionate about is for their performers to not have the financial burden associated with many theater companies. In many situations, performers and their families are tasked with having to pay a fee in order to be participants in a production. This is something Jessica and Ryan don't wish to require; they hope fundraising will allow those for whom this would be a financial burden to have this door open to them. Anyone who donates will help those with financial challenges and will provide a new opportunity for young performers. As well, to provide a fulfilling experience overall, there are aspects that do have a price which Ryan and Jessica will have to pay, such as rehearsal space, theater rental, show rights, a technical and musical director and much more. Ryan and Jessica wish to not only raise $18,500 to help fund the production of RENT, but they hope to fund future shows as well. Though the price appears daunting, if everyone donates a small amount it will add up and this goal can be achieved!

If financially contributing is not an option for you, all we ask is that you share our campaign with your friends and family in hopes of spreading the word and getting as many people to contribute as possible. Please post the link to our campaign on your Facebook, Instagram and/or Twitter (or any other social media platform you may use). Also, please email the link of our campaign to your friends and family! 

Any contribution will help and no amount is too little! We will take nothing for granted and truly appreciate all the support and love we get from everyone! Rehearsals are to begin mid-June through July. Our shows are set to be July 15th and 16th! Thank you so much, and see you at the theater!
