story:
A Little About Me:

  • I am a long time performer and dancer. At 26 years old, I have been dancing since the age of 10. Reluctant to express, I was not always the front runner, first draft pick or audition favorite. Therefore, I created a dance platform for normal people to be able to take classes without them being extremely difficult, yet still be exciting and fun!  Over the years I have studied Katherine Dunham technique,  performed with "The Joffrey Ballet" and taken various dance courses to perfect my craft.  This dance studio means the world to me! Not for personal reasons, but more so to have the opportunity to create a space for others to utilize.  When I first started I had "Zero" students for the first 6 months. You would think I would have quit right? Nope, I decided to keep having classes and eventually promoting them more professionally on social media.  Over the course of a year, I had over 2,000 clients.  I currently rent other venues and between the rent and not being stable this dance studio is mandatory for me at this point in my life. Every effort and donation helps!

What We Need & What You Get

  • The funding is being broken down onto several portions. Rehab, construction, cosmetics, licensing, studio needs and marketing. The rental space is at an all time low. The location is wonderful location and convenient near an expressway, so I want to put the time to fix this place up. Let's begin! The flooring needs to be done to become dance appropriate, as the flooring is now carpet and cement. The building needs an entire professional cleaning and extermination  The walls need to be stripped and re-painted. The property needs air to keep us in a comfortable climate during class, especially with all that sweat. All of the electrical units needs to be repaired and new lighting needs to be installed. The entire bathroom needs to be remodeled from the tile, to the sink, paint, mirror, decor and all! The dance studio is not a studio with sound systems and mirrors. Body length mirrors need to be professionally ordered and installed. I want to purchase new software to run the business properly and completely organized. The outside of the property needs an entire new reface. New doors need to be installed throughout the space and a new walls needs to be installed to separate the lobby from the studio.  Studio props are also needed (Mats, bars, and fitness tools and weights)  for safe profesional training. The lobby needs to be equipped to give guests a wonderful first walk in experience and security systems have to also be in place. The property needs work, plenty of other ins and outs with construction and cosmetics. Material alone has estimated 12,000 and labor cost have estimated about $6,000 . No donation is too small, Every donation counts! I will be funding a large portion of my own savings to the project as well. 
  • As for the business to properly run, funds for business license, trademarks, and company logos along with other legalities must be in place.
  • Perks for contributions are fantastic! Bags, T-shirts, Free classes and more! You will definitely be thanked for contributing to this project!

The Impact

  • Dance is an underrated stress reliever. So many people take the various classes I offer to relieve stress and simply put a smile on their face.
  • The adult classes I teach for women help them boost confidence, feel empowered,  lose weight, and become healthier mentally and physically. 
  • There are no similar studios in the area I am opening in and the neighborhood could use something positive like this nearby. Not only for the adults but the teens and kids as well.
  • I have been teaching classes for almost 4 years now and went from a 2,000 client base to 6, 000 clients and have now begun teaching all over the world.

Risks & Challenges

  • Challenges are always welcome to arise, that's life. However I have been in seminars, trainings and classes to better equip myself to handle the property. I have a team ready to be hired with excellent values and qualifications. This team will make this entire business run smoothly. 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can contribute other ways than contributing money!

Please share the link on social media, Tell a friend. Take a class, as all class profit is being saved to contribute to the business. Contact me via email : Kookiesdanceden@gmail.com with anything you can give, donate or do to help the studio out!
story_txt:
A Little About Me:
I am a long time performer and dancer. At 26 years old, I have been dancing since the age of 10. Reluctant to express, I was not always the front runner, first draft pick or audition favorite. Therefore, I created a dance platform for normal people to be able to take classes without them being extremely difficult, yet still be exciting and fun!  Over the years I have studied Katherine Dunham technique,  performed with "The Joffrey Ballet" and taken various dance courses to perfect my craft.  This dance studio means the world to me! Not for personal reasons, but more so to have the opportunity to create a space for others to utilize.  When I first started I had "Zero" students for the first 6 months. You would think I would have quit right? Nope, I decided to keep having classes and eventually promoting them more professionally on social media.  Over the course of a year, I had over 2,000 clients.  I currently rent other venues and between the rent and not being stable this dance studio is mandatory for me at this point in my life. Every effort and donation helps!

What We Need & What You Get

The funding is being broken down onto several portions. Rehab, construction, cosmetics, licensing, studio needs and marketing. The rental space is at an all time low. The location is wonderful location and convenient near an expressway, so I want to put the time to fix this place up. Let's begin! The flooring needs to be done to become dance appropriate, as the flooring is now carpet and cement. The building needs an entire professional cleaning and extermination  The walls need to be stripped and re-painted. The property needs air to keep us in a comfortable climate during class, especially with all that sweat. All of the electrical units needs to be repaired and new lighting needs to be installed. The entire bathroom needs to be remodeled from the tile, to the sink, paint, mirror, decor and all! The dance studio is not a studio with sound systems and mirrors. Body length mirrors need to be professionally ordered and installed. I want to purchase new software to run the business properly and completely organized. The outside of the property needs an entire new reface. New doors need to be installed throughout the space and a new walls needs to be installed to separate the lobby from the studio.  Studio props are also needed (Mats, bars, and fitness tools and weights)  for safe profesional training. The lobby needs to be equipped to give guests a wonderful first walk in experience and security systems have to also be in place. The property needs work, plenty of other ins and outs with construction and cosmetics. Material alone has estimated 12,000 and labor cost have estimated about $6,000 . No donation is too small, Every donation counts! I will be funding a large portion of my own savings to the project as well. 
As for the business to properly run, funds for business license, trademarks, and company logos along with other legalities must be in place.
Perks for contributions are fantastic! Bags, T-shirts, Free classes and more! You will definitely be thanked for contributing to this project!


The Impact

Dance is an underrated stress reliever. So many people take the various classes I offer to relieve stress and simply put a smile on their face.
The adult classes I teach for women help them boost confidence, feel empowered,  lose weight, and become healthier mentally and physically. 
There are no similar studios in the area I am opening in and the neighborhood could use something positive like this nearby. Not only for the adults but the teens and kids as well.
I have been teaching classes for almost 4 years now and went from a 2,000 client base to 6, 000 clients and have now begun teaching all over the world.


Risks & Challenges
Challenges are always welcome to arise, that's life. However I have been in seminars, trainings and classes to better equip myself to handle the property. I have a team ready to be hired with excellent values and qualifications. This team will make this entire business run smoothly. 

Other Ways You Can Help
You can contribute other ways than contributing money!
Please share the link on social media, Tell a friend. Take a class, as all class profit is being saved to contribute to the business. Contact me via email : Kookiesdanceden@gmail.com with anything you can give, donate or do to help the studio out!

story:
A Day in the Life of an Artist of Color

 

Why?

Recently I was a student at a performance program. During my time there I wrote a poem called "Drain Ourselves" about the tokenization, fetishization, and subsequent white washing I have felt as a performer in the Philadelphia theatre community. In my poem I wondered, if I have been praised as an artist due to my trauma and experience as a Person of Color, or due to the actual quality of my work. I performed this vulnerable poem during an open share and (to my surprise) my generally compassionate, mostly white classmates literally had no idea what I was talking about. They had never noticed these things happening to me or the power dynamics that affected me this way. I decided to reach out to my Philly friends to see if they had ever felt these hurdles in their art making. This project was born as a response to those forces that restrict our art, yet remain invisible to our white allies.

What?

A Day in the Life of an Artist of Color is an ongoing project that brings together Artists of Color in Philadelphia through the curation of both digital and physical spaces. It consists of three phases: a series of social media spotlights, social mixers, and collaborative photo series (Phase 1); a film project featuring materials from selected artists developed in the previous phase (Phase 2); and a live multimedia performance centered around the film (Phase 3).

Each part is purposefully designed to highlight Artists of Color in Philadelphia and showcase their work on their own terms. To create this project we are bringing together musicians, performers, dancers, craft-people, poets, filmmakers, and more to create a community that truly reflects the plurality of our experiences.

Part 1

The Spotlight Series

This phase focuses on Spotlighting local Philadelphia Artists of Color on Social Media. Each artist is given the poem "Drain Ourselves" as a prompt. Using the images and concepts described in the text- artists conceptualize their own photo shoot that shows their experience as an Artist of Color in the Philadelphia Artist community.

This also extends into our Artist Mixers which feature POC food/ art vendors, as well as other local businesses from all over Philadelphia. Our first Artist Mixer  took place on January 20th and had over 200 guests! In the weeks leading up to the event, each Vendor or Performer also received their own Artist Spotlight on Social Media. The vendors featured range from street performers who do their business at Rittenhouse or on Subway platforms, to recent High School grads, to local businesses and restaurants run by POC. All Artist Mixers are Pay-What-You-Can because we subscribe to the belief that anything that is inaccessible to the poor is neither Radical nor Revolutionary!

The Spotlight Series is an ongoing portion of the project. It will evolve and grow throughout 2018 to always be showcasing more Artists of Color in new ways.

Part 2

The Film

Using the poem "Drain Ourselves," the film depicts the journeys of Philadelphia artists, activists, and makers, as they navigate privilege and art world access here in Philly. Each artist will will team up with our cinematographer to create their own individual piece to visualize, respond to, or even question a section of the poem.  Our post-production team will then turn these mini movies, individually called "UnScenes" into one integrated film. This film will be free and accessible to all online.

Part 3

The Live Events

This phase is our version of a movie premier. It will wrap up the other two phases by featuring Artists/ Food Vendors/ Businesses of Color from all over Philadelphia.  The screening of the film will celebrate the work of the artists involved as well as all Artists of Colors. People of Color are so often silenced or policed in artistic spaces- this phase will celebrate and highlight the joy of People of Color, as well as create opportunities for Artists of Color to showcase their work and relate to the film.

The essential message of the project- from the way it will be made, to the writing of the film- is community building over perpetuating broken systems of oppression within liberal institutions, all the while celebrating the joy with which Artists of Color make and create their own histories.

How You Can Participate!

The biggest hurdle in our art-making is money and access.

This is where you come in.  We are committed to paying Artists of Color what they deserve for their work, but to tell this story we need your help! We are calling on you now to participate any way you can in this art-action.

Part 1 requires- space rentals, vendor table rentals, donated alcohol, props and costumes for curated Photo-series.

Part 2 requires- equipment rentals, on-location shooting space rental, costume costs, performer fees, lighting equipment, sound equipment, editing fees, and providing cooked meals and travel stipends to the artists on set.

Part 3 requires- venue space rentals, vendor table rentals, projection equipment for film

To accommodate Artists of Color of all kinds we are determined to create a process that meets artists where they are. Therefore, food on set and travel stipends are always calculated in order to ensure this process is accessible to all artists who participate in this project.

These are just a few of the things your support will be directly funding.  Any small amount you are able to contribute will go towards Artists of Color in our community!

Be an ally however you can! Donate and spread the word!

Support Artists of Color!

story:
The company

Wayne Parsons Dance creates work that sits on the border between dance and theatre with an aim to utilise the best of both text and movement in a truly distinctive approach to storytelling.

With direction and choreography by Wayne Parsons and new writing by Ankur Bahl a complex relationship between virtuosic movement and a compelling script has become the trademark of the company. 

"a choreographer with a distinctive narrative voice" ★★★★ The Guardian

 

 
 

The 2018 tour

Meeting and Vestige are to tour for the first time ever! 

Trestle Arts Base in St Albans: 1 November Book here

AMATA in Falmouth: 3 November Book here

The Gulbenkian in Kent: 5 November  Book here

Weston Studio in Bath Spa: 24 November Book here

A huge part of the tour is focused on education and training, with an extensive workshop programme planned, which needs your support to be realised! 

 

The programme 

Meeting and Vestige is the double bill we are touring, and both works have enjoyed great successes. Vestige was the first time the company collaborated with writer Ankur Bahl and dramaturg Pooja Ghai. There is also new composition from Angus MacRae set and costume design by Nicolai Hart-Hansen and Hannah Kidd. 

It's a world-class cast including Sonya Cullingford (Protein, Punchdrunk), Ian Garside (DV8, Punchdrunk), Grace Jabbari (Russell Maliphant, Mark Bruce) and Katie Lusby (Gecko, Punchdrunk).

" I can see very quickly why it’s riveting" DanceTabs

 

What We Need to succeed

We have raised 90% of the total budget for this tour and are now looking to raise the last 10%. Your contributions will go towards the cost of hiring technical equipment needed for the show, travel, rehearsals and promotional material to ensure everyone knows we are coming!

Click on the perks to find out more. 

 
"A maturity of conception with an ease of style" Writing About Dance.
 

Why Crowdfund?

As an emerging company, there was a limit on how much we could apply for from the Arts Council England. The deficit needs to be raised by the company. These means that philanthropy is our way of ensuring we can deliver our work. We hope you agree from watching the video--the work is important and worth your investment!

 

Share, Share, Share

If you have connected with the work, its themes and ideas, or know someone involved in the project then please do share with your friends and family. Please help us get the word out there by sharing this Crowdfunding campaign.

story:
“Some call me ‘witch’, and being ignorant of myself they go about to teach me how to be one.”
-Elizabeth Sawyer, The Witch of Edmonton

 

This Halloween the  Rude Grooms are bringing a thrilling & fiercely contemporary rendition of the tragicomedy The Witch of Edmonton. Inspired by the true story of Elizabeth Sawyer, a woman accused of witchcraft during the reign of James I, this production is a ghoulish whirlwind night complete with games, drinks, and dark magic.

 

None of it would be possible without our fantastic company and we want to make sure they get the support they deserve for their out of this world talent. Your support means we can pay each and every person who puts their talents into this truly magical night.

Please Note:

  • Donations on IndieGoGo are not tax-deductible. You may make a tax-deductible donation on Fractured Atlas: Rude Grooms is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Rude Grooms must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.​
  • When making a donation, make sure to enter a whole number without a decimal point (i.e., 35 rather than 35.00) -- contributors have reported issues with decimal points when backing the project. If you have any questions or issues, please reach out to us directly and we'll figure it out.
 

What We Need & What You Get

As an experiment in translating the Elizabethan theatre troupe model intro 21st Century Startup vernacular, our Patrons are of especially significant importance to us. With as small a donation as $25, you'll get priority access to all of our events -- including events not available to the general public (like our Secret Shakespeare Hunt, which guests have called "by far THE COOLEST THING I'VE EVER DONE IN New York City").

Because this is a limited-event and we are committed to keeping our "Groundling" admission accessible at $10, even sold out performances can't fully cover our costs -- by supporting us, you'll be a fundamental part of bringing these performances to Queens at prices residents can actually afford.

Here is exactly where your $500 will go:

$400 - Artist Stipends - four associate artists have offered to donate their stipends back to the company, this is the minimum cost to cover the gap between projected sales and the total cost of stipends for our other artists.

$100 - Publicity and Marketing - minimal advertising online to help make this as accessible to the local audiences in Astoria and Long Island City as possible.

In addition to joining our extended family, the following contributions will get you unique perks:

$1 - Upstart Crow - a personalized Halloween Meme in thanks for your contribution.

$25 - Patron - all of the above, plus exclusive access to our Private Series through July 2019.

$65 ($85 value) - Weird Sisters - all of the above plus two VIP seats and a personal Tarot Card reading at the performance of your choice. Seats are subject to availability -- 10/31 seating is EXTREMELY limited -- only two available

$175 ($235 value) - Muse of Blood & Fire - all of the above plus a custom Halloween sonnet delivered to you at the performance of your choice, stamped with a bloody handprint from that evening's performance and signed by the ensemble -- only two available

$300 (only available on IndieGoGo) - Tiger's Heart - all of the Muse of Blood & Fire perks, plus an invitation to observe a rehearsal (in person or via private video-conference) -- only two available

$500 (only available on IndieGoGo) - Lord Chamberlain - all of the above plus Banquo’s feast cooked for you and up to four friends by our Associate Producer -- only one available

$2,000 ($3,000 value) - Scream Queens - all of the above plus a private performance of The Witch of Edmonton at your home or the venue of your choice (transportation not included; the cast for your private performance is subject to change, pending actor availability) -- only one available

Even if we don't meet our goal, this production is coming on all hallows eve. Your contribution however means that our company can truly put their energy into their creative work.

 

More Ways to Help

Seriously, the smallest contribution will have a major impact on this production, and through it, the communities that it touches. But there are many more ways you can help:

Share this campaign all over your social networks. Connect us with people in your circle who have the desire and ability to help launch unique arts organizations.

Come and see us, and bring your friends! The best way for us to build word of mouth and find new patrons and sponsors is with bodies on the grass.

Lend us your talents! Rude Grooms is a truly collaborative experience so if you have time we’d love to have you.

 

Stretch Goals

If, beyond our wildest dreams, we not only meet but exceed our initial goal, here is our plan for how additional funds will bolster the production.

$600-$1,600 - Artist Stipends & production elements - every dollar about $600 will be evenly split between adding "stretch" production elements to enhance the audience's experience and increasing artist stipends.

$1,600-$2,000 - Additional PR and Marketing - more targeted online advertising, printing posters to put up near performance venues, etc.

$2,000+ - Hiring Additional Staff - bringing on additional front of house staff and assistants to support the production

story:
About The Great Brown Bear

Hi there! My name is Kierna Conner, and I'm an actress and creative living in the Big Apple. I graduated from the University of Arizona in 2016 with my BFA in Musical Theatre, and I have experience with project management, event planning, and entrepreneurship.

I've spent the past year writing, conceptualizing and workshopping a new work I've written called The Great Brown Bear. It's an immersive, surrealist adaptation of a classic Nordic folktale I loved as a child called 'East o' the Sun, West o' the Moon'. The Great Brown Bear uses the folktale as a lens to frame the journey of two lovers as they navigate what it means to relate to each other in a truthful way. This show is deeply personal to me because it's based on some of the most important romantic relationships in my life- my own, and more importantly, the one modeled to me by my parents. The show uses many important elements of my childhood and my family's culture to support our story, such as elements of my family's Finnish and Nordic heritage, poetry, and movement in honor of my late mother who was a dancer. 

In May of 2018, I submitted the show to the competitive New York International Fringe Festival, and it was accepted! We've been given a week long run from October 12th-16th, 2018, but we need your help to make it happen!

What We Need & What You Get

In order to make The Great Brown Bear's inaugural run a reality, we're asking for $3,500 of financial help from you, our community. Putting on a theatrical production is expensive, and we're looking for financial support in order to allow this show to find the foothold it needs in the competitive New York theatre world. The $3,500.00 will cover: 

  • the $1,000.00 venue and technical fee charged to us by FringeNYC
  • $600.00 of advertising in the Fringe program guide, contained in TimeOut Magazine! 
  • $400.00 for costume and set materials (I'll be doing the costume and set labor myself!) 
  • a financial stipend to try to convey to each of our 9 cast members and our beloved choreographer, Josh Dunn, how much we appreciate their hard work and skill!

Those who help support us in our very first efforts to bring The Great Brown Bear to life get some SUPER cool perks! Contributors can receive things like signed photos and posters, cast recordings of our original music, one-of-a-kind props from the show, and more! 

Any financial support we receive will help us fund The Great Brown Bear. Whether we don't quite make our financial goal, or we soar over and above it, the funds will go straight towards making it the best that it can be! Any additional funds we receive over the original goal will go directly towards additional compensation for our team (who are each doing EXCEPTIONAL work for far less than they are worth!) and supporting the larger goal of finding a more permanent home for The Great Brown Bear.

The Impact

The world of independent theatre is competitive, and it's easy to feel discouraged from creating original work when there are so many obstacles to overcome. But we believe the world needs to hear more new stories- and that the world needs to hear this story! Our story is a story of hope, of vulnerability, and of what it means to live in the present moment, in all of it's uncertainty and risk. We believe our story will connect people, and infuse them with the same hope and courage that we have! 

We are a team of creatives and leaders who have combined experience running successful small businesses, planning large scale events, and originating new works in festivals all over the world. We feel confident that this production of The Great Brown Bear will open the door to larger opportunities for the show and for us as creatives and professionals.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to contribute financially, you can also support our campaign by getting the word out! By sharing our campaign on social media and via email and word of mouth, you can help ensure that our goals will be met and our intention to bring hope and connection to NY audiences will become a reality! Share us on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, and via the IndieGoGo share tool! 

THANK YOU for taking time out of your day to read- we're glad you're with us and we hope you'll come and see the show! 

Website: www.thegreatbrownbear.com

Fringe Website Listing: http://www.fringenyc.org/basic_page.php?ltr=G

Tickets: https://www.eventbrite.com/d/ny--new-york/the-g...

Promo Video created by Casey Martin Klein, Insta: @caseymartinnyc, www.caseymartinklein.com/

story:
A History of Tier5

In 2015, Tier5 began its life a collective of graduate students from East 15 Acting School's MFA Acting (International) program in London. Their first project, Ladies in Waiting: The Judgement of Henry VIII, a dark comedy/drama that allowed Henry VIII's wives to finally tell him how much he actually sucked.

Thanks to crowdfunding success, Ladies in Waiting went on to have a sold out, critically acclaimed runs at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, Los Angeles, and Washington D.C. with Tier5 as well as in house licensed productions in Louisiana and London (also sell out successes!). Earlier this year is made it's US regional theatre debut with Southwest Shakespeare Company, enjoying another sold out run and currently being nominated for nine Broadway World Phoenix Awards. 

Taking the well-worn tropes and known facts of history and literature and revisiting them through a feminist light clicked and Tier5 found its voice. With one successful show under our belt, it was time to create a follow-up

 

Devising Little Women

After discovering a mutual love for Louisa May Alcott's Little Women, the Tier5 team began crafting a new version of the novel in late 2017. For a year the devising ensemble worked through improvs, research, scene work, and dance to create the show from the ground up. Part biography, part adaptation, and part examination of literature's credibility through a modern lens, meg jo beth amy & louisa was born. 

Assigned with the super boring task of writing a novel for young girls, Louisa May Alcott finds herself in a state of writer’s block. That is until she turns to figures and stories from her own life. The lines between fact and fiction begin to blur, as her novel, Little Women, is played out upon the stage, and Louisa’s self-examination of her own sexuality as well as unfinished family drama weaves itself through the story in quirky, weird, queer, and sentimental ways. Louisa must confront her own art as she, her characters, and the audience are all pulled towards an emotional conclusion.

meg jo beth amy & louisa premiered in a workshop production with Dixon Place in New York City, on November 1, 2018 to a full house and enthusiastic reception. 

 

So... what's next?

In the wake of our successful workshop, meg jo beth amy & louisa was offered a residency with the Center at West Park in April 2019 in NYC. Hoping to follow in the footsteps of Ladies in Waiting, after the residency we are planning to tour the production through the Fringe circuit. That's where you come in...

Mounting a theatrical production can be daunting and expensive. Which is why we are reaching out to the community to assist! Here's what we're looking to raise:

 

Rehearsal Space: $3,000 

Publicity Materials: $1,000

Set/Costumes/Props: $1,000

Insurance: $500

Actor/Technician Fees: $4,000

  • It's important that we compensate our ensemble for the work they have done. 

Entrance Fees: $1,500

  • Many of our Fringe festivals require the artists to pay an entrance fee. This amount will help us cover costs for the Orlando, Hollywood, and Capital Fringe (D.C.) Festivals

Transportation: $3,000

  • Transporting our actors through the country to multiple locations! 

Additional fees: $1,000

  • Any remaining amount with help to cover loose ends and IndieGogo fees.

 

Castles in the Air

Throughout Little Women, the March sisters discuss their "Castles in the Air," or dreams they'd long to come true. Presenting new theatre that breaks through typical tropes, revisits classic stories in new feminist lights, and provided opportunities for artists to explore their art in new and exciting ways is Tier5's castle in the air. With your help this holiday season, we can do just that.

Little Women is a novel about family: the love of fours sisters. In the current world climate, it's important for us to present this show about love. Now, don't go thinking this is some saccharine adaption, because this is NOT your Marmee's Little Women. A love letter to the Louisa and the original novel that also challenges it, meg jo beth amy and louisa is for the long time fans of the novel and those meeting the March sisters for the first time. It's for you. 

 

Other Ways You Can Assist

  • Buy a ticket for the show! Tickets will go on sale soon for our residency at The Center at West Park in New York City in April. Keep your eyes peeled for that! Also, as we confirm out attendance at the Fringe Festivals, we'll let you know when tickets go on sale for those!
  • Follow us on facebook (facebook.com/megjobethamyandlouisa)
  • Follow us on Twitter (@megjobethamylou)
  • Spread the word! Share our posts and IndieGogo page!

With your help this holiday season, we can astonish the world!

story:
Synopsis

Hannah wakes up terrified in the middle of the night. She just had another bad dream, but this time her big sister Allie won’t allow them to keep happening. She takes Hannah to a place where she’s never been, at least not while awake - the Dream World. Here where everything is possible, Hannah meets the monsters, giant bugs, and clowns that have been tormenting her. Allie plays with the infinite possibilities to teach her sister how to demystify nightmares using magic and goofiness. But when Allie is faced with terrors of her own, the journey almost comes to an end. She’ll have to deal with the shadows of her fears and the voices of her own judgements. Dream and reality collide, and perception becomes her greatest weapon. Beyond Dreams is a play about family, awareness and courage. 

Why this show?

No one is a stranger to the sensation of waking up in the middle of the night shaking, sweating and too scared to even turn on the lights. That feeling is even worse when you are unaware that you can protect yourself. I don't think we are helpless as children, we're just unaware of our capacities. 

However, dreams are simply fabrications of our imaginary and our imaginary is just the result of what we see, hear, smell on a daily basis. So they happen due to external input. What if we can change that input or lead it in another direction?  And what if we can do that in life too? We can, because we do it all the time. We receive, interpret and register everything that happens unconsciously and we often hurt ourselves with our interpretations. So let's become aware of this process and choose how to interpret. In "Beyond Dreams" through games, fantasy and make believe we explore how we can own our fears no matter if we're 6 years old or 40. By the way, this isn't just about nightmares we have when we're asleep, but those we face when we're awake as well.

If you relate to anything that has been said so far, then you know why we're doing this and why we're asking you for your help. We believe that there are stories that need to be told, there are theatre shows that stay with us forever. That's how powerful art is and that's why it deserves support, because it can change anything as long as we let it.

Who We Are

Mafalda Pinto Correia is a New York city based actress, whose journey started in Portugal. She graduated from Academia Contemporânea do Espectáculo and had her debut in the National Theater with "Fome Longe". She went on to act in several shows like "Oedipus Rex", "Dead Souls", "A Family is a Family" and tour in Portugal, Spain, Italy and France. As a performer/director she created several plays for younger audiences such as "The Lusiads", "Beasts", "The Ship of Hell". Always carrying the wish of deepening her craft she moved to New York to expand her horizons at The Lee Strasberg Theatre and Film Institute. Recently she stared in Midnight Espresso and Telescope, the later presented at the Strasberg Film Festival. As it's probably clear by the theme of the play, family plays a huge role in her life. If she's not on stage or on set, she's baking, dancing or swimming in the nearest ocean. She would like to thank her family and friends for existing and for their readiness to help (even when she's being extremely picky). 

Jordyn Moone is an actor from Ohio. She is delighted to perform in this charming and beautiful show! She is a graduate of the Lee Strasberg Theatre & Film Institute and is a scholarship student at the Upright Citizens Brigade, NYC. She holds a Bachelor of Science in Business Administration from Boston University, and is a former Captain of the US Army, among many other things, including being human and stuff. She has been seen in productions of Unity (1918), Wanda’s Visit, and Into the Woods among others. She would like to warmly thank Mafalda, “the Hulk”, for creating a great show, and her loving family & friends for their continued support.

Where Your Contributions Go To

Producing a show in New York is as insane and costly as it sounds and we're doing 10 performance days. So here's the budget breakdown:

Space (Rehearsal+Performance): $5000

Sets, Props, Costumes: $300

Marketing: $800

Light/Sound: $600

House Staff: $500

Insurance: $500

______________________________________________________

Total= $7700

None of the money raised here is intended for the creative team. I know what you're thinking, creators always get the short end of the stick. However that's where marketing and social media sharing comes in! Because if we sell out the show we will be able to pay the artists!

Even if we don't reach our goal this show is happening. Candlelight is always an option and jeans and a t-shirt are a valid costume nowadays. Jokes aside, we are investing as much as we can in this and your help means we can go further, and improve the visual quality of the show, and sleep at night (I know I said jokes aside but...). 

Your Impact

Now you know what we're doing, a family show in the Holiday season. Now you know why we're doing it, because our fears don't have to torment us forever. You even know how we'll do it, two actresses, a stage in Manhattan and a lot of creativity and support from friends. So what else do you need? To know what your participation brings to the table.

This is what you will help create and what your help will make possible:

  • Use sales revenue to actually pay our workers, from the person that made the poster to the person who will be on stage performing.
  • Bring ticket's prices down! If we achieve our goal ticket's price will drop to half.
  • Reach more people. With more people spreading the word and funds to invest in marketing we can make sure everyone in New York knows "Beyond Dreams" is happening.
  • And last but not least: Keep the dream alive. We are artists because we believe in art and its contribution to our society. We won't stop creating, exploring, questioning unless it becomes physically impossible. And even then, we'll only accept defeat after every stone has been turned. I'm sure one of those stones is hiding the solution. Maybe that solution is you.

We will shout "Thank You" from the highest mountain when you join our team! By the way, because we are in New York the highest mountain is the Empire State Building.

If you still have any questions please feel free to ask! There's a button on the top that says "Ask a question", use it. We'll be happy to answer any doubt.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate but you still believe in our project there're definitely other ways you can help:

  • Get the word out and share this campaign on every social media page you own! You'll see several share tools on the top of the page.
  • Come and see the show!

Thank you so much, having you be a part of this means a great deal.

story:
SOBRE LA OBRA

 

Soy mujer. Tengo más de treinta años. Soy profesional, autónoma, me considero una persona funcional. Pero hay una duda que me ronda desde hace un tiempo, y a medida que el reloj avanza, se va volviendo, de alguna forma, más urgente:

 

¿QUIERO TENER HIJOS?

 

A veces pienso que sí, que es una experiencia que deseo tener. Otras veces, me parece que quizás no: solo me han enseñado a creer que debo tenerla.

 

Todo esto lo he conversado una y otra vez con mi psicóloga. Pienso en si estaré preparada, en si necesito tener una pareja, en qué tan capaz soy de hacerme responsable de otro ser humano… Y así, con todos estos cuestionamientos en mente, voy dando tropiezos en la vida, pero también grandes pasos.

 

[Jimena, 32]

 

Lo que llevas dentro es un thriller sobre la maternidad y la psicología. Una historia sobre lo frágiles que podemos ser los seres humanos y todo lo que somos capaces de hacer cuando nuestros más profundos anhelos y esperanzas son puestas en juego.
 

¿CÓMO PUEDES APOYAR?

 

Esta campaña busca recaudar tres mil dólares (US$ 3000) para cubrir los gastos de diseño de arte, escenografía, vestuario y dar un justo reconocimiento a todos los profesionales involucrados en este maravilloso proceso teatral.

 

Como no queremos solamente pedir donaciones, hemos pensado en entregar algunas recompensas a nuestros gentiles patrocinadores. El monto que puedes donar va de los US$ 5 (cinco dólares) al infinito y más allá. Puedes transferir desde cualquier entidad bancaria en cualquier país. ¡Anímate a colaborar!  

 

Tu apoyo en este proyecto será sustentado ante Sunat (entidad que fiscaliza los tributos en Perú). Lo que llevas dentro es producida por VIVE Producciones, empresa que se encargará de registrar los ingresos y egresos.

 

Ficha artística

 

Dramaturgia y dirección: Jimena Salas Pomarino
Asistencia de dirección: Giacomo Roncagliolo Bermúdez
Sonido y música: Silvio Lafont e Irazema Vera
Producción general: VIVE Producciones
Producción ejecutiva: Adriana del Águila Panduro
Elenco: Giselle Collao, Yolanda Rojas y Renato Gianoli
Diseño gráfico: Elmer Yarmas
Fotografía: Joselyn D’Angelo
Videoarte: Nicolás Ortega
story_txt:
SOBRE LA OBRA Soy mujer. Tengo más de treinta años. Soy profesional, autónoma, me considero una persona funcional. Pero hay una duda que me ronda desde hace un tiempo, y a medida que el reloj avanza, se va volviendo, de alguna forma, más urgente: ¿QUIERO TENER HIJOS? A veces pienso que sí, que es una experiencia que deseo tener. Otras veces, me parece que quizás no: solo me han enseñado a creer que debo tenerla. Todo esto lo he conversado una y otra vez con mi psicóloga. Pienso en si estaré preparada, en si necesito tener una pareja, en qué tan capaz soy de hacerme responsable de otro ser humano… Y así, con todos estos cuestionamientos en mente, voy dando tropiezos en la vida, pero también grandes pasos. [Jimena, 32] Lo que llevas dentro es un thriller sobre la maternidad y la psicología. Una historia sobre lo frágiles que podemos ser los seres humanos y todo lo que somos capaces de hacer cuando nuestros más profundos anhelos y esperanzas son puestas en juego. 
¿CÓMO PUEDES APOYAR?
 
Esta campaña busca recaudar tres mil dólares (US$ 3000) para cubrir los gastos de diseño de arte, escenografía, vestuario y dar un justo reconocimiento a todos los profesionales involucrados en este maravilloso proceso teatral.
 
Como no queremos solamente pedir donaciones, hemos pensado en entregar algunas recompensas a nuestros gentiles patrocinadores. El monto que puedes donar va de los US$ 5 (cinco dólares) al infinito y más allá. Puedes transferir desde cualquier entidad bancaria en cualquier país. ¡Anímate a colaborar!  
 
Tu apoyo en este proyecto será sustentado ante Sunat (entidad que fiscaliza los tributos en Perú). Lo que llevas dentro es producida por VIVE Producciones, empresa que se encargará de registrar los ingresos y egresos.

story:
Short Summary

Extremities” is an incredibly gripping drama that portrays the act of rape and its aftermath as the victim turns the tables on her attacker, reaching a climax of fever pitch suspense.

Marjorie, is attacked in her home by a would-be rapist, Raul, and manages to turn the tables on him, tying him up in her fireplace. Her roommates come home to discover the attacker bound with cords.

Terry and Patricia, the roommates, express different points of view about rape in society. Terry, a rape victim herself as a teenager, believes that Raul will not be convicted because a rape did not actually occur and there is no proof. Patricia believes in the judicial system and insists on calling the police. The three friends are also turned on each other at various points in the play

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need your financial help for getting this up on stage! Producing theater is a beautiful amazing thing, but it’s also an expensive one. All our funds will go specifically to get the rights, set design, props, marketing and publicity
  • We put together a highly skilled and experienced cast and crew who will work crazy amount of hours to get this powerful story on stage.
  • Not only will you help bring a powerful play to the light but you will get some wonderful perks in the meantime! Look to your right and you will see all the goodies that come in exchange for your support and generosity.
  • Help us reach our goal!!!! J

The Impact

  • Even thou this play was written in the 80’s, it couldn’t be more timely. At a moment where women are speaking up loudly about sexual assault, it’s causing a big shift and different types of debates and conversations are happening around the world. This play offers different points of view, and takes the audience on a wild ride of what if’s.

It is very important time for female producers and directors to have a voice, show their talents and strengths, and share our stories.

This play will be performed from February 1st – March 23rd at the amazing theater 68 in North Hollywood! And will be doing a total of 16 performances. We can’t wait for you to see this amazing powerful play!

story:
Last summer, two Masques alumni approached Mike Perrotta (the late advisor of the Fair Lawn High School Masques drama club) about putting on a "Masques alumni-only" show. It would be a way to help fundraise for the current Masques, get former drama geeks back into the theatre, and to have an opportunity to work closely with our beloved mentor again. Perrotta was excited by the idea and flattered by the growing alumni interest in the project. Over the months that followed, a dialogue opened up between those alumni and a larger group in which ideas for shows and process were thrown around. When the ideas were brought back to Perrotta in the fall, a soft decision was made to start rehearsals on a series of one-act plays the following summer. This decision came only weeks before Perrotta's passing. In his absence, we carry on.

This alumni show will now be a tribute show (and, ideally, an annual performance) that will help fund the Michael Perrotta Scholarship for the Arts, which was recently established by the Fair Lawn School District. 

Gainesville is a darker drama centered around three sisters that are learning how to deal with life after the death of their father. This play was one that Perrotta never stopped working on; each incarnation with the Masques was just a little different and with that, we hope to honor Perrotta’s memory and thank him for the time we were all able to spend working with him.

story:
CAST

APOLLO RIEGO - MAGICIAN
PEARLS DAILY - BURLESQUE ARTIST
MANI VAFAEI - MUSICIAN/COMPOSER

DIRECTOR - JOE BARROS

Joe Barros is best known for his work on Broadway such as Cagney, Little Shop of Horrors and Gigi along with many others. Having him on the team will certainly make this show well directed.

We want to bring the real New York City to the stage!  See what it's like for a struggling street performer, dreaming to make it big in one of the toughest cities in the world. This show is a unique experience that combines the art of live magic with film along with street dance, burlesque and live music with an original soundtrack. Our story follows Apollo...a MAGICIAN to be, who doesn't know it yet. He's a man down on his luck who's just looking for his big break. Until one night, when he sneaks into the subway and fate decides to step in. Will he figure out what to do with his life or will he fall flat on his face. Join the struggle, the love and the dream. Watch live as his magic show proves, that all it takes, to live the dream, is the courage to rise above. APOLLO RISING!

WHERE IS IT GOING?

Your pledges will help make our dream become a reality. We're seeking to raise $15,000 to help with production costs such as building stage illusions, custom sets, projector + screen, costuming and refillable prop supplies. 

Illusions will make our show bigger and better! Purchasing illusions "off the rack" gets quite expensive and uncustomizable, so, we have an illusion builder that will allow us to put our unique stamp on these big stage illusions.

Custom Sets - Even our backdrop screams NEW YORK CITY! We're bringing everything from grafitti art by JB Magday to Broadway marquees. This will immerse the audience right into show.

Now for the good stuff! We've prepared some incredible perks for you! It varies from exclusive performance/rehearsal/blooper footage of Apollo Rising, the original soundtrack, one on one magic lessons, tickets to the show and even a private performance of Apollo Rising at your next event! Take a look and see which one suits you!

Just in case we don't reach the entire goal, we will make do with what we have and still bring you the best show possible. Of course, the show would not reach its full potential if we don't hit the mark so, with your help, we're hoping for the best in hitting our target amount to make this show as spectacular as possible.

Please spread the word about this campaign on social media, text and even snail mail! We're certain with your help, this will get us to reach our goal and beyond! Thank you so much and we're looking forward to doing this project with you!

story:
Short Summary

I'm Brandon Sharkey.  I'm a playwright and actor and I'm working to bring LeRoy "Phat Trane" Johnson's story to the stage for the 2018 Hollywood Fringe Festival  (June 7th-24th, 2018) and I need your help.

Singer/Songwriter LeRoy Johnson was born at Charity Hospital in the city of New Orleans, sometime in the late 1950’s or early 1960’s (we think). In 2005 Hurricane Katrina flooded the hospital, and it’s record room, causing many old files to go unrecovered and the hospital to remain closed to this day.
What happened to young LeRoy Johnson since those early days in New Orleans has always been a mystery. Until now.  Now, freshly out of prison (after 20+ years), with no shortage of rumor and gossip, this mystical musician, who has influenced fans worldwide, is looking for his story to be told to a few final audiences before he heads Home for good. 
From other musicians, to artists and politicians, LeRoy “Phat Trane” Johnson has managed to quietly nudge his way into American culture. Any support you can provide this show is incredibly appreciated. And please come hear some of the famous songs and the stories behind them in this new show we call…. Phat Trane: Found

------------

I first become aware of Phat Trane while I was vacationing in Spain with my wife.  There was a local Spaniard, our quasi-tour guide,  who wouldn't stop asking me about an American musician, a man he called “Fit Treen”.  He was astonished that I, being an American, hadn’t known more about Phat Trane.  Until finally, he brought me to “Cafe Populart,” a small bar in Madrid that was known for playing American music. As the drinks flowed and the music brought the room alive I was taught about the life of Phat Trane, at least the little that was known.   

Soon our tour guide was gone and our trip was over. With the real world waiting for us back in the United States, the life of Phat Trane Johnson became a hidden secret obscured by uncertainty.  

After doing some research I found out he was sentenced to prison in the 1990’s. I figured he probably died in confinement a few years ago.  So when I found out not only was he alive but that he had recently gotten out of prison, my journey to find him began with an urgency.  And when I found him, well, he was an inspiration for me.  And this show is a product of that inspiration. It is the result of late night storytelling and stack of VHS taped performances.  It's his songs, his stories, his life.  It is Phat Trane, found.

 

The Impact

The Hollywood Fringe Festival (June 7th-24th, 2018) is the perfect place to introduce this show and see if we can spread the word about Phat Trane and some of the wisdom he’s slyly be giving to the world while it was busy looking at its phone.  We’ve been lucky enough to receive donations and are able to cover a small percentage of our performance budget but we are reaching out to see if we can get some additional support to cover the remainder of our financial needs.

Risks & Challenges

Our basic expenses include venue costs, technical crew, marketing, and insurance requirements.  Every donation, even smaller dollars, helps us get closer to our goal and is sincerely appreciated.

We have flexible funding, which means that every dollar you give finds its way to us and helps us bring this show to the stage (June 7th-24th, 2018).  If we are lucky enough to get all our expenses covered additional monies will go to booking additional shows and possibly getting a recording of one or more of the live performances.  We can't stress how much every little bit helps.

There are perks for each level of financial giving but nothing can adequately repay the gift of support for the arts.  Your gift is truly a spark that can help ignite creativity and inspiration.  

The Hollywood Fringe Festival (June 7th-24th, 2018) is an annual, community-derived event celebrating freedom of expression and collaboration in the performing arts community. Each June during the Hollywood Fringe, the arts infiltrate the Hollywood neighborhood: fully equipped theaters, parks, clubs, churches, restaurants and other unexpected places host hundreds of productions by local, national, and international arts companies and independent performers.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help.  If you are unable to give a financial donation please show your support by sharing the good news about this show with family and friends.  Word of mouth can be invaluable and is also greatly appreciated.

story:
The LinoStory

For us, Linotip represents the time and space where we focus our attention on the multiple ways we can enhance the visibility of contemporary dance in the independent art sector.

How do we do that? 

Our artistic direction is mainly oriented towards contemporary dance show productions that are based on physical theatre and performance. Our main goals for the next years consists in

  • creating and offering to the public a contemporary dance repertory
  • creating a contemporary dance company
  • enhancing education through contemporary dance
  • developing and implementing transdisciplinary cultural programs
  • research and innovation involving contemporary dance and technology

 

Who's "Us"?We’re a small yet daring team and if you want to meet us or find out more about us you can contact us at contact@linotip.ro.

 

What we did so far?

We started in 2016, full of energy and positive thinking, with our heads bursting with all sorts of creative ideas and with a little help from our friends, looking back from 2018, we did around 100 individual events successfully.

That includes (creating 3 new shows, re-staging an older show, presenting them for the audience more than 50 times, creating a partnership with students to encourage development, engaging with the dance community through direct talks, creating one festival and partnering in 3 other, getting prizes for one of our shows, being invited to play our shows in different parts of the country and abroad, organising15 workshops, etc).

Why are we doing this campaign?

As we said, we care a lot about our audience as much as we care about our creations. And when you care about something, you do what it takes to make that thing work. 

For a year we had around 60 chairs borrowed from 2 independent theatres but at the beginning of January 2018 we had to return them. As you can see they looked comfortably good. So, we need to find something at least as good as this. 

For this, we decided to press pause for 2 months and not dance our shows in order to be able to focus our attention on what we need to do to create comfort and good visibility for our audience: new chairs and new platforms.  

We build a community around Linotip by constantly offering shows, classes and other events related to contemporary dance. And although this break is more than necessary it's very important to bring new chairs and platforms in this space as soon as possible, to be able to reconnect with the public. 

In other words, we want to move fast but not furious and accomplish this new change we need to do. Here's how the space is gonna look with new platforms and a bigger number of chairs. Thanks to a friend architect we have some sketches to show you. 

 

Why is this so important?

We want our space to be a model for others to come. To offer our best shows and activities in optimal conditions. We want our team, dancers, audience and partners to feel that this is a place where quality, passion and good energies are highly respected. The modern look of the space and the functions that this space has, draw more and more attention towards contemporary dance and it’s ability to grow again and maybe one day become as visible as theatre and cinema are these days in our country.

 

What We Need

Based on the research market that we’ve made, we found some good quality producers and we figured out that in order to create the most amazing “Comfort zone” for our audience we would be required to have 13500 dollars.

It might seem like a lot of money.  Maybe.  But, with this sum we get a lot of stuff: 

  • 80 Awesome chairs, delightfully comfortable
  • 12 Platforms to increase visibility
  • Steps to help reach the platforms
  • Handrails to ensure safety
  • Small led lights to make steps visible in the dark - safety again
  • Different sizes of legs for the platforms to set the hight difference between rows
  • More safety pins and systems to secure the platforms and the chairs together

All of the above are made of high quality materials tested for safety and are made according to European regulations.

 

What You Get

Partnering with us in this endeavour is becomes an opportunity to join our awesome community of people who enjoy and love contemporary dance and are aware of the positive impact that this type of art has in the social, cultural and educational systems. 

Beautiful perks

  • you’ll be present on our website and social media 
  • someone in the team will make a special thanks video for you (surprise)
  • you’ll get to participate in our contemporary dance workshops, 
  • come and see the shows we’re making, 
  • you can have a special seat in the audience, 
  • for your amazing support you can actually appear next to our partners on our posters this year. 

Check out the perks and claim the one suitable for you!

 

LinoImpact

 

Linotip started as an idea and after long years of waiting and planning and taking steps back, building experience in life, in art, in working with other people, the right moment came. And we took it.

It wasn’t easy. We had an empty work-in-progress space that needed to be transformed in what it is today. For about 8 months, while the space was transforming (painting the walls, electric wiring, wooden floor, dance floor, lighting, sound, cleaning), we were questioning ourselves about what we aim with this project and building a strong strategy and a set of goals to guide us.

The biggest impact that we can continue to have with this space is to give confidence to others. Confidence that it’s ok to dare, to break the norm, to take on some risks, to challenge yourself and the times you’re living in to make a difference. 

And we continue to work a lot to keep it running. We feel strongly that this is what we have to do, and so, no matter how hard it gets sometimes, we believe in this art so much and in the people’s power to influence and change the world we live in that it’s actually impossible for us to quit doing what we do. :)

 

LinoRisks & LinoChallenges

Because we work independently, so no funds from the government to sustain us, the risk we take with this campaign is that we’re not gonna be able to raise the entire sum. 

To overcome this we turned to the community we built around us (performers, dancers, choreographers, actors, people in the audience and people that come to our classes), we established connections with the press and radio stations to help us share the message about this campaign. 

If you got here and you can’t contribute financially, but you like what we do, share our campaign with your friends! Contemporary dance is a magic place that worths our time and resources. 

 

Other LinoWays You Can Help

Together we can do so much more and we invite you, if you like us and what we do,  to spread out the word with your friends and family, on Facebook, Instagram, Linked-in, Youtube, Twitter, Pinterest and wherever you think it’s worth spreading. 

Write an article, post it, re-post it, cross-post it, make a video of how important it is for you to have a space like Linotip available for shows, classes, film projections, talks and all sorts of other activities related to contemporary dance.
story_txt:
The LinoStory

For us, Linotip represents the time and space where we focus our attention on the multiple ways we can enhance the visibility of contemporary dance in the independent art sector.
How do we do that? 

Our artistic direction is mainly oriented towards contemporary dance show productions that are based on physical theatre and performance. Our main goals for the next years consists in

creating and offering to the public a contemporary dance repertory
creating a contemporary dance company
enhancing education through contemporary dance
developing and implementing transdisciplinary cultural programs
research and innovation involving contemporary dance and technology

 
Who's "Us"?We’re a small yet daring team and if you want to meet us or find out more about us you can contact us at contact@linotip.ro.
 
What we did so far?
We started in 2016, full of energy and positive thinking, with our heads bursting with all sorts of creative ideas and with a little help from our friends, looking back from 2018, we did around 100 individual events successfully.

That includes (creating 3 new shows, re-staging an older show, presenting them for the audience more than 50 times, creating a partnership with students to encourage development, engaging with the dance community through direct talks, creating one festival and partnering in 3 other, getting prizes for one of our shows, being invited to play our shows in different parts of the country and abroad, organising15 workshops, etc).

Why are we doing this campaign?
As we said, we care a lot about our audience as much as we care about our creations. And when you care about something, you do what it takes to make that thing work. 
For a year we had around 60 chairs borrowed from 2 independent theatres but at the beginning of January 2018 we had to return them. As you can see they looked comfortably good. So, we need to find something at least as good as this. 

For this, we decided to press pause for 2 months and not dance our shows in order to be able to focus our attention on what we need to do to create comfort and good visibility for our audience: new chairs and new platforms.  
We build a community around Linotip by constantly offering shows, classes and other events related to contemporary dance. And although this break is more than necessary it's very important to bring new chairs and platforms in this space as soon as possible, to be able to reconnect with the public. 
In other words, we want to move fast but not furious and accomplish this new change we need to do. Here's how the space is gonna look with new platforms and a bigger number of chairs. Thanks to a friend architect we have some sketches to show you. 

 
Why is this so important? 
We want our space to be a model for others to come. To offer our best shows and activities in optimal conditions. We want our team, dancers, audience and partners to feel that this is a place where quality, passion and good energies are highly respected. The modern look of the space and the functions that this space has, draw more and more attention towards contemporary dance and it’s ability to grow again and maybe one day become as visible as theatre and cinema are these days in our country.
 

What We Need
Based on the research market that we’ve made, we found some good quality producers and we figured out that in order to create the most amazing “Comfort zone” for our audience we would be required to have 13500 dollars.
It might seem like a lot of money.  Maybe.  But, with this sum we get a lot of stuff: 

80 Awesome chairs, delightfully comfortable
12 Platforms to increase visibility
Steps to help reach the platforms
Handrails to ensure safety
Small led lights to make steps visible in the dark - safety again
Different sizes of legs for the platforms to set the hight difference between rows
More safety pins and systems to secure the platforms and the chairs together

All of the above are made of high quality materials tested for safety and are made according to European regulations.
 
What You Get
Partnering with us in this endeavour is becomes an opportunity to join our awesome community of people who enjoy and love contemporary dance and are aware of the positive impact that this type of art has in the social, cultural and educational systems. 

Beautiful perks

you’ll be present on our website and social media 
someone in the team will make a special thanks video for you (surprise)
you’ll get to participate in our contemporary dance workshops, 
come and see the shows we’re making, 
you can have a special seat in the audience, 
for your amazing support you can actually appear next to our partners on our posters this year. 

Check out the perks and claim the one suitable for you!
 

LinoImpact
 
Linotip started as an idea and after long years of waiting and planning and taking steps back, building experience in life, in art, in working with other people, the right moment came. And we took it.

It wasn’t easy. We had an empty work-in-progress space that needed to be transformed in what it is today. For about 8 months, while the space was transforming (painting the walls, electric wiring, wooden floor, dance floor, lighting, sound, cleaning), we were questioning ourselves about what we aim with this project and building a strong strategy and a set of goals to guide us.

The biggest impact that we can continue to have with this space is to give confidence to others. Confidence that it’s ok to dare, to break the norm, to take on some risks, to challenge yourself and the times you’re living in to make a difference. 

And we continue to work a lot to keep it running. We feel strongly that this is what we have to do, and so, no matter how hard it gets sometimes, we believe in this art so much and in the people’s power to influence and change the world we live in that it’s actually impossible for us to quit doing what we do. :)
 

LinoRisks & LinoChallenges
Because we work independently, so no funds from the government to sustain us, the risk we take with this campaign is that we’re not gonna be able to raise the entire sum. 
To overcome this we turned to the community we built around us (performers, dancers, choreographers, actors, people in the audience and people that come to our classes), we established connections with the press and radio stations to help us share the message about this campaign. 
If you got here and you can’t contribute financially, but you like what we do, share our campaign with your friends! Contemporary dance is a magic place that worths our time and resources. 
 

Other LinoWays You Can Help
Together we can do so much more and we invite you, if you like us and what we do,  to spread out the word with your friends and family, on Facebook, Instagram, Linked-in, Youtube, Twitter, Pinterest and wherever you think it’s worth spreading. 
Write an article, post it, re-post it, cross-post it, make a video of how important it is for you to have a space like Linotip available for shows, classes, film projections, talks and all sorts of other activities related to contemporary dance.

story:
This has been an exciting year for me (and you too hopefully)... After touring the US last Fall, I distilled the creamiest, most frothy layer of my standup material and baked it into a 50 minute, multi- layer dream cake one man show 'Back In The Closet'. It's all of my wildest fantasies rolled into a theatrical burrito of insanity and pleasure- and the Edinburgh Fringe Festival is the ideal platform with which to go and launch this crazy show.

Originally when envisioning taking a show like this to Edinburgh Fringe last year, I was prepared to go do it in the back of a shrimp restaurant somewhere outside of town and just roll the cosmic dice and see what happens.

Now, through a series of very special events, great people and some good fortune, I'm so thrilled that I get to go do the show for 27 nights in a row inside of one of the most beautiful venues at the festival... a giant multi-theater castle that goes by the name of Gilded Balloon, right in the heart of everything.

The show itself is not very expensive. It's basically just me, some tights, a jar of peanut butter, a figure skating outfit, a pair of sneakers, and a keyboard/piano.. 

Launching it at Edinburgh Fringe Festival will be quite pricy. 

At bare minimum, total cost of flights, apartment, press/pr and marketing, producer costs, tech, and all related on-site fees runs close to 8,500 british pounds (about $12,000 US dollars, whuuut?!;)

This is where YOU (hopefully) might jump in and help lift one of these heavy gold bricks even just one little inch higher... every little push on here helps... it really does!  It feels surreal (and strangely exciting), and i've never done anything like this before-  it really is the opportunity of a lifetime and i really hope we can all make it happen together!  I can cover $8,000. We just need $3,800 more...

Please join the cause if you can, select a perk and become a loyal supporter and friend of this weird and crazy adventure. Ok thaank youuuu!!!!

way more info on the show here:
https://romanfraden.com

story:
Un parcours irrégulier... ça peut être riche!

Je suis étudiante en danse contemporaine à L'École de danse de Québec. Je termine officiellement cette formation en mai 2019. Auparavant, j'ai terminé mes études en Arts Visuels au Cégep de St-Laurent en 2015. J'ai commencé à pratiquer la danse de manière constante l'âge de 18ans. Voilà pourquoi je suis toujours à le recherche de formations diverses qui pourraient enrichir mon parcours! 

Le Projet

Dans un premier temps, ce projet me permettrait d'apprendre un vocabulaire gestuelle nouveau. En tant qu'interprète en danse contemporaine, il est important de pouvoir proposer une variété d'options gestuelles aux chorégraphes. La prochaine année scolaire sera ma dernière dans mon programme et j'aurai la chance de travailler avec plusieurs chorégraphes invités. Cette année déterminera largement mon initiation sur le marché du travail en tant que danseur interprète.

L'importance 

Souvent les danseurs qui s'entrainent depuis l'enfance ont une très bonne technique mais n'ont pas nécessairement la chance de vivre autres choses que la danse. Pour un danseur initié tardivement à la discipline, il se trouve souvent à avoir beaucoup de choses à exprimer sans avoir la justesse technique, ce qui ressemble plutôt à mon cas. Ce projet me permettrait de prendre confiance en tant que créateur et danseur dans l'objectif de promouvoir la diffusion d'oeuvres dansées diverses. Encourager la danse! Encourager la relève artistique! Encourager les parcours irréguliers! 

Ce que j'ai besoin

Jusqu'à présent, j'ai réussi à payer la formation en Chine de 1500$ pour une durée de 5 semaines  tout inclut.

Ceci comprend:

  • l'entrainement de 6h-7h par jour/5 jours par semaines.

Il y a un plan d'entrainement personnalisé pour chaque étudiant. Le jour d'arrivé à l'école, je dois rencontrer le directeur, Maître Shi Yanjia. Il sera en mesure de choisir le plan d'entraînement le plus approprié en fonction de mes besoins, de ma condition physique, de mon expérience et de mes exigences.

L'entrainement se fait en petit groupe. Je serai associé à une classe d'environ 10 étudiants dirigés par un maître avec une spécialisation de Kung Fu (Shaolin, Sanda, Wing Chun, ou Mantis Boxing). J'aurai aussi le privilège de suivre des sessions individuelles avec un maître de Shaolin.

  • logé pendant 5 semaines
  • nourrit 7 jours par semaine

Les fonds amassés m'aideront à payer mon billet d'avion (1000$). Le vol est déjà réservé. Je dois maintenant ramasser des sous pour rembourser le plus possible l'emprunt pour le billet avant mon départ en Chine. Tous les fonds accumulés, objectif atteint ou non, serviront à payer le billet d'avion en partie ou complètement.

L'impact

J'ai tenté de faire appel au CALQ (Conseil des Arts et des Lettres du Québec) et au CAC (Conseil des Arts du Canada) pour faire des demandes de bourses de perfectionnement. Malheureusement, les deux conseils acceptent uniquement les demandes de professionnels de domaines artistiques. Il n'y a donc aucune ressources financières pour les jeunes de la relève pour des projets à titre de perfectionnement. Il faut déjà être professionnel pour devenir professionnel...

Par le passé, j'ai utilisé cette plateforme (Indiegogo) pour lever des fonds afin de participer à un stage de perfectionnement à Montréal qui m'a énormément apporté en tant qu'interprète. La même année, j'ai été accepté à L'École de danse de Québec. Grâce à tous ces collaborateurs, je peux à ce jour étudier ma passion, explorer le mouvement du corps. Merci à vous!

Du concret! Horaire d'entrainement en Chine

Voici l'horaire en image:

file:///Users/camnarroe/Desktop/Training%20schedule%20and%20Kung%20Fu%20class%20-%20Qufu%20Shaolin%20Kung%20fu%20school.htm  

Une opportunité en or

  • Pourquoi partir maintenant ? Parce qu'ensuite il ne me restera qu'une année à l'école.
  •  Les arts martiaux comme le Kung Fu prend beaucoup de sa puissance technique du bassin. Dans mon cas, en danse, je me suis souvent blessée le bas du dos et le bassin à cause d'un manque de force. Cet entrainement m'est donc optimal pour prévenir d'éventuelle blessures.

Vous ne pouvez pas contribuer? 

Partagez ma page de financement et le tour est joué.

Merci infiniment!

story:
Love, hysteria, and deception reign in this Victorian re-imagining of Shakespeare’s classic. Cesario is in love with Orsino, who’s in love with Olivia, who’s in love with Cesario, who’s really Viola in disguise. 

There’s cross-dressing, crossed lines, and cross servants. The situation’s complicated, and that’s before Viola’s missing twin turns up! Societal masks, hidden identity, unrequited love, and the perils of Victorian psychiatry form an intricate web of heartbreak and despair. 

Can love prevail against the mores of Victorian society? Make of it what you will.


Hello!

We are Some Kind of Theatre, an emerging Edinburgh-based company who create accessible theatre with literary themes.  We are returning to the Edinburgh Fringe for the third year running, this time bringing with us a Victorian-inspired production of Shakespeare's Twelfth Night.  We will also be offering the show as part of our Shakespeare On The Sofa scheme, which brings theatre into living rooms, care homes, offices, and schools.

Our Show Team

Director: Chris Paddon

Assistant Director: Gerry Kielty

Producer: Emily Ingram

Tech: Craig A. Black
 

Our Cast
Orsino: Michael Brown

Malvolio/Antonio - Justin Skelton

Viola - Elsa Van Der Wal

Olivia - Cinzia DuBois

Toby - Chris Pearson

Maria - Rebecca Phipps

Andrew - James Sullivan
Feste: Effie Summers

 


(Photo by Nigel Thornton: The Steampunk Tempest, 2016)


Some Kind of Theatre At The Edinburgh Fringe
This year we’re making the move from the PBH Free Fringe, where we’ve performed for two very enjoyable years, to a more traditional venue (The Vault, Paradise Green, Merchant Street) in order to guarantee ourselves an accessible performance space.  

We want to ensure that our shows and auditions are available to everyone and, although we’ve had a fantastic time with PBH and admire the amazing work that their organising team do each year, we’ve found that the nature of the Free Fringe’s application and organisation process make it difficult to guarantee whether or not we will end up in a performance space that is accessible to wheelchairs, families, and other audience members, show crew and performers.  

This does however mean that we have to factor in venue hire costs this year, which is where crowdfunding comes in! 


(Photo by Nigel Thornton: Flyering for The Steampunk Tempest)

Where Will Your Money Go?
Venue
Performing in a modestly priced venue on the Fringe for a fortnight will cost us just shy of £2000.  We're already working hard to raise these funds through a variety of fun and exciting fundraising events, but this crowdfunding campaign's success would help us make the final push to pay for the use of Paradise Green's accessible and atmospheric Vault theatre space.

Publicity Materials
We're all about bringing Shakespeare's work to new audiences and so will be out and about every day of the Fringe flyering, offering show posters to local businesses, and chatting to potential audience members about our work.  Flyers and posters cost money (and so do emergency umbrellas for our flyering team when the Edinburgh summer rain strikes!), so your donations will help us ensure that we have enough publicity material to help us promote the show for the entire festival.

Set & Costume
As a company, we make a lot of our props, costume, and set from recycled materials and modified charity shop finds.  We do need some funds though to help source unusual bits of costume and scenery that we can't create ourselves, which this year include a dress-maker's mannequin and corsets.

Script Printing
Even the mundane costs have to be covered and - with a cast of nine and a crew of four - printing an approx 35 page script can add up quickly! 
 

(Set painting for Julius Caesar)

 

Thank You!
Thank you for taking the time to look at our crowdfunding campaign and to read this far.  If you're not able to contribute to the campaign, but would like to support us, there's lot of different ways that you can help.

- You can spread the word about the show and our crowdfunding campaign.

- You can come and see us at the Edinburgh Fringe, or book a Shakespeare On The Sofa performance of the show in your living room/garden/office/care home and invite friends and family who can't normally go to the theatre.

- If you are a business owner, consider sponsoring us or allowing us to display a poster at your business.

- You can support us at a later date via Ko-Fi or Patreon.

- You can follow us on Twitter or Instagram or like us on Facebook.


(Photo by Perry Jonnson: Julius Caesar)


Praise For Our Previous Shakespeare Productions:
 “A small, wondrous gem” ⭐⭐⭐⭐The Steampunk Tempest, 2016  
Dominic Leonard, The Edinburgh Fringe Review 

"a very enjoyable hour" Julius Caesar (with pirates!), 2017
Ariane Branigan, The Wee Review
