story:
About the show

After successful performances at 'Calm Down, Dear' Festival of Feminism 2018 (Camden People's Theatre), POW! Thanet International Women's Festival and HerStory Feminist Theatre Festival; poet and performer Alissa Anne Jeun Yi is developing Love Songs through the Soho Writer's Lab for a full Edinburgh Fringe run at Underbelly Cowgate (2nd-26th August) this summer. 

Established in 2017, Trip Hazards theatre company aims to innovatively stage fun, fresh and thought-provoking work for modern and diverse audiences. Their energetic, cross-disciplinary shows combine the autobiographical and the absurd, whilst finding creative ways to incorporate spoken word, live music, and rap into the telling of unheard stories.

www.triphazardstheatre.com | Facebook | Twitter

www.alissaajycooper.com | Twitter

Cast & Crew

Love Songs has emerged due to hard work from a variety of kick-ass female creatives:

  • Alissa Anne Jeun Yi (Writer/Performer)
  • Anna Jeary (Director)
  • Tanya Agarwal (Producer)
  • Mia Lewis (Assistant Producer)
  • Symoné Performing Artist (Hooping Choreographer) 
  • Annelise Heaton (Illustrator/Animator)
  • Katt Webster (Fashion Photographer)

 

Why we believe in Love Songs...

and why you should too

There are sadly a lot of shows about assault, but we believe we are developing something empowering, unique and fresh. Love Songs aims to present an different and ultimately ‘positive’ narrative about sexual assault arguably lacking in current discourse. This alternative narrative involves not painting those who have experienced rape as ‘survivors’ or ‘victims’, but instead focuses on embracing female vulnerability, allowing us to reclaim and ultimately own the moments we have felt violated and powerless. Regardless of the mistakes, the heartbreaks and the dark times, being able to grow as a person through challenging experiences is simply part of life, and life is worth celebrating.

As a newly-established BAME theatre company we are also driven to start a dialogue about the hyper-sexualised stereotypes East Asian women face daily, whilst giving other Asian women to see themselves properly represented on stage. Exoticised, submissive ideals about Chinese female bodies have long been ingrained in Western culture, but intersectional feminist critiques of this within theatre and other art forms continues to be lacking in proportion to the scope of this issue.

 

What your money will support

For transparency we have provided an outline of our budget for Love Songs below. We are looking to crowdfund a flexible target of £2000 to help cover these costs.

  • Fringe Registration, Brochure Entry and Venue Deposit - £1978.95
  • Accommodation - £2060
  • Print Marketing Materials - £500
  • Fuel for Transport - £190.80
  • Set, Props & Tech Hire - £365.00
  • Miscellaneous - £50  

 

What you'll get in return

We're delighted to have support from a number of great sponsors (Candy Kittens, Vegan Nights and more) to provide you with some sexy campaign perks to say THANK YOU! In keeping with the message of our show to embrace and enjoy female sexuality, check out our First Date, Treat Yo'Self and Date Night packages to the right...

 

Other ways you can help 

If you like what we're doing but aren't able to donate, we would massively appreciate your support in other ways. Here are some suggestions...

  • SHARE our campaign via email or social media - make sure you tag us and use #LoveSongsShow so we can give you a follow!
  • Follow us on Twitter & Facebook to stay up to date with the show!
  • Get in touch - if you have a project, Edinburgh show or publication you feel has themes in common with Love Songs, we'd love to hear from you regarding publicity opportunities and arranging PS Swaps for August

 

Thank you! ❤️️❤️️❤️️

story:
About ‘Curbside Players’

The Curbside Players theatre company was founded in January of 2018 by Natalie Bennett, Ethan & Madison Armstrong. The three met while studying theatre at the University of North Texas in Denton and were bonded by their shared love theatre. After realizing there was a need for innovative classical theatre in their community they determined that their first production as a company should be A Midsummer Night’s Dream. Our company is dedicated to to inspiring others, giving opportunities, and simply creating through the art of theatre. Our mission is to produce authentic shows that encompass the many important aspects of theatre.

 

A Midsummer Night’s Dream

Our production of William Shakespeare’s classic comedy will be set in America in the 1960’s. Themes of transformation are predominate in the show’s text as well as a defining feature of the sixties making this show an exciting and compelling combination as both the mundane and fantastical will be intermingled. This play, and its conceptualization, strive to emphasize the parallels of the struggles in the 1960’s and politics today, effectively forcing the audience to acknowledge that, while it may not repeat itself exactly, history does rhyme. Since January, our team has been working diligently on this production. We have cut the script ourselves while maintaining the iambic pentameter and rhyme scheme, thoroughly researched our concept, and in May met with Arts Mission Oak Cliff and put down the deposit for the space to stage our show! In June, we met for the first time as a company, to read through our script together and begin our rehearsal process. Since then this entire process has been more than rewarding, and with the help of our members (as well as our friends) we have a model for our set design as well as donated set pieces, posters and other promotional materials already designed, and even an original score!

 

What We Need

There are A LOT of costs involved in producing show and because we are an extremely new company we do not have a surplus of funds to pull from. To help ameliorate the costs we have set up this campaign and other fundraisers, in addition to selling ads in our program/ playbill. Any money donated from this campaign will go towards paying for our venue and event insurance, as they are our two most substantial costs. If we raise any additional funds they will go towards other necessities such as costumes and set dressing.

 

Risks & Challenges

Our three founders have put an immense amount of work into this wonderful and fulfilling project.  They have also been lucky enough to come into contact with some amazing individuals, with out whom, this production would not have been possible. We have had an outpouring of help from our company members, friends, and family that have eased many of the stressors involved in starting a theatre company and staging our first show, which is why money has been our largest hurdle. Currently, this production is being funded entirely by our three founders. Regardless of the total money raised from this campaign or any others the three of them have committed to the costs of this production. This means that your donation is essentially risk free, because the outcome of your donation (the show) is guaranteed. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We completely understand that not everyone can help us by contributing funds, but there are a couple of other ways you can help. Firstly, you can help us promote the show! Like us on Facebook (Curbside Players), follow us on Instagram (@curbsideplayers), and urge others to do the same!!! Secondly, if you or your business are interested in purchasing an ad in our program, email Natalie Bennett at nreneeb@verizon.net. LASTLY, Come see our show!!! Tickets are available for purchase at curbsideplayers.com

story:
Meet some old school leather daddies, lesbian auto mechanics and transgender activists - live & online.

Interested? 

No, this isn’t a new dating app (although someone please make that happen). It’s our newest live theater project. 

Experience LGBTQ+ history come alive as we bring OUT of Site: SOMA online, and learn about the many inspiring figures who made San Francisco into the Queer oasis that you know and love today.

\

An acid trip through Queer time & space
The performance centers around the untold stories of radical LGTBQ+ people in San Francisco’s SOMA district, a neighborhood that has been a catalyst for radical change and a stronghold for queer and activist organizing.

Our online show is a performance like you haven’t seen yet: immersive theater, drag, live music, puppetry, a virtual tour, a dance party - all in celebration of our radical LGBTQ+ figures who fought for justice and visibility. 

Enjoy a cocktail while sitting in The Stud, an historic queer bar where Sylvester and Ru Paul once graced the stage. See how the bar’s leather daddies transformed into the longhaired psychedelic artists who became the epicenter for the genderqueer revolution. Yes, that actually happened.

Learn about Alan Selby, the man who founded one of the most renowned kink and leather stories in the nation, and how he raised critical funds for his community during the AIDS crisis. Get the chance to wear your best leathers and parade them on our virtual stage. You can also volunteer to appear in a scene!  

Join Michael Valerio and Kathleen Connell - two out & proud organizers who founded the Folsom Street Fair, resisted redevelopment, and raised awareness and created community during the AIDS pandemic.

Stories of resilience

This show honors their legacies of resistance, resilience and rising to the occasion when faced with great adversity.  

Real talk: many of us are feeling the hardship of being physically disconnected from our communities right now. The ability to gather and be seen together in public spaces has always been a key way for our Queer communities to be heard. With these physical spaces currently inaccessible to us, we must find ways to build community virtually.

Our show provides just that: a way to be together through virtual space. Through this show, we connect others around the world and have a whole lot of fun while doing it. 

This show reminds us that we have been here before, and that we can learn from history on how to deal with times like these.  We have inherited that same strength and resilience that enabled our Queer ancestors to survive times of turmoil.

Going Virtual

We originally anticipated to premiere this show in June, out on the streets in San Francisco’s SOMA district where these original stories took place. Just as we were gearing up to premiere the work, the City of San Francisco was put under shelter-in-place orders. Our dream to celebrate these stories on the streets where they happened had all but been dashed.

We were faced with a hard decision: Do we postpone? Do we wait until next year when we can do this safely? All the while, our small theater company was facing the immediate struggle to stay economically afloat during this pandemic.

Weighing our options, we realized that this show, and these stories, needed to be told right now. In this moment of crisis, we believe this performance is a balm for the challenges we are currently facing.

Your Support

Your donation will have impact in several ways:

  • Support our arts ecology: All funds will be used to pay our artists, designers and staff in order to make this a virtual show like-never-before.
     
  • Support those who are facing economic hardship: Your donation will subsidize our low-income audiences, allowing us to offer pay-what-you can tickets to our folks who can’t afford the full ticket price.
     
  • Keep the vision of our theater company alive: When shelter in place is lifted and we feel safe to be together in public again, we look forward to sharing this show on the streets and, you can say that this is a project that YOU helped keep alive at a time when we need it most. 

Join with us to ensure that LGBTQ+ history is never lost.

story:
Showpony Studio is a collaboration of efforts between three of Vancouver's beloved burlesque companies; Diasporic Dynasty, Geekenders, and Virago Nation.  Needing a permanent place to call home, we have been offered an exciting yet time-sensitive opportunity to take over the old "Chicken Coop" - a 2,000 sq foot studio complete with dance mirrors and costume storage.  Our companies are all coming together to create a community-driven space for rehearsals, workshops, performances, and live-streamed shows.  By donating to this fundraiser, you will be providing a safe and welcoming home for performers and producers to create their art, and you will also be supporting LGBTQ+, Indigenous, and BIPOC communities.  With COVID-19 closing down theatres all over the world, our revenue and funding has been cut to pretty much nothing, and we need your help to keep this space afloat until performances become normalized again!

 

Taking over a lease in the middle of a pandemic is an ambitious endeavor, especially with the current state of businesses not being able to open up fully until a vaccine for COVID-19 is discovered.  We know it's sad to hear, but there’s no guarantee that theatres will open up anytime soon.  For that reason, the ideal situation is that we are able to raise enough funds to cover at least 6 months of costs, without having to worry about relying on show revenue to foot the bills.  We are very lucky to have found a physical location to call home, and this fundraiser helps to ensure we will be able to keep this studio in the glitter-covered hands of the Vancouver burlesque community members.   With your generous support, we will be able to offer the space to other Vancouver creatives as well, with proper social distancing and COVID-19 safety protocols in action, of course.

 

Plain and simple, funding a studio costs money... 

Before we can even begin to imagine using the space to bring more sparkly magic into the world, we need cash in hand for the upcoming rental fees & utilities.  Since most venues and shows (aka our main revenue streams) are not able to go on for the unforeseeable future, we are hoping to raise enough to prepare at least 6 months of rent and utilities. This makes up a large chunk of money needed; about $10,000-$12,000.

While this rehearsal studio's approach to redecorate is black box theatre style (neutral and minimalist), the upgrades in function and style that we will have is going to cost between $3,000-$5,000; with the focus being on new paint for the walls and set pieces, backdrop curtains, a sound system, and photo studio lighting for live streaming shows and filming performances.  The more we raise, the better quality equipment we can invest in! 

That doesn't even cover campaign funds, advertising budget, physical perks fulfillment, business permits, insurance, website design, cleaning equipment and more. All those little things really add up!


Graciously donated by performers, creators, and artists of the local burlesque scene, there's some wonderful prizes available for our fundraiser!  From Showpony Prize Packs, to Pin-Up Photography Packages, to homemade pasties, to 1 on 1 classes with some of Vancouver's BEST Burlesque Dancers, there's a magical perk for everyone.  Scroll along the side bar of this campaign to see every gift there is to offer.

You can also buy a yearly MEMBERSHIP to our society if there's nothing there that entices you, but we doubt that will be the case.  Perks include studio time, reduced rental rates, and (eventual) show tickets! 

We would also be grateful for bigger donations, if you want to become a permanent sponsor of Showpony Studio.  If anyone needs to organize a payment plan outside of IndieGoGo, please do not hesitate to reach out via email:  showponystudioinfo@gmail.com 
 

Below is merely an introduction to each of our companies, and we hope you feel intrigued to get to know more after reading about our campaign.

DIASPORIC DYNASTY: Diasporic Dynasty is a newly-established Black, Indigenous, and Persons of Color (#BIPOC) collective, aiming to champion and uplift the stories of BIPOC within the Vancouver Performing Arts communities.  Their group comprises of burlesque and drag performers who have performed around the province over the past decade - thus, their practice largely centers on movement, striptease, and satire while celebrating the diversity in their voices and paths.​  As individuals weary of working in productions and communities that do not see them as priorities, they have joined together to decolonize stages and foster inclusive opportunities for BIPOC creators.
Find out more about DIASPORIC DYNASTY here.

GEEKENDERS THEATRICALS: Geekenders, called a "cult sensation" by Vancity Buzz, is British Columbia's pre-eminent geeky theatrical and performance troupe.  Producing ‘nerdlesque' shows, variety shows, fandom-based parties, plays, and immersive theatre, Geekenders is, first and foremost, about community. Their emphasis is always going to be about providing a quirky, interesting evening full of art, socializing, and fun for those of you who might not otherwise spend their Friday at a party, while also offering space for LGBTQ+ stories and body-positivity.
Find out more about GEEKENDERS here.

VIRAGO NATION:  Founded in May 2016, Virago Nation is on a mission to reclaim Indigenous sexuality from the toxic effects of colonization. Through humour, seduction, pop culture, and politics, they will show that Indigenous women will not be confined to the colonial virgin-whore dichotomy, but will design a new dynamic and multi-faceted sexual identity rooted in their own desires.   They are a collective of Indigenous artists creating performance through burlesque, theatre, song, and spoken word as well as workshops and community networks rematriating Indigenous sexuality.
​Find out more about VIRAGO NATION here.

We understand that people don't have a lot of extra funds to spend, especially in these times.  But there are many other ways you can help us.

Please share the campaign widely!  Every time you share this in your favourite Slack, Discord, Twitter, Instagram, Facebook group, or wherever it is that you do your socializing online, it helps bring visibility to our campaign and to more folx who can help make the dream of this studio a reality.

We will also need lots of hands on deck for cleaning, re-painting, hanging lights, installing sound systems, organizing, etc.  Volunteers will be offered studio time as a thank you.

Adding prizes to the list is another way you can help.  Are you a teacher, photographer, artist, or another creative that can offer a perk to add to the roster?  Please send us an email!

If anyone is able to offer connections to big sponsors or grant funding in regards to supporting LGBTQ+, Indigenous, and BIPOC artists, please don't hesitate to reach out to us at: showponystudioinfo@gmail.com 
 

Thank you so much for your time and support, and we hope to see you at Showpony Studio soon!

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

We gratefully acknowledge that our companies operate primarily on the stolen traditional terrorities of the xwməθkwəy̓əm (Musqueam), Skwxwú7mesh (Squamish), and Səl̓ílwətaʔ/ Selilwitulh (Tsleil-Waututh) peoples. We do so to honour the original caretakers of these lands who have been here since time immemorial, and the Indigenous people who continue to activate, protect, and care for these lands. Learn more at: https://native-land.ca/

a 2,000 sq foot studio complete with dance mirrors and costume storage.  Our companies are all coming together to create a community-driven space for rehearsals, workshops, performances, and live-streamed shows.  By donating to this fundraiser, you will be providing a safe and welcoming home for performers and producers to create their art, and you will also be supporting LGBTQ+, Indigenous, and BIPOC communities.  With COVID-19 closing down theatres all over the world, our revenue and funding has been cut to pretty much nothing, and we need your help to keep this space afloat until performances become normalized again! Taking over a lease in the middle of a pandemic is an ambitious endeavor, especially with the current state of businesses not being able to open up fully until a vaccine for COVID-19 is discovered.  We know it's sad to hear, but there’s no guarantee that theatres will open up anytime soon.  For that reason, the ideal situation is that we are able to raise enough funds to cover at least 6 months of costs, without having to worry about relying on show revenue to foot the bills.  We are very lucky to have found a physical location to call home, and this fundraiser helps to ensure we will be able to keep this studio in the glitter-covered hands of the Vancouver burlesque community members.   With your generous support, we will be able to offer the space to other Vancouver creatives as well, with proper social distancing and COVID-19 safety protocols in action, of course. Plain and simple, funding a studio costs money... Before we can even begin to imagine using the space to bring more sparkly magic into the world, we need cash in hand for the upcoming rental fees & utilities.  Since most venues and shows (aka our main revenue streams) are not able to go on for the unforeseeable future, we are hoping to raise enough to prepare at least 6 months of rent and utilities. All those little things really add up!Graciously donated by performers, creators, and artists of the local burlesque scene, there's some wonderful prizes available for our fundraiser!  From Showpony Prize Packs, to Pin-Up Photography Packages, to homemade pasties, to 1 on 1 classes with some of Vancouver's BEST Burlesque Dancers, there's a magical perk for everyone.  Scroll along the side bar of this campaign to see every gift there is to offer.You can also buy a yearly MEMBERSHIP to our society if there's nothing there that entices you, but we doubt that will be the case.  Perks include studio time, reduced rental rates, and (eventual) show tickets! We would also be grateful for bigger donations, if you want to become a permanent sponsor of Showpony Studio.  If anyone needs to organize a payment plan outside of IndieGoGo, please do not hesitate to reach out via email:  showponystudioinfo@gmail.com  Below is merely an introduction to each of our companies, and we hope you feel intrigued to get to know more after reading about our campaign.DIASPORIC DYNASTY: Diasporic Dynasty is a newly-established Black, Indigenous, and Persons of Color (#BIPOC) collective, aiming to champion and uplift the stories of BIPOC within the Vancouver Performing Arts communities.  Their group comprises of burlesque and drag performers who have performed around the province over the past decade - thus, their practice largely centers on movement, striptease, and satire while celebrating the diversity in their voices and paths.​  As individuals weary of working in productions and communities that do not see them as priorities, they have joined together to decolonize stages and foster inclusive opportunities for BIPOC creators.Find out more about DIASPORIC DYNASTY here.GEEKENDERS THEATRICALS: Geekenders, called a "cult sensation" by Vancity Buzz, is British Columbia's pre-eminent geeky theatrical and performance troupe.  Producing ‘nerdlesque' shows, variety shows, fandom-based parties, plays, and immersive theatre, Geekenders is, first and foremost, about community. Their emphasis is always going to be about providing a quirky, interesting evening full of art, socializing, and fun for those of you who might not otherwise spend their Friday at a party, while also offering space for LGBTQ+ stories and body-positivity.Find out more about GEEKENDERS here.VIRAGO NATION:  Founded in May 2016, Virago Nation is on a mission to reclaim Indigenous sexuality from the toxic effects of colonization. Through humour, seduction, pop culture, and politics, they will show that Indigenous women will not be confined to the colonial virgin-whore dichotomy, but will design a new dynamic and multi-faceted sexual identity rooted in their own desires.   They are a collective of Indigenous artists creating performance through burlesque, theatre, song, and spoken word as well as workshops and community networks rematriating Indigenous sexuality.​Find out more about VIRAGO NATION here.We understand that people don't have a lot of extra funds to spend, especially in these times.  But there are many other ways you can help us.Please share the campaign widely!  Every time you share this in your favourite Slack, Discord, Twitter, Instagram, Facebook group, or wherever it is that you do your socializing online, it helps bring visibility to our campaign and to more folx who can help make the dream of this studio a reality.We will also need lots of hands on deck for cleaning, re-painting, hanging lights, installing sound systems, organizing, etc.  Volunteers will be offered studio time as a thank you.Adding prizes to the list is another way you can help.  Are you a teacher, photographer, artist, or another creative that can offer a perk to add to the roster?  Please send us an email!If anyone is able to offer connections to big sponsors or grant funding in regards to supporting LGBTQ+, Indigenous, and BIPOC artists, please don't hesitate to reach out to us at: showponystudioinfo@gmail.com  Thank you so much for your time and support, and we hope to see you at Showpony Studio soon!------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------We gratefully acknowledge that our companies operate primarily on the stolen traditional terrorities of the xwməθkwəy̓əm (Musqueam), Skwxwú7mesh (Squamish), and Səl̓ílwətaʔ/ Selilwitulh (Tsleil-Waututh) peoples. We do so to honour the original caretakers of these lands who have been here since time immemorial, and the Indigenous people who continue to activate, protect, and care for these lands. Learn more at: https://native-land.ca/

story:
Welcome!

I’m Adanna, the writer of ‘At The Feet Of Jesus’. ATFOJ is set in Brazil during the 2014 World Cup and explores family, football and the sacrifices made to protect your heritage at all cost. This is all brought to life through the oral storytelling of the Brazilian Candomblé tradition.

We’re raising £3000 to help bring this play to the Omnibus theatre and Young Vic this summer.

By supporting you will:

  • Ensure we’re able to pay all contributors involved.
  • Support our mentor programme: subsidising two young creatives to join our team & learn about the process of producing a show.
  • Help us connect with local communities in London via our community performance and workshop at the Young Vic (part of their Neighbourhood Theatre initiative).

 

The Show's Origins

During the lead up to the 2014 World Cup and 2016 Olympics I began to watch lots of documentaries about the effect these global events were having on the local residents of Brazil. I was captured by how similar and relatable their stories were to Londoners who were also feeling the effects of gentrification and the impact social class has on communities across the city.

In 2014 a shorter version of my play was chosen as part of the Braziliance Festival by StoneCrabs theatre. In 2016 I developed the play and submitted it to Angelic Tales new writing festival at Theatre Royal Stratford East. It was staged for one night and had a sold out performance. Since then I’ve been working towards transforming the play into a full length production.

The Show

"...the very clay you walk on runs through our veins..."
Rio 2014, the World Cup. Brazil vs Germany. The streets are electric with excitement, politics, protests and violence.  The Cardoso family are at a crossroads. Hours away from being evicted, they have decide whether to fight to stay where their ancestors have lived for centuries or leave everything they know and love behind.

In their plight for freedom the family discover buried secrets that threaten to pull apart the very thing they treasure most: each other.

How far would you go to protect your family’s legacy?

At The Feet Of Jesus is a vibrant and provocative play about family, football and the sacrifices made to protect the ones you love at all costs. All brought to life, through the vibrant oral storytelling of the Brazilian Candomblé tradition.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Much of the costs for the production has been catered for but we still need to raise additional funds to ensure the show's success. We need the help of contributors like you to make this show happen.

The money raised during this campaign will help to cover the cost of:

  • Lighting and Technical Support
  • Videography (to capture rehearsals and the production)
  • Costume
  • Set Design
  • Mentoring Programme
  • Marketing

To express our gratitude for your support, all contributors will receive a Special Thanks in our program. Some support levels come with added bonuses, including:

  • Press night tickets
  • Signed copy of the script
  • Exclusive access to rehearsals
  • VIP ticket to Young Vic performance (entry via invitation only)

 

The Impact

I think it’s really important to explore how we all share the same hopes and fears regardless of country and culture. I wrote ATFOJ with the intention of connecting a British audience with a different perspective of Brazil that’s rarely shown on stage. My hope is that by showing this play, an audience can have fun and enjoy the relatability of the story.

We’re staging a free performance at the Young Vic and collaborating with the theatre as part of their Neighbourhood Theatre initiative. This will provide the opportunity for local communities in London (who don’t often have access to theatre) to watch our show for free. Followed by a fun Q&A and workshop with a Paraiso School of Samba.  

With your support we can create a successful run and the Omnibus and Young Vic which will stand us in good stead to fulfill our future goals for the production: A UK tour of the production and and staging of the play in Brazil itself. Exciting!

 

Risks & Challenges

Time is the biggest challenging factor as we only have 2 months to bring this project all together by May 2020.

When managing similar projects in the past, I learnt that organisation is the essential to key to succeeding within a tight schedule. We have a dedicated team behind ATFOJ which will maximise the our time by being able to delegate tasks and share responsibilities. This will ensure the best possibility of a successful production.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We appreciate that not everyone can contribute financially to the campaign, but there are other ways you can help!

We ask you to please SHARE our campaign in your social media circles by use of the Indiegogo share tools.

Donate, share and spread the word!

Show Dates/Location

At The Feet Of Jesus (Omnibus Theatre) dates/times are:

  • May 12 at 7.30 pm
  • May 13 at 7.30 pm
  • May 14 at 7.30 pm
  • May 15 at 7.30 pm
  • May 16 at 7.30 pm
  • May 17 at 4.00 pm

Purchase tickets at https://www.omnibus-clapham.org/

At The Feet Of Jesus (Young Vic  - by invitation only)

  • July 23 at 7.00pm

https://www.youngvic.org/index.php/taking-part/neighbourhood-theatre

Thank You for your support!

Show Dates/Location

May 16 at 7.30 pm
May 17 at 4.00 pm

Purchase tickets at https://www.omnibus-clapham.org/

July 23 at 7.00pm
https://www.youngvic.org/index.php/taking-part/neighbourhood-theatre

story:
Short Summary

“How do I begin when there are few words I can choose??

I’m a Los Angeles based writer who always thought the music of British Synth-Pop duo Erasure would make a fantastic musical.

So, in 2015, I began the journey of  “OH L’AMOUR: The Erasure Musical.”   It’s been a labor of love that ultimately placed me in the same room with legends Vince Clarke and Andy Bell at The Roundhouse London in 2017!!  Their support and encouragement  has fueled continued progress on the show - most recently a table read in L.A. March 8th of this year.

Now, we’re preparing a new, fully-sung OH L’AMOUR!  With a talented cast of actors and dancers, this showcase will be recorded and made available for streaming later this year.

How Can You Help?

The money raised in this campaign will be used to cover costs of a new production that will be used to attract theatrical producers to OH L'AMOUR such as recording new tracks for 24 Erasure songs!  “Phantom Bride” as a lullaby?  “Sometimes” as a country western ballad?  Telling the OH L’AMOUR story requires new versions of all our favorite Erasure songs.  

Benefits of your support to include show swag, signed show memorabilia.  These will evolve over the course of the campaign - so check in often!

Why “OH L’AMOUR?”

OH L’AMOUR’s theme - “If you’re not born into a family that will love you as-is, build one that does.” -  is as relevant today as it was in the 1980s when the show is set.

With a cast of characters as diverse as the world we live in, OH L’AMOUR is exactly the life-affirming, jubilant and fun show we need right now!  

First performed in 2016 to 300+ guests, screened in London and Erasure authorized in 2017,  additional readings in Chicago (2018) and Los Angeles (2020) plus over 7000 Vimeo views worldwide of the original performance recording …L’AMOUR’s music, characters and humor have kept fans wanting more!

Here’s your chance to join the ever-widening L’AMOUR family and to help it achieve its ultimate goal of a Broadway or West End theatrical run.

What's the show about?

Hideaway Records is where we find Sam at the open of OH L’AMOUR.   It’s 1985, the economy sucks, Reagan has a war on drugs and AIDS is a shadow that looms over every gay man.  Sam’s an aspiring writer and comes from a long line of…under-educated folk who don’t think that’s a respectable living.  Sam’s good; he’s got the acceptance letter to an elite writer’s program at San Francisco State to prove it.  But there is neither money nor support for him at home.  Sam’s only option, should he wish to honor his star that guides him and his warm heart that seeks romance, is to get to San Francisco somehow.

When all his belongings are stolen his first day out, Sam’s newfound friend Savannah offers him solace and a couch.  A smart, street savvy Black woman, Savannah’s no stranger to catastrophe herself, though hers usually come in the form of problematic boyfriends.

Sam immediately meets Bobby, a charismatic DJ who longs for spinning stardom.   Sam is drawn to Bobby like a moth to a flame.  Savannah, meanwhile, meets the one straight employee in the gay bar at which Bobby spins; a white Texas cowboy who spews Southern charm and who might be too good for a girl with brash self-esteem issues.  Beau is key in helping Sam emerge from his cocoon to win over the elusive Bobby, endearing himself to all.

Ignoring warning signs that Bobby might have one foot in their relationship and another in 80s promiscuity, Sam follows Bobby to San Francisco as it luckily coincides with his own dream.  That dream is sidelined, though, by the allure of the city and its nighttime denizens.  Sam’s creative productivity sputters.  Savannah stays behind and her relationship with Beau hits its own turbulence.

Sam and Bobby go sour quickly in the city of free love and limitless self expression.  Bobby’s need for attention and adulation, combined with a side career Sam uncovers, are more than Sam can handle.    

Sam’s new student reading at SF State is the moment he unexpectedly loses Bobby and meets Latinx social worker Gabriel.

The end of Act I finds Sam, alone and despondent, spiraling downwards.  Not even Savannah, who bought a one way ticket to San Francisco, can stop Sam’s descent.  She’s fleeing her own demons; finding herself pregnant after kicking Beau out, worried the child would force Beau to stick around to love the un-loveable…her.  Beau, working odd jobs along the way, is en route to find Savannah.

At the bottom of a spiral, alone on a smoky dance floor, Sam is lifted up by a drag queen (with a "Hope" tattoo - a star where the "O" should be) and lured to a bright new day.

ACT II starts a year later.

Beau arrives in San Francisco the day Savannah has come to end of her search for Sam, now living at a halfway house called “The Innocents.”  They’ve all survived journeys of hiding and searching - unable to realize that what they require most is the love and support they so rightly deserve from those dearest to them.  Savannah finds the house but is turned away.  Sam hides until she leaves, but Savannah notices Sam’s pale blue Smith Corona typewriter in the corner and knows he’s there.  They’re finally reunited.

Sam and Gabriel, The Innocents house manager, have a relationship akin to a sparring couple in a screwball comedy.   It started the moment that drag queen dropped Sam off on the front steps.  Everyone thinks Sam and Gabriel act like boyfriends, including Bobby who’s still around as the spirit to which Sam confides.  Bobby knows he needs to move on, that Sam’s inability to let go of the past is preventing him from enjoying the now and dreaming of the future again.  Gabriel just might be part of that future.

Beau finally sees Savannah and the son he’s never seen.  They come to discover that they share the same fears and those can be better dealt with as a team.   The unopened letters Beau has been sending Savannah have each included a check from his oil jobs.  Enough money to open the hair salon Savannah has always dreamed of.

Sam and Gabriel’s friendship ends in an argument-ending kiss.  A kiss that means Gabriel will have to resign.  The kiss also signals to Bobby that he can move on; his guilt was keeping him earthbound.  

At an Act-Up fundraiser at Wonderland, Sam discovers Beau has returned and the drag queen who saved Sam's life is revealed.  Sam says good-bye to Bobby.  United as friends and lovers, our leads prepare to love and fight against whatever will come their way.

Risks & Challenges

Should we fall short of goal, we'll adapt this step of OH L’AMOUR to fit within the amount raised.  Although this will not affect physical dividends, it might affect experiential dividends such as pre-show party.   This could also affect if, when and how the show is streamed.

Other Ways You Can Help

Times are challenging right now and we know not everyone can participate financially.  Supporting us on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram is a HUGE help.   If you live in the LA area and can help in other ways, drop us a line!  We’d love to hear from you.

story:
Our Project

Rochelle Perry is a writer/producer.  She’s had a number of plays produced, but this time it’s a little different… and much more “ambitious” than any other project she’s produced herself. After reading Lewis Carroll’s Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland and Through the Looking Glass, she was inspired like nothing’s inspired her in a long time.  Since she loves merging art and theatre, she thought Wonderland would be the perfect springboard for creativity and imagination.  So she put a call out to writers around the country to submit ten minute plays based on Carroll’s Alice books, and she and the literary department chose the eight best plays of the bunch.

Having a campaign on Indie Gogo is a valuable tool for spreading the word about your passion project.  This is not only a dream for the producers, but a dream for everyone involved.  There are actors who have expressed they always wanted to play the Cheshire Cat. There are artists who have said they have always wanted to paint their version of the Red Queen.  Even the costumers have always wanted to put their spin on dressing the characters.  And now each of them have a chance to do that.  It’s amazing that one man’s work could inspire so many to get together and collaborate on such an exciting project!  For many this has become a way for artists to express themselves.  It’s turned into a project much bigger than something anyone ever thought it would be.  (And who doesn’t love Wonderland?!)

What We Need

We need to raise $5000 to fund:

  • Costumes
  • Set/Props
  • Directors
  • Actors
  • Stage Manager
  • Light/Sound Design
  • FOOD!

What You Get

Here are the perks:

  • FAN OF WONDERLAND – For $1 you are awesome just for donating.  We silently thank you.
  • THANK YOU – For $5 you will get a personal thank you on our website/facebook page.
  • ADMISSION – For $25 you will get a free ticket to see the show (this includes tea and cookies) and a thank you on social media and in the program.  (Note: Tickets through this Campaign will be special commemorative tickets with your name on it.)
  • T-SHIRT – For $50 you will receive a Curious Conversation t-shirt (plus all previous perks)
  • ARTSY FARTSY – For $100 you will receive a free handmade teacup ring and a limited edition print of the Curious Conversations poster signed by Maria Vitan, the artist (plus all previous perks)
  • WELCOME TO WONDERLAND– For $150 you get a poster signed by the cast and crew (includes shipping and handling if you can’t make it to the show) AND a photo with the cast and crew (plus all previous perks)
  • UNBIRTHDAY BRUNCH – For $250, you can have brunch with members of the cast and crew (plus all previous perks)
  • REWRITING WONDERLAND – For $500, you can work with one of the writers to develop your own 10-minute play and have it produced at the Eclectic Company Theatre (plus all previous perks)
  • WE'RE ALL MAD HERE – For $750, you will receive a costume or prop from the show (plus all previous perks)
  • LEWIS CARROLL'S PRODUCER – For $1000 you will receive producer credit and you can spend a day in LA with the producer, visit Wonderland-inspired shops, eat Wonderland-inspired food, and a ticket to Disneyland (enjoy the Alice in Wonderland ride, the Teacups, or both!) (plus all previous perks)

The Impact

Both Thursday performances will be “Pay What You Can.”  This really allows the underprivileged to come and see the show.  A portion of the funds will also be donated to various children’s hospitals and charities.

We’ll also have a WONDERLAND ART GALLERY at the theatre during the performance.  For every art piece that sells, a portion will be donated back to the theatre and back into the arts themselves.  Thank you for keeping 99 Seat Theatre alive in Los Angeles!!!

Risks & Challenges

With your contributions you’re giving us this chance to really do this project justice… did I ever say how many people have told me how “ambitious” this project is?  Wonderland was never meant to be small.  To do it justice, you have to think about all that’s involved – an entire evening that transports the audience through the rabbit hole and into Wonderland, with its beautiful sets, elaborate costumes, quirky characters, and a whole lotta fun!

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute financially, that doesn't mean you can't help!

  • Please share this campaign with your friends
  • Follow us on Facebook
  • Check out our website
  • Come and see the show
  • Volunteer to help out as an associate producer, stage manager, or artist

Hope to see you at the show.  Please say hi so we can personally thank you for your contribution.
story_txt:
Our Project
 
Rochelle
Perry is a writer/producer.  She’s had a
number of plays produced, but this time it’s a little different… and much more
“ambitious” than any other project she’s produced herself. After reading Lewis Carroll’s Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland and Through the Looking Glass, she was
inspired like nothing’s inspired her in a long time.  Since she loves merging art and theatre, she
thought Wonderland would be the perfect springboard for creativity and imagination.  So she put a call out to writers around the country to submit ten
minute plays based on Carroll’s Alice books, and she and the literary
department chose the eight best plays of the bunch.
Having a campaign on Indie Gogo is a
valuable tool for spreading the word about your passion project.  This is not only a dream for the
producers, but a dream for everyone involved. 
There are actors who have expressed they always wanted to play the Cheshire Cat.
There are artists who have said they have always wanted to paint their version of the Red Queen.  Even the costumers
have always wanted to put their spin on dressing the characters.  And now each of them have a chance to do
that.  It’s amazing that one man’s work
could inspire so many to get together and collaborate on such an exciting
project!  For many this has become a way
for artists to express themselves.  It’s
turned into a project much bigger than something anyone ever thought it would
be.  (And who doesn’t love Wonderland?!)

Costumes

story:
Wi111ow Theatre presents a physical poem in collaboration with poet Miriam Calleja and featuring live music by Fuzzhoneys. Trap-ease is made up of a bite-sized collective, with each member bringing what they love best to the table. Starting on a zero budget is difficult, but when there’s a good mix of drive and dedication you know you’re onto something good. 

Over the last four months, we’ve been taking care of every little detail from finding a place to shelter our rehearsals, to designing props in synch to the physicality of the performance, transcribing poems into script form, finding resources to aid our concept and so on.

Starting from a group of poems the script has flourished, and we can’t do this without your help. The event is to consist of the band Fuzzhoneys to sustain the live performance; therefore we need a sound system. Appropriate lighting is another crucial part of any theatre performance. The rental of equipment and professional help are the most costly parts of the project.

Considering the whole process of planning, collecting and setting this is a low budget improvised project full of love and hard work. The team consists of: 

  • Alba Florian Viton has a B.A.Hons degree in Theatre Studies and is the creator and director & performer of Wi111ow Theatre - 
  • Naomi Said is a professional actress, she's been working in performance since 2013 and has followed several international acting workshops.
  • Brandon Shaw is a dance professor at the University of Malta and the director of Cleave Dance Theatre. 
  • Miriam Calleja is a pharmacist by profession, a foodie and writer by passion. She is about to publish a book of poetry called Pomegranate Heart.

Not familiar with these names? 

Check out the first collaboration of As the Dust Settles - the full performance is online; from the snippets mentioned in our video. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jl7L_fsuykQ 

Have a look at the perks, we have personally made these gifts and they are fully related to the script of our play - it's always lovely to have a booklet or a small art piece that reminds you of something you have watched and experienced! Through lots of passion and sweat, we're really giving a lot of work into this and the perks you'll get can only be found through this space - From the CDs, to the posters, to the dedicated physical piece!

All gifts/perks can only be found through this Indiegogo - Limited time of 25 days.

Please help us to bring this performance to life!


TRAP-EASE 

Alba Florian Viton Director & Actress (Shiela) 

Naomi Said  - Actress (Louisa)

Brandon Shaw - Actor (Tim)

Miriam Callejja - Writer & Assistant Director. 

Francesca Mercieca - Production assistant, Camera & Music.

Mia Scerri - Camera & Sound


Any questions/ queries?

Get in touch:  trapeasemalta@gmail.com

story:
My name is Ava Shapiro.  I am completing my Bat Mitzvah on May 2nd, 2015.  I chose our wonderful Ballet School, Ballet Western Reserve (BWR), in downtown Youngstown, Ohio as my Mitzvah project because our ballet school is very dear to me and we need funds!

BWR has been in business as a non-profit 501 c3 for 52 years!  Our building, while it has a ton of character, is even much older than that.  As a result, our historic building is often in need of capital improvements, and just as importantly, we have many talented dancers in the greater Youngstown area that cannot afford to start or continue their dance education.  BWR needs money for both capital improvements and scholarship money.  

It is so important to me to not only help BWR survive while I am a student, but also to make sure it remains viable for years to come.  Youngstown is an amazing city with a storied history, but when things in the local economy are tough, as they are in Youngstown, the Arts usually suffer.  Downtown Youngstown needs the arts to remain vibrant and BWR plays a huge part in making that a reality.  

BWR trains dancing students from the age of 3 years old to the age of 18.  Our Ballet school has produced countless students who have gone on to dance in college and even professionally.  We, the students of BWR, take our passion for dance very seriously!  The thought that BWR might not have the funds to continue long term is truly heartbreaking to many of us.  In order to survive, we must continue with capital improvements to our building.  We also need to continue to offer some scholarship money in order to maintain the diversity of our dancers and be able to provide assistance to dedicated students that just could not afford to maintain their dance education without help.

Just last year, BWR needed to spend $50,000.00 to repair it's dilapadated roof.  We were fortunate enough to be awarded a large grant and then raised the rest of the money from private donations.  However, we know that we cannot always go to the same contributors every time we need money.  We also are aware that the majority of our students could not continue as students here if we often raised tuition.  We need your help!  We need to expand our financial support group and raise at least $15,000.00.  This money will allow us to continue offering some scholarship money as well as keep our building in working order.  Right now, we need new flooring in a few of our studios, we need a technology upgrade, and our signage is outdated and does not reflect our current status.

Just recently, I had the privilege of taking a master ballet class with Misty Copeland from American Ballet Theater in New York City.  If you have never heard of her, you should google her.  She is one of the most famous ballerinas in the country.  She started dancing at the age of 13 at a Boys and Girls club in California.  Misty was raised by a single mom and had 3 full and 2 half siblings.  If someone did not discover her dancing and provide assistance to allow her to flourish, the world would have lost an amazing artist.  She is now widely regarded as one of the most beautiful and talented dancers in the world and performs professionally.  She is sponsored by Under Armour and her commercials are inspiring!  The next Misty Copeland just might be right here, in Youngstown, Ohio!

I am certain that BWR has made me a better person, both physically and mentally.  BWR is an amazing Youngstown institution that has literally improved the lives of thousands of students.  We, at BWR, are very passionate about our dance school.  We have amazing teachers and students.  All that we lack are funds!  We love our school.  We need your help!  Any donation you make, large or small, means a lot and all of us dancers at BWR will be very appreciative.  Thank you so much for taking the time to hear my solicitation.  Please consider funding our school!

story:
"Our main aim is to make a theatre space that is accessible and affordable, allowing companies and artists to come in and be nurtured artistically but also come out the other end financially better off." Jamie and Ella, Artistic Directors.


We are a brand new fringe theatre space opening in London made up of a collection of creatives who have come together with an aim of developing quality work without the large overheads artists are usually greeted with.

The development of our space above the White Hart pub in Stoke Newington is underway but we still need help to ensure we have all the capabilities of any other fringe theatre. That is all of our technical set up costs (Lights are bloody expensive) rent and marketing.

Our aim is to nurture and develop all the theatre makers that come through our doors, this will ensure that all these artist are financially benefited from being a part of N16.

For more information and to see our full program go to www.theatren16.co.uk

story:
Shay Ishii Dance Company (SIDC) is a modern dance company based in Austin, Texas.  This season SIDC is presenting Dancestry, a celebration of artistic heritage and revival of historic dance. Dancestry showcases masterworks of modern dance pioneers, Loïe Fuller, Isadora Duncan, and Erick Hawkins. The program culminates with new works by the collaborating artists who have studied and embodied the techniques, philosophies and choreography of these dance icons. Dancestry traces dancers and choreographers across generations with a rich historical narrative and a compelling contemporary voice.

*May 22 & 23, 2015 at the Debra & Kevin Rollins Studio  Theatre, Austin, TX

Featured Works:

  • Loïe Fuller: Night, Fire Dance, Lily of the Nile, La Mer
  • Isadora Duncan: Bacchanal, Furies, Chopin Suite
  • Erick Hawkins: Greek Dreams with Flute
  • And new works by Meg Brooker, Katherine Duke and Shay Ishii.

Collaborating Artists include: Meg Brooker (Artistic Director of Thel Dance Theatre), Jessica Lindberg Coxe (Lindberg Slayter Reconstructions), Katherine Duke, (Artistic Director of Erick Hawkins Dance Foundation), Megan Slayter (Lighting Designer and Lindberg Slayter Reconstructions).


Our Budget: 

Income

  • $3200 from the Cultural Arts Division of the City of Austin Economic Development Department
  • $2000 from the Western Michigan University
  • $4680 estimated ticket sales
  • $200 from private donations

$10,080 TOTAL INCOME

Expenses

  • $2525 Theatre Rental
  • $ 300   Costumes
  • $ 500  Licensing Fees for Erick Hawkins’ works
  • $1700  Production Costs: Security and House Manager at Theatre
  • $ 750  Materials for Set Pieces
  • $2000  Lighting Equipment Rental 
  • $1300  Travel (Air Travel and Car Rental)
  • $1000  Printing/Publicity (Programs, Posters, Advertising)

$10,075  TOTAL EXPENSES

We have enough to pay the bills (to cover rent, costumes, lighting equipment, promotion, licensing fees, travel expenses) but we would love to be able to pay all of the dancers and the lead artists. Of course, we will dance for free….not only do we love what we do, we think it is invaluable to keep this work alive-on bodies in studios and on the stage.

SO… the show will go on with any level of funding we receive but these amazing artists should be compensated for their gifts.

Our Goal to Compensate Artists

  • $4000 5 Collaborating Artists ($800 each)

  • $1800  6 Dancers ($300 each)

$5800 TOTAL

*These numbers do not reflect the generous In-Kind support for housing, travel, rehearsal space etc. provided by donors and artists.

For more information on Shay Ishii Dance Company please visit shayishiidanceco.com

story:
Hello friends!

I’m so happy to share the news that Lola Lola Dance Theatre is making a short dance film. And to invite you to become part of our process.

We are creating Distant Anchors in a tight time frame. We began in March, the shoot is late May and post-production is in June. Afterwards, we'll submit to festivals worldwide, and host a private screening in NYC in September. Our brief time frame is an asset for staying focused and motivated, but is challenging when pursuing traditional funding methods like grants. That’s why your support is so essential to realizing this production.


Here’s how your donation will help:

  • $2,800 – Stipends for Performers & Production Team
  • $600 – Set, Costumes, Materials
  • $1,000 – Production Expenses, Equipment Rental
  • $600 –Travel, Catering & Incidentals

Distant Anchors has been an important departure from my text-based and narrative driven way of working. It has been a return to the body, and to letting the movement create the narrative. Though it's challenging to work differently, I am  growing from the experience.

Distant Anchors began percolating in my mind when looking at the beach portraits by photographer Rineke Dijkstra. Her adolescent subjects are  on the verge of transition – toward adulthood and toward movement. The simplicity of their awkward poses against the vast blue-grey beachscapes is striking. In the studio we are exploring embodying her work, which strongly influences the mood of the film.

We are also working with rigor – physiologically a sudden shiver, or the stiffening of joints (as in rigor mortis) as a way to generate movement. Additionally, we are approaching the process in a rigorous manner, meaning pushing our explorations as far as we can and working with great detail.


PERKS!

We want you to know how much your support means to us. Everyone who donates will be thanked on the Lola Lola Dance Theatre website and on Facebook if you use it.

Other perks include sending you a postcard from the shoot, a print of a film still from the finished product, a download of the film, and an invitation for you and a guest to the private screening in September.

You (or your business) can become a sponsor for $500 and we will include your name and logo in the credits of the film. At the $1,000 level you receive a producer credit and a meet & greet with the performers.

We would like to extend an extra special thank you to Mark Gilbert of Mark’s Bookkeeping Services & Nobody’s Perfekt Media for his advance commitment to sponsorship! Your generous support has been a wonderful motivator for this project.

Can’t donate right now? No problem!

  • You can help us by spreading the word about our Indiegogo campaign. You can use the “share” tools to post to social media
  • If you’re near Westport, CT, where the shoot will take place, we welcome volunteers for the set up & take down of the set, or help with catering for the crew.
  • Do you have a fabulous retro (and maybe striped) bathing suit you don’t wear anymore? Maybe it will work for us as a costume.
  • Do you have experience applying to film festivals you can share with us? Are you great at proofreading?


TEAM:

Jessica Bonenfant, Creative Director: www.lolalola.org

I’ve been the Creative Director of Lola Lola Dance Theatre since 2003. The company creates innovative dance theatre full of striking imagery for traditional and site-specific spaces, as well as film. We have produced six evening-length performances in New York City and numerous shorter works that have been seen across the country. I have participated in artist residencies in the U.S. and France, and have received funding from the National Endowment for the Arts via Chashama’s Windows Project. Distant Anchors is a welcome next step in the company’s trajectory.

I invite you to learn more about my fabulous collaborators: 

Kate Louise Peterson, Cinematographer: www.katelouisepeterson.com

Tara Sheena, Performer: http://tarasheena.wordpress.com

Nola Smith, Performer: www.nolasmith.com

Charly Wenzel, Performer: http://charly-wenzel.com

William Stanton, Sound Design: www.williamyorkstanton.com

Liz Stanton, Vocalist: www.lizstanton.com

We are still seeking a set designer and an editor. If you think that might be you, email Jessica at heylolalola@gmail.com


THANK YOU for taking the time to hear about our project! We look forward to updating you on our progress and showing off the final product to our community.

Love,

Jessica & the Distant Anchors Team
story_txt:
Hello friends! 
I’m so happy to share the news that
Lola Lola Dance Theatre is making a short dance film. And to invite you to
become part of our process. 
We are creating Distant Anchors in a tight time frame. We began in March,
the shoot is late May and post-production is in June. Afterwards, we'll
submit to festivals worldwide, and host a private screening in NYC
in September. Our brief time frame is an asset for staying focused and motivated,
but is challenging when pursuing traditional funding methods like grants.
That’s why your support is so essential to realizing this production. 
Here’s how your donation will help:

$2,800 – Stipends for Performers &
Production Team
$600 – Set, Costumes, Materials
$1,000 – Production Expenses, Equipment
Rental
$600 –Travel, Catering &
Incidentals

Distant
Anchors has been an important departure from my text-based and narrative driven way of working. It has been a return to the body, and to letting
the movement create the narrative. Though it's challenging to work differently, I am  growing from the experience. 
Distant
Anchors began percolating in my mind when looking at the beach
portraits by photographer Rineke Dijkstra. Her adolescent subjects are  on the
verge of transition – toward adulthood and toward movement. The simplicity of
their awkward poses against the vast blue-grey beachscapes is striking. In the
studio we are exploring embodying her work, which strongly influences the mood
of the film. 
We are also working with rigor –
physiologically a sudden shiver, or the stiffening of joints (as in rigor
mortis) as a way to generate movement. Additionally, we are approaching the
process in a rigorous manner, meaning pushing our explorations as far as we can
and working with great detail. 
PERKS!We want you to know how much your
support means to us. Everyone who donates will be thanked on the Lola Lola
Dance Theatre website and on Facebook if you use it. 
Other perks include sending you a
postcard from the shoot, a print of a film still from the finished product, a
download of the film, and an invitation for you and a guest to the private
screening in September. 
You (or your business) can become a
sponsor for $500 and we will include your name and logo in the credits of the
film. At the $1,000 level you receive a producer credit and a meet & greet
with the performers. 
We
would like to extend an extra special thank you to Mark Gilbert of Mark’s
Bookkeeping Services & Nobody’s Perfekt Media for his advance commitment to
sponsorship! Your generous support has been a wonderful motivator for this
project. 
Can’t
donate right now? No problem! 


You
can help us by spreading the word about our Indiegogo campaign. You can use the
“share” tools to post to social media 

If
you’re near Westport, CT, where the shoot will take place, we welcome
volunteers for the set up & take down of the set, or help with catering for
the crew. 

Do
you have a fabulous retro (and maybe striped) bathing suit you don’t wear
anymore? Maybe it will work for us as a costume.

Do
you have experience applying to film festivals you can share with us? Are you
great at proofreading?

Jessica

Project. Distant Anchors is a welcome
next step in the company’s trajectory. 
I invite you to learn more about my
fabulous collaborators:  
Kate
Louise Peterson, Cinematographer: www.katelouisepeterson.com
Tara
Sheena, Performer: http://tarasheena.wordpress.com
Nola
Smith, Performer: www.nolasmith.com
Charly
Wenzel, Performer: http://charly-wenzel.com
William
Stanton, Sound Design: www.williamyorkstanton.com
Liz
Stanton, Vocalist: www.lizstanton.com
We are still seeking a set designer and
an editor. If you think that might be you, email Jessica at heylolalola@gmail.com

YOU for taking the time to hear about our project! We look
forward to updating you on our progress and showing off the final product to
our community.

story:
What's Going On Here?

What Do Critics Know? is a hilarious, original new musical with a golden age, ear-catching score. The show takes place in 1957 and is about a struggling Broadway playwright named Nathan Wood, who is constantly having his shows taken off Broadway because of - you guessed it - scathing critical reviews. But in a strange turn of fate, the three most powerful theater critics must put on a new musical that has to get good reviews. 

The show will be performed July 23-27 at the glamorous Alice Griffin Jewel Box Theatre at Signature on 480 W. 42nd Street, New York, NY   (see Gallery for pics!) 

We are Matt Gurren (Book, Music and Lyrics) and James Campodonico (Music and Lyrics) - the writing team behind What Do Critics Know? Jim and I aren't exactly contemporaries - we have a couple generations between us - but we average out at about 50. All the same, we are kindred spirits who have put nothing but our love and passion for musical theater into this show. Jim's had an extensive career in musical theater studying at the prestigious BMI Workshop and had classmates that included Alan Menken (Beauty and the Beast, Aladdin), Ed Kleban (A Chorus Line), Maury Yeston (Nine). His shows have been presented at Goodspeed, the O'Neill, Luna Stage, York Theatre and many more notable venues. Matt's a playwright with presented works that include "Appraiser's Desk", "Mrs., Widow", and musicals "No Lover's Fool" and "Last Dance" and is a member of the Dramatists Guild. 

After having a hit staged reading of What Do Critics Know? at off-Broadway's York Theatre Company in November with a stellar, Broadway cast, our show was selected out of hundreds of applicants to be one of ten shows presented as part of the New York Musical Theatre Festival's Next Link Project. This is an amazing opportunity for new writers and their works, giving them exposure to a wider audience and ensuring next steps in the show's development. Many NYMF shows have gone on to Broadway and Off-Broadway (Next To Normal, Chaplin, [Title Of Show], Altar Boyz, Yank! - to name a few) and have won Tony Awards, Drama Desks and the Pulitzer Prize for Drama. With your help, our show could be next!

What We Need and What You'll Get 

While NYMF has provided our Next Link Show with a subsidized production slot (they think it's worth investing in!), a majority of the funding still falls on us writers. With a fully staged show that is a period piece and has a cast of 13 and a 7-piece orchestra  - our current budget stands at $62,000. We aren't going to make back a fraction of those expenses from ticket sales, so we depend on contributions from individuals like you to cover:

  • Technical Equipment (mics, lighting, sound)
  • Costumes, props, set
  • Rehearsal Room Rental 
  • Actors, Designers and Musicians 

In return for your donations, there are a bunch of cool perks ranging from social media shout-outs, signed demo CDs, personalized songs to show tickets, invites to VIP events, backstage access and producer status! 

What Your Donations Pay For

Your donations to this campaign will be used and make a huge difference. Here are ways your contributions can help: 

  • $25 pays for an hour of rehearsal
  • $100 pays for an actor's wardrobe
  • $250 pays for one of our run-crew members 
  • $500 pays for a musician
  • $1000 pays for an actor 
  • $2500 pays for our technical equipment 
  • $5000 pays for our venue 

The Impact

It's an increasing concern that there are fewer original musicals getting exposure from established theaters. We now live in a world of adaptations, jukebox musicals and revivals. The new shows that do ultimately make it to the Great White Way take a tremendous amount of time, effort, courage and support. What Do Critics Know? has everything you could want in a musical: a fun, original story, memorable characters, melodic music and  a heartfelt message. Critics are everywhere - be they peers, friends, relatives - and don't forget the notorious inner critic. This is a show about risk, following your dreams and fulfilling your potential no matter what critics might say.  

So if you love musicals and want to see something brand new, then please join us on our journey and help make our dream of What Do Critics Know? a reality. 

Other Ways You Can Help

It's not the size of your wallet, it's the size of your heart. Some people just can't contribute financially, and we won't criticize you for that! There are still ways you can help:

  • Spread the word about our show to friends and family and send them to our website www.whatdocriticsknow.com to learn more and hear our music
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to increase awareness of our project on your social network! 
  • Like us on Facebook and invite your friends
  • Come see the show in July! (Performances are July 23-27th - VISIT http://www.nymf.org/festival/2015-events/what-d... for details)

story:
NOTE: ALL DONATIONS ARE TAX DEDUCTIBLE!


It All Starts When Our Heroes Die

Hello! We are the Rogue and Peasant Players. We are a theatre company that believes in honoring the playwright's intent. We are led by:

  • Malka Wallick- A RADA and Sarah Lawrence trained Shakespearean actress and scholar Malka has text based tattoos that make her resemble a Shakespearean version of Memento.
  • Kelly Monroe Johnston- The former artistic director of the Arizona Shakespeare Festival and a stage director with over two decades of experience, Kelly is clearly on close terms with Billy Shakes.
  • Tim Dowd- A Shakespeare and Company trained actor and writer and improv fiend, Tim prefers to spend his time playing with swords. (We mean rapiers, you pervs.)

We at the RPP believe in producing the works of William Shakespeare as well as new and emerging playwright's who have been inspired by his words. We just want to tell you a good story...

                        R+J

                                                      a new play by Erin Breznitsky

                                                  directed by Kelly Monroe Johnston

                                                                  May 22-24, 2015

                                    Theater Lab, 357 west 36th st, 3rd fl New York, NY

When two suicidal young lovers find themselves thrust together in the afterlife, they think they've finally reached "happily ever after." But before they can transform their monumental passion into a love that can stand the test of time, the couple must reconcile the echoes of past mistakes that return to haunt them. Simultaneously humorous and heartbreaking, R+J tells a tale of love, loss, youth, and innocence through a contemporary exploration of one of the most infamous romances of all time.

Erin Breznitsky has written a spectacular new sequel to Romeo and Juliet and we are honored to be able to share it with the world. We are currently producing this one weekend workshop production with an eye toward finding corporate underwriters and larger theatre companies who may help us produce the play on a larger scale at a later date this fall. 

But to do that we need your help...

"One for one, that's called compromise"

We are fortunate enough to have secured free rehearsal space in Brooklyn and Queens, which will help to keep our costs low, however, we still have some other costs to cover:

  • 1350 in location rental
  • 800 in designer costs
  • 300 in other various costs
  • 800 for actors
  • 100 for marketing
  • 200 for costumes
  • 200 for set pieces

Although, this seems like a large amount, it is in fact, on the low end of cost for producing work in NYC. Now that we've told you what we need, we get to tell you what you receive in !

  • Signed cast photo
  • Make one of the artistic directors sing whatever you want wearing whatever you want.
  • Become the guest director on an episode of the Rogue and Peasant Podcast
  • Get your own personalized sonnet
  • Impress the shit out your lady friend with our specialized Sonnetgrams
  • A free actors reel edit courtesy of For Real Reelz.
  • And tons more!

"We could...talk?"

R+J explores the very nature of love and relationships, forcing us to re-examine our preconceived notions and expectations. The vitality of the every day relationship, with all of its bumps and banality is no less beautiful than the surging passions of a new-found love. It all depends on your perspective. 

The Rogue and Peasant Players are particularly well suited to share this story with you as they have a combined sixty years of experience in the theatre, an experience which is a love affair of sorts. We have played the Romeos and Juliets and are ready to explore these new characters and relationships.

Risks & Challenges

We face two large challenges moving forward: fundraising and reaching our target audiences.

In terms of fundraising, I think our strategy is fairly obvious. The other more pressing challenge is reaching our target audience.

In order to reach the typical Shakespeare loving, theatre-goer we are utilizing he typical social media outlets, with experts managing the content. We are using paper mediums as well, such as postcards and for some pint sized fun, business cards. 

As we mentioned earlier we are also targeting potential corporate underwriters as well as other big theaters to help us produce R+J on a much larger scale in the future. 

We have compiled a list of over 100 local businesses, some of which we have worked with on previous projects, and are inviting representatives to come and see the show.  Contacting them proves a greater challenge.

...  But You Can Help

First of all any donation, no matter how small, really does help. Not only do we get the funds you've contributed but your donation helps to validate our campaign and encourages others to donate. 

Beyond that you can help us get the word out. We live in an internet age, and by sharing our campaign on facebook, twitter, reddit, instagram or what have you, you can help bring in more people, more donations and more brand ambassadors to help you spread the word. 

In addition to our endless gratification  (and the very nice tax deduction) you will be able to earn perks... Want to earn yourself a couple of free tickets, spread the word and help us raise the funds and you'll be there.

Thank you all for reading this far down. You have an attention span far beyond that of mortal men. Thank you, for your attention, your contributions and your patronage and as always...

Go fuck with some text

-The Rogue and Peasant Players.

We live in an internet age, and by sharing our campaign on facebook, twitter, reddit, instagram or what have you, you can help bring in more people, more donations and more brand ambassadors to help you spread the word. In addition to our endless gratification  (and the very nice tax deduction) you will be able to earn perks... story:
Our bodies are 75% water.

This dance work asks - What would happen if we moved like the liquid we are?  The dancers of Antonia & Artists are taking a journey through the depths within to harness the fluidity, agility and transformative strength of the most powerful element.


The show - 2015 Philly Fringe Festival

8pm Shows September, 5th (Sat), 6th (Sun), 11th (Fri) and 12th (Sat)

at the Community Education Center, Meetinghouse Theater (West Philadelphia)

There will be a special preview of the show in Scratch Night at FringeArts on August 10th. More info to come!


We need your help to make it happen!

Making this work takes time, heart... and yes, some cash. We hope you'll support the project by making a contribution.

Does this cover the cost of the show?

Not even close! This fundraiser will take us that last leap to producing the show, but we will also need corporate sponsorship, volunteers and ticket sales to cover expenses. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Sign up to volunteer (putting up posters, ushering, etc)
  • Spread the word about the show and share our video!

Thank you, thank you

Many artists have contributed their work to this project already, and more will soon!

First, thank you to dancers and performers Sean Thomas Boyt, Kat J. Sullivan, Leanne Grieger and Hillary Pearson who are the life of this piece! These artists are incredible collaborators and I am lucky to get to work with them.

Thank you to Hilary Brashear for doing an amazing job with this video, Kaitlin Chow for fabulous photos, and Meredith Stapleton for being a comrade and dramaturg for the piece. (You can check out all of these folk's work by clicking the links!)

Thank you also to Ann-Marie Gover and Grace Stern for being in-process collaborators!


Sincerely,

Antonia Z Brown

story: I am Jillian.  I am sixteen years old and I have been dancing since I was 3 years old.  I am a student at the Joffrey Ballet's Jazz and Contemporary Program in New York City.  Since I was a little girl, it has been my dream to be a dancer in New York City.  I have been attending Joffrey's program since September of 2014 and feel extremely blessed to have the opportunity and support to complete the first year of four for training.  I am looking for support in the way of funding and prayers.  Your consideration is greatly appreciated.  I am very thankful for the opportunity to share my adventure as I pursue my dream!
