story:
The Mission
Hubbard Street Dance Chicago’s core purpose brings artists, art and audiences together to enrich, engage, and change lives through the experience of dance. Following the success of its first production for young people and families — based on Crockett Johnson’s beloved children’s book Harold and the Purple Crayon — Hubbard Street embarks on an entirely new adventure this fall.

The Adventure
Work is currently underway toward the world premiere of an exciting, original work for children and families: Mariko’s Magical Mix: A Dance Adventure, choreographed by Robyn Mineko Williams for Hubbard Street 2, in collaboration with the shadow puppeteers at Manual Cinema. This innovative, multimedia production shares the story of a young girl and her magical journey through the world of music.

Three-time Princess Grace awardee Robyn Mineko Williams and HS2 Director Terence Marling are delighted to join forces once again, harnessing the power of music and dance, to ignite the imaginations of young viewers. This ingenious work is being designed for maximum accessibility to audiences ages 5 and up, while displaying the high caliber of contemporary performance for which Hubbard Street is known worldwide. Using the universal languages of movement and sound, Mariko’s Magical Mix celebrates how art creates and strengthens bonds among people of diverse cultural backgrounds.

The Need
Hubbard Street Dance Chicago needs $10,000 to bring this magical live production to children of all ages, both near and far, beginning with a world premiere at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts Friday, October 2, 2015-Sunday, October 11, 2015, followed by a Chicago premiere in 2016.

Help Us Make Magic
Your support is vital in helping us bring Mariko’s adventure to life, through building costumes and scenery, and commissioning and completing its memorable score. Every donation brings this performance closer to families across the country.

Above: Costume design rendering by Branimira Ivanova for “Little Brother / Little Friend” in Mariko’s Magical Mix: A Dance Adventure.

Grant a child the opportunity to explore the world of dance alongside Mariko, and choose from the many great benefits — listed to the right — that we’ve provided in special thanks for your generous support.

Thank you to the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts for its commissioning support, to the Charles and Joan Gross Family Foundation for commissioning original music for the work, and to the Princess Grace Foundation–USA and R. Penny Rodes DeMott for providing additional support.

The Story
It’s the not too-distant future, and the tedium of everyday life is making Mariko restless — until the day she discovers a crate in her attic, filled with vinyl records that her mother collected. Armed only with headphones, our young hero is transported to a world of music and shadow, where she makes friends, builds impossible machines, escapes entrapment, and slays her own demons.

The Impact
With this project, Hubbard Street seeks to engage perhaps the most important dance audience: children, who are the future audiences for and artists of contemporary dance. Engaging children with the art of dance has been a priority of Hubbard Street for the past 17 years, and we view it as vital to the continued advancement and survival of this art form.

Robyn Mineko Williams is eager to present a work for this special audience that attempts to address what children really experience — their desires for independence and discovery which are, at the same time, accompanied by a yearning for the comforts of home.

Among this work’s unique elements are: 

• its narrative choreography, which helps to draw children into the performance;

• its short choreographic segments, lasting five minutes or less, which keep children engaged throughout the work;

• the use of shadow puppets to create images with which children can connect;

• its themes of diversity and inclusion;

• and interactive components that give children a chance to respond to what they are seeing on stage, and play a role in the choices the characters make.

Mariko’s Magical Mix will be offered at affordable ticket prices for family audiences at venues throughout the country, as well as for student groups who will experience the production free of charge.

Continuing a Manual Cinema tradition, audience members will be invited onstage following each performance to explore how the images were made in real-time, using shadow puppets. This will give children and parents the opportunity to observe what it takes “behind the scenes” to bring a dance production to life, as well as a chance to meet the artists and ask them questions.

How Else Can I Help Mariko?
Make some noise! Help us get the word out about this unique project by sharing this story with your friends and family through social media, using the hashtag #MarikosMagicalMix and mentioning @HubbardStreet and @ManualCinema.

story:
OUR STORY

My name is Nafeesa Monroe and I'm the founder and artistic director of Classics in Color: A Theatre Company.

Nafeesa Monroe

Our mission is about inclusivity, not just on stage but off, in ethnicity, in gender, in physical able-ness.... We want the world to see themselves in our productions of classic and classical works. 

             


We're raising $20,000 to produce our very first co-production this fall. For its inaugural season, Classics in Color has joined forces with the wonderful Quick Silver Theater Company for a mutual inaugural co-production of a contemporary American classic: the Pulitzer Prize winning "Proof," by David Auburn. Our co-producer, Quick Silver Theater Company, is aligned with us in our desire to better reflect our world on stage. As such, we decided to work together to professionally produce Proof in New York City this fall, in September of 2015.

Doing this is no small feat, and that's why we need YOU. You can help fund this vision from the ground up. You can be a collaborator in making this dream a tangible reality!

We made a conscious choice to cast all actors of color in these roles. We are excited to present this work that speaks of and to highly intelligent women. We have put together a fantastically talented cast and an equally talented team of ALL female designers led by none other than the Tony nominated actress, Johanna Day, making her directorial debut. 

                          

Tony Nominated Actress Johanna Day

Your tax-deductible donation will be used to fund the many facets of this production, the theatre, the set, the lights, and making sure our cast and our designers are compensated for their time and talent.

Classics in Color is a professional theatre company founded on nothing less than excellence. We look forward to your collaboration in this excellence and building a relationship with you, a true supporter of the arts.

WHERE THE FUNDS GO

  • Rights to produce the play
  • Rehearsal space rental for 3 weeks in August
  • Theatre space rental for 2 weeks in September
  • Set building (including lumber costs, carpenter, shop to build)
  • Costume building/purchase
  • Props building/purchase
  • Insurance
  • Director
  • Designers (including Set, Lights, & Sound)
  • Stage manager 
  • Crew (including lights & sound)
  • Actors
  • Graphic Designer
  • Printing of posters, postcards, & programs
  • Transportation of set, costumes, props
  • Any additional funds remaining will stay in Classics in Color's account and go towards future productions, including our next two projects in 2016, one reading in DC and one reading in NY. 

FLEXIBLE FUNDING INFO
The beauty of flexible funding is that if we don't reach our goal, we will still receive the funds present. All perks will still be delivered as well.

story:
Short Summary

Hi there,

The non-profit Yggdrasil Larp gathers young people and adults twice yearly to explore the literary world of Harry Potter and to problematize and illustrate the issues with racism, sexism and structural injustices one can encounter in everyday life. 

Choosing to do so in an alternate reality offers our participants the opportunity to explore and scrutinize important social issues in a safe and comfortable setting. 

We are campaigning for funds to be able to lower the participation fees of this event, particularly due to the fact that we have many underage participants, for which a high participation fee might prove an issue. 


What We Need & What You Get

Honestly? We need as much funding as possible and every single dime will go to our participants and to keeping the larp campaign going. We've set the bar fairly high, and regardless of how much money we actually manage to get, it'll go straight to creating a better (and cheaper) experience for our participants. 

Most of the perks we'll be offering are location specific (Sweden), but not all, so please feel free to check them out!


The Impact

We want to create a space which welcomes everyone who loves the Harry Potter-stories, regardless of age, race, disability and gender. Too few activities actually manage to be as inclusive as larp is, and lower fees will open the event for even more participants, again, regardless of situation and personal obstacles. 

The non-profit organization of Yggdrasil lajv has successfully arranged several of these events before, but funding is becoming more and more of an issue. That is why we're reaching out to the community at large for help. 


Risks & Challenges

Yggdrasil larp has become a popular meeting point for many in the Swedish Harry Potter community. If we fail to gather the necessary funds to lower our fees, it might have to be cancelled all together, robbing us of the possibility to further explore our mutual hobby.

IndieGogo is not the only channel from which we're trying to gather funds. Most of our activites are handled by people who volunteer both their time, efforts and money, and we'd very much like to ease their burden a little. Should this campaign fail, we'll try our hardest to raise the money elsewhere.  


Other Ways You Can Help

If you'd like to share this campaign, we'll be thrilled. You hear that? Super thrilled!

story:
Tandav has been invited to perform at India's "Avignon Festival"-the Delhi International Arts Festival, the ONLY company representing FRANCE in India in this year's edition. After multiple trips to  India, auditions, endless phone calls, tedious paperwork, trips to the embassy and visa offices, NOW, ITS HAPPENING! We are ready to GO!

It's been because of everyone's support  and constant encouragement in the last two years that we have taken on such an ambitious goal- TO GO TO INDIA! It has been a dream for two years!

We can do it BUT we need your help! 

Furthermore, the group will undertake a research and creation residency in the village of India- working on a new piece, planned to tour in 2016. 

To perform in Delhi and undertake the residency, we want your support! We dont have a lot of time  and need the financial help to present a beautiful show and if possible, live well too.

To do what we love takes a lot BUT we are stubborn artists. We know there is a lot of love in the world and we will take all we can take and hold in our hearts.

What your support means to us?

Everything!

Your help and support would mean that we  will actually have a better place to sleep, sufficient food to eat, rehearse in an okay space and undertake the one-month residency after the performance.

Without your support, we will be under a lot of financial pressure.

Here is where your money will go:

Accommodation (in Delhi and Auroville): 210 Euros

Travel: 500 Euros for three actors from France and Norway (we are paying half our fares!)

Rehearsal space (in Delhi and Auroville): 100 Euros

Food (total food cost in India for the 1.5 months!): 190 Euros

We have raised 1200 Euros (through sponsorships from embassies and private companies, self-funding and in-kind support!)

If we don't reach the goal we will still get the amount that has been donated, so partial win, we would have something...)

Risks and Challenges

We are performing in exactly 28 days before the premier work of our company! Wohoo with a one-week rehearsal before the show!

If you cannot help with money, send us your love and stay connected with us on our Indian adventure. Share the word. 

The Company

TANDAV is an international physical theatre company based in Paris, newly established in 2014.  The company is made up of 7 actors, directors and dancers.

The company's work is about taking risks, aesthetically and physically. It attempts to break down barriers between dance and theatre, and above all, the relationship between performers and the audience. 

It has been almost two years that we have bee training together, asking questions, constantly changing and shifting focuses while remaining focused on being in service to experimentation.

This is our opportunity to start in a place known to break and transform people. This is where we have dreamed to start and we hope this will result in multiple new projects in the future.


Lots of love,

Jay, Sunniva, Clara and Yearime (the "touring" team)

story:
Once Upon a Time...

There was a 17th Century theatre called Smock Alley Theatre. Despite being old and excellently preserved, the team of (not-quite-so-old) troopers within the building decided that the people needed to see new art AND that support needed to be given to Artist's to show their brilliant ideas. And so, Smock Allies : Scene + Heard was born.

Smock Allies : Scene + Heard is a festival of new work across MUSIC - DANCE THEATRE - COMEDY + SPOKEN WORD arts genres. It provides a chance for artists to test an excerpt of previously unseen work or new ideas / formats in front of a live audience in order to get feedback before mounting and staging full length productions. 

Are you a Beautiful Believer, a Festival Überfrau or an Artist's Ally?

Smock Allies : Scene + Heard is platform for work that is in development. We provide a safe environment with feedback and encouragement to support Artists to make new work within the Arts,  but we will need your help!

Would you a Cocktail named after you? Or an invites to a sexy party? How's about Theatre Tickets? A Banquet? or your own private cinema? 

Of course you would! Super! Because we need to cover the costs of essentials like  Printed Programmes, Projectors, A Dance Floor, Additional Rehearsal Space for the Companies, Technical Support and Operators!

Your support will help the Artists to present their exciting new ideas.

The Impact

We believe in breaking down barriers to showcase work that is accessible to all, across a variety of disciplines. 

Our team has gathered years of collective experience producing festivals, theatre, tv + film, design, architecture, photography, music, marketing, comedy and dance as well as the technical expertise which we want to share with Artists to help their work find its way.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to get a PERK today, perhaps you can help spread the word and encourage those who can share their generosity...

  • Use this link to let people know of our campaign

  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
TEATRO DEI CONCIATORI - ROMA

Dal 23 al 28 Febbraio 2016

ASPETTANDO GODOT

Di

Samuel Beckett

Regia

di

Alessandro Averone

con

Marco Quaglia

Gabriele Sabatini

Mauro Santopietro

Antonio Tintis


Scene Alberto Favretto

Costumi Marzia Paparini

Luci Luca Bronzo

Foto di scena Manuela Giusto

Ufficio Stampa Maya Amenduni

Web assistant Martina Mecacci


In questi tempi di crisi e violenza, due motivazioni che inducono la gente a rinchiudersi a casa aspettando che passi (o che arrivi un improbabile salvatore a liberarci dall'angoscia), la Sycamore T Company ha deciso, comunque, di credere in un gruppo di giovani artisti e di aiutarli a realizzare i loro progetti.

 Senza fondi statali, nè comunali, nè regionali, credendoci e basta. 

Credendo soprattutto che la passione e il talento possano bastare a ridare una spinta efficace al pubblico teatrale, specialmente giovanile, nel suo riappropriarsi di un tempo e di uno spazio non solo di divertimento ma anche di emozione e catarsi. 

Con il supporto di uno dei teatri "nuovi" di Roma, coraggioso e sperimentale, il Teatro dei Conciatori, e con l'aiuto di un cast artistico e tecnico di prim'ordine, Aspettando Godot andrà in scena a fine febbraio 2016, contando esclusivamente su fondi privati. 

Per questo chiediamo il vostro aiuto, nel sostenerci in questa impresa al limite del donchisciottesco ma che ha senso proprio perchè, in questo tempo oscuro, solo stringendosi tutti e resistendo insieme si può continuare ad aspettare  - e vincere la paura, a dispetto di tutto, di noi stessi per primi.


"Quello che mi ha sempre affascinato in Beckett è la sottile e fine poesia che scaturisce dai suoi testi. L’amore e la compassione per l’essere umano costretto disperatamente alla ricerca di un senso. 

Il vagare su questa terra in perenne attesa di un gesto, di una parola che si faccia Verbo e indichi una via, una meta per colmare il mistero dell’essere qui e ora.

Nessun Dio. Nessuna metafisica.

Si aspetta. Qualcosa di indefito e sconosciuto.

Si fa passare il tempo e si riempie uno spazio.

Ci si aggrappa perdutamente a qualsiasi cosa ci ricordi che esistiamo e che siamo vivi.

Si gioca, con quello che resta. Del mondo, dell’essere umano, delle parole.

Si resiste. Con affetto e violenza. Con quello che si è. Con tutti i nostri limiti. Stretti l’un l’altro. Aspettando Godot " (Note di regia - Alessandro Averone)

artistico e tecnico di prim'ordine, Aspettando Godot andrà in scena a 
fine febbraio 2016, contando esclusivamente su fondi privati. 
Per questo chiediamo il vostro aiuto, nel sostenerci in questa 
impresa al limite del donchisciottesco ma che ha senso proprio perchè, 
in questo tempo oscuro, solo stringendosi tutti e resistendo insieme si 
può continuare ad aspettare  - e vincere la paura, a dispetto di tutto, 
di noi stessi per primi.

"Quello che mi ha sempre affascinato in Beckett è la sottile
e fine poesia che scaturisce dai suoi testi. L’amore e la compassione per l’essere umano costretto
disperatamente alla ricerca di un senso. 

Il vagare su questa terra in perenne attesa di un gesto, di
una parola che si faccia Verbo e indichi una via, una meta per colmare il
mistero dell’essere qui e ora.

Nessun Dio. Nessuna metafisica.

Si aspetta. Qualcosa di indefito e sconosciuto.

Si fa passare il
tempo e si riempie uno spazio. 

Ci si aggrappa perdutamente a qualsiasi cosa ci ricordi che
esistiamo e che siamo vivi.

Si gioca, con quello che resta. Del mondo, dell’essere
umano, delle parole. 

Si resiste. Con affetto e violenza. Con quello che si è. Con
tutti i nostri limiti. Stretti l’un l’altro. Aspettando Godot " (Note di regia - Alessandro Averone)

story:
Λούλα

του Βαγγέλη Ραπτόπουλου

Το μυθιστόρημα που σόκαρε, δίχασε και ενθουσίασε, για πρώτη φορά στο θέατρο.

Προσπαθώντας να φτάσει πάση θυσία στο αποκορύφωμα της ηδονής, μια όμορφη φοιτήτρια της Φιλοσοφικής Αθηνών έρχεται αντιμέτωπη με την εφιαλτική όψη της λαγνείας.

Μια παράσταση για τον γυναικείο οργασμό και την απουσία του. Για τη χρήση ινδικής κάνναβης. Για σεξουαλικές διαστροφές. Για τη λαγνεία ως εφιάλτη της Aνατολής. Για βρικόλακες στην Aχαΐα του προηγούμενου αιώνα. Για κόσμους άλλων διαστάσεων στη σύγχρονη Aθήνα. Kαι για τον κόσμο των ψυχώσεων.

Μια πολιτική πορνογραφία.

Ο αυτιστικός κόσμος της Λούλας. Η Λούλα ως σύμβολο μιας ολόκληρης γενιάς που πάλεψε να ενηλικιωθεί στις τοξικές δεκαετίες απο το ’90 και μετά.

Η Λούλα αναζητά απελπισμένα και ασυνείδητα την εκτόνωση του σώματος καθώς δεν μπορεί να συνδεθεί με την πραγματικότητα, την χώρα και την Ιστορία. Η ανοργασμία της την κάνει εμμονική. Προβάλλει σαν αναπηρία και μέγγενη. Πρέπει να φτάσει σε οργασμό για να απελευθερωθεί.

Η συγκάτοικός της, η Εύη, το alter ego της, χωρίς την εκθαμβωτική ομορφιά της Λούλας, κάνει τους άντρες να τρέχουν από πίσω της γιατί ξέρει να τους ικανοποιεί και να ικανοποιείται. Είναι το αντίθετο της Λούλας, είναι η χυδαία, σαρκαστική και κυνική σύντροφός της. Ένα ντεσαντικό δίδυμο. 

Οι δύο κοπέλες, σε ένα φοιτητικό δωματιό στα Εξάρχεια, με αναμμένη την τηλεόραση και τα γειτονικά μπαλκόνια να ξεφωνίζουν Σφακιανάκη και Γαρμπή, μιλούν για το σεξ όπως το διαβάζουν στα περιοδικά του Κωστόπουλου, πηγαίνουν στο Πανεπιστήμιο, αν και ελάχιστα μιλούν για αυτό, φαντασιώνονται τους γυμναστές των πρωινάδικων μέχρι που ο Βρικόλακας εισβάλλει και τους συστήνει με έναν περίπατο στα Εξάρχεια μια Αθήνα μεταφυσική, διαβολική, τρομώδη και πανέραστη.

Ο κόσμος της “Λούλας” μέσα από την πορνογραφία, το χιούμορ, το noir και το θρίλερ, αποκαλύπτεται ως μελέτη μιας γενιάς, της γενιάς μας, που αναγνωρίζει και παλεύει με τον αυτισμό της προκειμένου να φτάσει στην ενηλικίωσή της.

Η παράσταση είναι αυστηρά ακατάλληλη για ανηλίκους.

Το μυθιστόρημα του Βαγγέλη Ραπτόπουλου “Λούλα” κυκλοφορεί από τις Εκδόσεις Καστανιώτη.

Δραματουργική επεξεργασία / Σκηνοθεσία : Δημήτρης Αγαρτζίδης, Δέσποινα Αναστάσογλου
Μουσική: costinho (Κωστής Ζουλιάτης)
Σκηνικός χώρος – Κοστούμια: Μαγδαληνή Αυγερινού
Φωτισμοί/ Φωτογραφίες : Karol Jarek
Βίντεο : Μικαέλα Λιακατά, Ιάσων Αρβανιτάκης
Κίνηση : Αλεξάνδρα Καζάζου
Κατασκευές/ Γλυπτά : Ιωάννα Πλέσσα

Παίζουν: Ανθή Ευστρατιάδου, Βίκυ Κατσίκα

Στη φωνή του Στέλιου ακούγεται ο Πέτρος Μάλαμας

Η Βοήθειά σας

Μέσα στη νέα πραγματικότητα που έχει διαμορφωθεί τα τελευταία χρόνια το θέατρο προσαρμόζεται προκειμένου να συνεχίσει να παράγει έργο, χωρίς την κρατική υποστήριξη.Οι θεατρικοί οργανισμοί αυτοδιαχειρίζονται και διαμορφώνεται μια νέα κατάσταση που μας εισάγει σε μια νέα εποχή, στην οποία η ιδιωτική συνεισφορά αποτελεί ζωτική ανάγκη. Γνωρίζοντας την οικονομική δυσκολία στην οποία όλοι έχουμε περιέλθει, ζητάμε τη βοήθεια σας.

Τα χρήματα πρόκειται να διατεθούν προκειμένου να καλυφθεί ο υλικός εξοπλισμός της παράστασης και αμοιβές συντελεστών: Σκηνικά, κοστούμια, ηχογράφηση μουσικής, αμοιβές μουσικών, αμοιβές ηθοποιών κατά τη διάρκεια των προβών.

Οποιαδήποτε βοήθεια, οικονομική ή μια κοινοποίηση του συνδέσμου μας είναι πολύτιμη!

story:
LEFT at the Emerge Festival

Neus Gil Cortés has been creating work for several years alongside a successful dance career.  Having danced with numerous choreographers, she is now developing her own artistic style and a repertoire that can be performed at festivals and in venues around the world. 

I believe in exploring our social contexts and the reality we are involved in as artists. I often wonder why contemporary dance is a minority artform when its source (the body) is the most natural and knowledgeable of tools. I believe dance artists too often make little effort to allow their work to be understood and that we as dance artists have a shared responsibility to address that. This is not about underestimating the intelligence of the audience, but about offering a context so that people are in the right disposition to perceive or feel what is trying to be communicated.

Neus has been invited to present a new work, Left, at C-12 Dance Company's Emerge Festival in November 2015, alongside new works by Co_Motion Dance, Tamsin Griffiths, Gemma Prangle, and What Is Written Dance Company.

Left explores self-judgement, self-deprecation, and self-doubt: the feeling of being inadequate, and the fear that we are not good enough, smart enough, or interesting enough.  Left is a reflection on the power of the psyche to both effect and affect human nature. 


Why are we fundraising?

We are committed to recognition of the value of professional artists by the awarding of proper and fair payment.

We will be working full-time for three weeks creating Left with two professional dancers, and performing every night for a week. 

We have a designer, who will want to costume the dancers.

Reaching our target of £2,500 will allow us to pay these people. 


What's in it for you?

There's a feeling you get when you've helped realise someone's dream. We'll promise you that.  We'll also thank ever donor individually across all of our social media.  Top-level supporters will also become acknowledged Patrons of Left, and get tickets to the show! 

Your support - whether it's £5 or £100 - will make an enormous difference to what we're able to do.  You'll be  supporting the creation of a new work, as well as helping Neus to grow her repertoire and her business as a choreographer.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute to this campaign, you can still help us by sharing it with people that you think might be interested - there are some sharing tools on this page.

story:
Heathers The Musical - it will be Very

HEATHERS THE MUSICAL is the darkly delicious story of Veronica Sawyer, a brainy, beautiful teenage misfit who hustles her way into the most powerful and ruthless clique at Westerberg High: the Heathers. But before she can get comfortable atop the high school food chain, Veronica falls in love with the dangerously sexy new kid J.D. When Heather Chandler, the Almighty, kicks her out of the group, Veronica decides to bite the bullet and kiss Heather’s aerobicized ass… but J.D. has another plan for that bullet.

Brought to you by the award-winning creative team of Kevin Murphy (Reefer Madness, “Desperate Housewives”), Laurence O’Keefe (Bat Boy, Legally Blonde) and Andy Fickman (Reefer Madness, She’s the Man). HEATHERS THE MUSICAL is a hilarious, heartfelt and homicidal new show based on the greatest teen comedy of all time.  

Who we are 

We are "..Gently with a Chainsaw Artists' Collective" - an equity coop with professional artists and up and comers looking to bring this great show to Vancouver for the first time in all of Canada!  

Cast

Christine Quintana - Veronica Sawyer 
Christine is an actor, playwright, and co-Artistic Producer of uber-indie theatre company Delinquent Theatre. As an actor, Christine has played in Saint Joan, She Stoops to Conquer,and the LEAP Reading Series (Arts Club), The Glass Menagerie (Fire Escape Co-op) Mr. Marmalade (Latchkey Co-Op), Of Mice and Men (Hardline Productions), The Wizard of Oz and Seussical (Carousel Theatre), RENT (FCP), and The Madonna Painter and Wild Honey (Theatre at UBC).  Christine’s plays include Selfie (commissioned by Théâtre la Seizième, premiered in March 2015, winner of the Sidney Risk Prize for Outstanding Script by an Emerging Playwright), Our Time, and Stationary: A Recession-Era Musical (toured to Talk is Free Theatre and the Cultch in April 2015, winner of the Jessie Richardson Theatre Award for Outstanding Musical, Small Theatre) for which she also served as producer and performer.  Christine co-created The Story of You and Me with collaborator Scott Button for Hive 3: The New Bees. Christine is Artistic Apprentice with the Electric Company Theatre, Marketing & Operations Coordinator with Neworld Theatre, and the Program Assistant for the LEAP Program at the Arts Club. She holds a BFA in Acting from the University of British Columbia and is dedicated coffee drinker and animal lover.
Kamyr Pazandeh - Jason J.D. Dean
Kamyar is thrilled to be working on such a fun show with a wonderful cast. Credits include 'Jud Fry' in Oklahoma!, 'Tybalt' in Romeo and Juliet (Studio 58), and 'Ernest Simpson', 'Bertie', 'Diamond', and 'Espil' inThe Duchess (Ruby Slippers). He is the recipient of the Leon and Thea Koerner Award in the Fine and Performing Arts as well as the Lloyd Nicholson Memorial Endowed Scholarship. He is currently co-writing and composing a musical that will be presented at Studio 58 in February during FourPlay. Kamyar has been playing piano since he was six and trumpet since he was ten. He began singing bass in the Magee Chamber choir at the age of fifteen in which the group took 2nd place in Canada in the Kiwanis festival. Since then he has sung in numerous groups including The Postmodern Camerata, Vancouver Academy of Music's Opera, and Sonic Boom. Music remains a source of inspiration in his life and work. Look out for him this summer at Bard on the Beach where he will be playing 'Pericles' in Pericles. Kamyar is a graduate of Studio 58. Enjoy the show! 

Synthia Yusuf - Heather Chandler

After taking a couple years off to pursue professional wine-drinking, Synthia is very excited to be back in the play business, and even more excited to be a part of The Heathers cast! She'd like to thank her friends and family for their love and support, and for laughing at her jokes. Favourite credits: Pilar in Legally Blonde: The Musical, and Evelyn in The Girl in the Frame. 
Devon Basswood - Heather McNamara
Devon is thrilled to be having a blonde moment in 'Heathers' alongside this wonderful cast and creative team! Recent credits include: Woman 1 in 'Edges' (Two Monkeys Co-op), Kate / Chutney / Elle U/S in 'Legally Blonde' (TUTS), Betsy Bear in 'Busytown' (Carousel Theatre for Young People), Daisy Hilton in 'Side Show' (Fighting Chance), Kate in 'Zanna, Don't' and Ashley in 'Changing Minds' (Awkward Stage), and Rose Fenny in 'Dogfight' (ArtsWest Playhouse and Gallery in Seattle, WA), for which she was nominated for 'Best Actress in a Musical' by the Gregory Awards and Broadway World. 
Nhi No - Heather Duke

A triple threat performer originally hailing from Victoria, British Columbia, Nhi Do is an actress, producer and director.

Nhi swiftly crossed over from the stage to film and television upon her arrival to Vancouver and soon found herself in a variety of productions including Watchmen, the award-winning Mulligans and Stranger with My Face. Recent projects include the original play, Patch, by NOW! Theatre, Luchagore Production's short, Feliz Cumpleanos (part of the Soska Sister's Women in Horror Massive Blood Drive 2015 PSA), OUTtv's first transgender sitcom, The Switch and Hallmark's The Magic Stocking.

When not acting, Nhi teaches and coaches several students while co-hosting and directing a talk/variety webseries called Dog's Breakfast.

Stephanie Davis - Martha Dunnstock

Over a year ago Steffanie listened to the soundtrack and fell in love with Heathers: a Musical. Steffanie is an alumna of the Capilano University Musical Theatre program and won the 2012 Outstanding Newcomer Ovation award. Credits include: Kris/Speaker in The Best Laid Plans: a Musical, Stella in Darling (Springboard Performance), Enid in Legally Blonde, Charlotte Cardoza in Titanic, Bye Bye Birdie (TUTS), Assassins (Pipedream), Jan in Grease (Footlight Theatre) and Dolly Levi in Hello Dolly (Exit22). 

Ram Sweeney - Colin Sheen

Colin is currently in Cambridge as part of their Anne of Green Gables show.  You may have seen him right here in Vancouver at the Arts Club Production Red Rock Diner.   

Kurt Kelly - Hal Wesley Rogers

Most recently Hal was on stage at the York in the musical Best Laid Plans.  He has studied at Circle in the Square and played Jesus in Fighting Chance's production of Jesus Christ Superstar.  

Ram's Dad/Big Bud Dean/Coach Ripper - Nelson Wong 

New Zealand-born actor, Nelson Wong, was a regular on Here TV's Donald Strachey Mystery Series, playing Kenny Kwon, the detective's trusty sidekick, has appeared in several TV movies including a lead role as Detective Jeff Wong in Lifetime TV's My Silent Partner and as State's Prosecutor Richard Lee on Secret Liaisons (Movie Central), has appeared on such shows as Fringe (FOX), The L Word(Showtime), Psych (USA), and jPod (CBC), and portrayed the twisted Dr. Black in the hit horror feature American Mary (Screamfest’s Best Picture 2012-Twisted Twins Productions).  Currently he can be seen in CBC’s spy drama The Romeo Section.

On stage Nelson has worked closely with playwright C.E. Gatchalian, originating the characterizations of Jeff and Chang Hyun for his world premieres of Broken (2006), and Falling In Time (2011), respectively-now available in book form. He is also a proud member of the improv comic troupe The Bobbers, and the sketch comedy group, Assaulted Fish.

Mr. Fleming/Veronica's Mom - Lori Watt

A Vancouver based actor Lori has been singing, dancing and acting since she was a young girl.  Some of her favourite roles are listed here:

Film:  Rorshach's Mom (Sylvia Kovacs) in The Watchmen, Samantha Garner in Embedded. 

Stage: Lil, in the award winning A Particular Class of Women, Collette in Four Dogs and a Bone, Bo in Criminal Hearts, Angel in Dregs of Society, April Greene in Hot L Baltimore, Friend in Gwynn Hunt's original play Missing and Florence in The Odd Couple (female version), Rocky Horror show with Wicked Awesome Theatre (Ovation Award nominee). 

Kurt's Dad/Veronica's Dad/Principal Gowan - Ken Overbey

Ken is doing double duty on this project and is also our choreographer.  

Bitter Geek - Matt Montgomery

Matt Montgomery is a recent graduate of the Canadian College of Performing Arts in Victoria BC. Born in Edmonton Alberta, Matt  spent his childhood moving around BC until he came to Vancouver to pursue his love for Musical Theatre. He is very excited to be a part of HEATHERS! Some of his recent credits include "Luke" in the Vancouver Fringe production of The OC the Musical, and "Jonathan" in Excavation Theatre's The Old Haunt.

Preppy Stud/Officer Milner/J.D. understudy - Daren Dyhengco

Daren is a recent grad of Capilano University’s Musical Theatre Program. He is very humbled to be given the chance to be the dance captain, an understudy and a swing for this production. Past credits include Albert in The Secret Garden (Exit 22), Ensemble in Hairspray (TUTS) and Brother in The Good Person of Setzuan (Exit 22). He would like to thank the producers, his director, his friends, and as always the never-ending support of his family.

Hipster Dork/Officer McCord - Brent Hirose

Brent Hirose is an actor, writer, improviser, director and voice over artist based in Vancouver, BC. A graduate of the University of Winnipeg Film and Theatre program, he spent the first decade of his career in the prairies where he co-founded the indie theatre company Theatre by the River and the improv troupe The Horrible Friends. He is well known on the Canadian Fringe Festival circuit as a touring performer with dozens of productions under his belt including many hit one man shows. Since moving to Vancouver, he has become a company member and instructor with Instant Theatre, and can be seen regularly performing improv and comedy all over the Vancouver area. He is also an active member of the local fandom community, performing regularly with West Coast Geeks vs Nerds and co-hosting the weekly Huge Nerds Podcast. Past theatre credits include A Few Good Men (RMTC/Citadel), The Paperbag Princess and More (PTE), Billy Bishop Goes to War, Saint Joan (Theatre by the River) and Miss Saigon (Rainbow Stage). 

New Wave Girl - Vivian Full 

Vivian is excited to be making her theatrical debut in Vancouver at the York Theatre. Passionate about the arts, Vivian has worked professionally in film/television and stage in Canada, the United States and the United Kingdom. Her most recent credits include DC Comics's Legends of Tomorrow, Ties That Bind and Heartland. Vivian has garnered numerous awards and nominations over the years, including an upcoming Joey Award nomination (2015) and winner for Best Actress at the AirTV Awards in Scotland (2014). Vivian received her professional training in drama, music and dance from the world-renowned Royal Conservatoire of Scotland in the U.K. and the Interlochen Arts Academy in the U.S. Vivian hopes everyone enjoys Heathers: The Musical!

Stoner Chick - Quinn Cartwright 

Hey yo Westerburg! Quinn is very excited to be a part of this incredible production. She is currently in her final year in Studio 58's acting program. Look for her in the world premiere George F. Walker's "The Crowd" in the spring. Favourite credits include Laurey in Oklahoma! (RCMT), Blind mouse in Shrek (TUTS), Luciana in Boys from Syracuse (Applause), Kendra in 13 (Awkward stage) and Meg March in Little Women (Broadway edge). Thanks to Kathryn Shaw, David C Jones and the rest of the production team for making this possible! Peace and love, man...

Young Republicanette - Deanna Rayne

Deanna is a singer-songwriter, actor, dancer, and producer. Her work ranges from acting in offbeat Fringe-esque theatre shows, to writing soulful ballads, and performing sultry jazz tunes with her band. Throughout her career Deanna has performed at a variety of events and venues most notably at the Vancouver Fringe Festival, The Ignite Theatre Festival, and at the Coastal Jazz Festival. In collaboration with the “Ethnic Sisters” Deanna recently launched a risqué and satirical blog depicting the experiences of her and three other 20 something year old women living life in the city. This summer Deanna released her second single “The Fire” and an acoustic version of her next single “To See You” is set for release later this year.

Crew

David C. Jones – Director

David C. Jones is director, an actor, keynote speaker, writer, filmmaker and teacher. 

David C. Jones has worked on everything from classic’s like Moliere’s The Learned Ladies and Sophocles’ Electra, to modern works like EcoDiva,Stop:Kiss, Poor,Superman and the Jessie nominated musical Ruthless!, improvised shows like The Gay Mafia and Twisted Anne of Green Gables and concert musicals like On the 20th Century and Wish You Were Here. David has also created and directed numerous corporate productions, charity fundraisers and trade shows using his wealth of theatrical training and experiences to help create spectacular spectaculars. He was Entertainment Manager of the 2010 Winter Olympics and Paralympic Games.    David has also won awards for his short films. For more information, please see his website www.davidcjones.ca.

Lisa Dery & Lori Watt – Producers

Lisa Dery and Lori Watt formed the Frolicking Divas in 2009 when they partnered together to bring Criminal Hearts to Vancouver.  Since then they have done a host of female dominated projects, such as The Vagina Monologues, a female version of The Odd Couple, and partnered with other companies to bring their works to Vancouver such as A Dreamer Examines His Pillow, Directed by Mel Tuck.  

Lisa is a graduate of AMDA the American Music and Dramatic Academy in New York and spent 10 years their singing in jazz bands and being generally fabulous while Lori stayed here, raised a child and attended Gastown Actors Studio.

Both Divas live in Burnaby now.  Lisa with her family and Lori with her son and collection of artist friends.   They are so thrilled to be bringing Heathers to Vancouver.  

Liz McLaughlin - Assistant Director

Elizabeth is an Actor and Acting Coach in Vancouver, BC. 

Elizabeth has recently finished working on SUPERNATURAL, ASHES ON THE WATER, AGAMEMNON, ANSIEDAD, PSYCH and FRINGE. 

As a Coach Liz has worked on a number of Film/ Television and Theatre productions over the past few years. 

Michael Brooks - Stage Manager

Michael was born in a one room log cabin in the nether lands of New Brunswick and was raised by a Moose and a Squirrel. No, not really. But he was born and raised in Fredericton, New Brunswick where he heard the call of the boards. Moving to Vancouver in the mid 90’s with stars in his eyes and the idea of becoming an actor. Michael quickly realized his real talents were in the area of Stage Management and Technical Direction. Michael pursued this new passion and has toured all over British Columbia and has managed shows across Canada. Michael most recently survived Aliens and Zombies during a successful run of Virtual Stage's Alien Contagion:  Rise of the Zombie Syndrome.

Ken Overbey - Choreographer 

Sarah Mabberley - Set Design

Michael Methot - Technical Director/Lighting Design

Sacha Picard - Costume Designer


What We Need 

Frolicking Divas would like YOU to help us bring HEATHERS THE MUSICAL to the York Theatre in January 2016.  We have formed an Equity Co-op entitled "..Gently with a Chainsaw" Artists' Collective (those of you familiar with the original movie will get the reference - the rest of you will have to see the musical) complete with fresh faces and seasoned professionals to bring you a great show to ring in the new year.  

We have already had some great sponsors come on board:

F As In Frank is our Vintage Clothing Sponsor for the show; and 

The Poster Guy will be providing assistance getting the word out around town with their fabulous postering skills.

What we need now is to raise some money to make this project truly great. 

Where does the money go?

There are a number of things to pay for on this productions and we certainly don't expect to have them all paid for by you, but for those of you that may not be familiar with all that goes in to making a big project like this happen, a few of the costs include:

- venue rental

- venue technicians

- box office, concession and front of house staff at the theatre

- our band 

- our actors

- set design/build

- photography/publicity and marketing

- the play rights 

- insurance, royalties, etc.

Risks & Challenges

It's tricky putting up independent theatre projects.  We all know that producing theatre in Vancouver is not going to make anyone rich.  We do it because we LOVE THEATRE.  It's as simple as that.  We love producing and performing in shows that are relevant, entertaining and enjoyable for audiences, even when the message may not always be the most comfortable one.  Heathers tackles such themes as bulimia, bullying, teen suicide and the werther effect.  We hope to have audiences walking away having not only having had a great time in the theatre but ALSO feeling inspired to talk about some of those  challenging issues that face teens today.  

We have an amazing team assembled and an incredible cast and we can't wait for you to see our show in January.  Tickets will be up for sale next week, but if you contribute to our indiegogo today, you can take advantage of some very special 'perks' as a thank you for helping us bring Heathers to Vancouver including tickets to our show.  As mentioned before - it will be very.

Before Mean Girls, before The Hunger Games - there were the HEATHERS. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Short on funds but still want to show us your support?  Thank you for that! Please feel free to share, tweet, put on your Facebook wall - we are so grateful for anything you can offer to get us closer to our goal of raising $7050 for our show.
story_txt:
Heathers The Musical - it will be Very
 
HEATHERS THE MUSICAL is the darkly delicious story of Veronica Sawyer, a brainy, beautiful teenage misfit who hustles her way into the most powerful and ruthless clique at Westerberg High: the Heathers. But before she can get comfortable atop the high school food chain, Veronica falls in love with the dangerously sexy new kid J.D. When Heather Chandler, the Almighty, kicks her out of the group, Veronica decides to bite the bullet and kiss Heather’s aerobicized ass… but J.D. has another plan for that bullet.
Brought to you by the award-winning creative team of Kevin Murphy (Reefer Madness, “Desperate Housewives”), Laurence O’Keefe (Bat Boy, Legally Blonde) and Andy Fickman (Reefer Madness, She’s the Man). HEATHERS THE MUSICAL is a hilarious, heartfelt and homicidal new show based on the greatest teen comedy of all time.     Who we are 
We are "..Gently with a Chainsaw Artists' Collective" - an equity coop with professional artists and up and comers looking to bring this great show to Vancouver for the first time in all of Canada!  
Cast
Christine Quintana - Veronica Sawyer 
Christine is an actor, playwright, and co-Artistic Producer of uber-indie theatre company Delinquent Theatre. As an actor, Christine has played in Saint Joan, She Stoops to Conquer,and the LEAP Reading Series (Arts Club), The Glass Menagerie (Fire Escape Co-op) Mr. Marmalade (Latchkey Co-Op), Of Mice and Men (Hardline Productions), The Wizard of Oz and Seussical (Carousel Theatre), RENT (FCP), and The Madonna Painter and Wild Honey (Theatre at UBC).  Christine’s plays include Selfie (commissioned by Théâtre la Seizième, premiered in March 2015, winner of the Sidney Risk Prize for Outstanding Script by an Emerging Playwright), Our Time, and Stationary: A Recession-Era Musical (toured to Talk is Free Theatre and the Cultch in April 2015, winner of the Jessie Richardson Theatre Award for Outstanding Musical, Small Theatre) for which she also served as producer and performer.  Christine co-created The Story of You and Me with collaborator Scott Button for Hive 3: The New Bees. Christine is Artistic Apprentice with the Electric Company Theatre, Marketing & Operations Coordinator with Neworld Theatre, and the Program Assistant for the LEAP Program at the Arts Club. She holds a BFA in Acting from the University of British Columbia and is dedicated coffee drinker and animal lover.

Kamyr Pazandeh - Jason J.D. Dean
Kamyar is thrilled to be working on such a fun show with a wonderful cast. Credits include 'Jud Fry' in Oklahoma!, 'Tybalt' in Romeo and Juliet (Studio 58), and 'Ernest Simpson', 'Bertie', 'Diamond', and 'Espil' inThe Duchess (Ruby Slippers). He is the recipient of the Leon and Thea Koerner Award in the Fine and Performing Arts as well as the Lloyd Nicholson Memorial Endowed Scholarship. He is currently co-writing and composing a musical that will be presented at Studio 58 in February during FourPlay. Kamyar has been playing piano since he was six and trumpet since he was ten. He began singing bass in the Magee Chamber choir at the age of fifteen in which the group took 2nd place in Canada in the Kiwanis festival. Since then he has sung in numerous groups including The Postmodern Camerata, Vancouver Academy of Music's Opera, and Sonic Boom. Music remains a source of inspiration in his life and work. Look out for him this summer at Bard on the Beach where he will be playing 'Pericles' in Pericles. Kamyar is a graduate of Studio 58. Enjoy the show! 

Synthia Yusuf - Heather Chandler
After taking a couple years off to pursue professional wine-drinking, Synthia is very excited to be back in the play business, and even more excited to be a part of The Heathers cast! She'd like to thank her friends and family for their love and support, and for laughing at her jokes. Favourite credits: Pilar in Legally Blonde: The Musical, and Evelyn in The Girl in the Frame. 
Devon Basswood - Heather McNamara

Devon is thrilled to be having a blonde moment in 'Heathers' alongside this wonderful cast and creative team! Recent credits include: Woman 1 in 'Edges' (Two Monkeys Co-op), Kate / Chutney / Elle U/S in 'Legally Blonde' (TUTS), Betsy Bear in 'Busytown' (Carousel Theatre for Young People), Daisy Hilton in 'Side Show' (Fighting Chance), Kate in 'Zanna, Don't' and Ashley in 'Changing Minds' (Awkward Stage), and Rose Fenny in 'Dogfight' (ArtsWest Playhouse and Gallery in Seattle, WA), for which she was nominated for 'Best Actress in a Musical' by the Gregory Awards and Broadway World. 

Nhi No - Heather Duke

A triple threat performer originally hailing from Victoria, British Columbia, Nhi Do is an actress, producer and director.
Nhi swiftly crossed over from the stage to film and television upon her arrival to Vancouver and soon found herself in a variety of productions including Watchmen, the award-winning Mulligans and Stranger with My Face. Recent projects include the original play, Patch, by NOW! Theatre, Luchagore Production's short, Feliz Cumpleanos (part of the Soska Sister's Women in Horror Massive Blood Drive 2015 PSA), OUTtv's first transgender sitcom, The Switch and Hallmark's The Magic Stocking.
When not acting, Nhi teaches and coaches several students while co-hosting and directing a talk/variety webseries called Dog's Breakfast.
Stephanie Davis - Martha Dunnstock
Over a year ago Steffanie listened to the soundtrack and fell in love with Heathers: a Musical. Steffanie is an alumna of the Capilano University Musical Theatre program and won the 2012 Outstanding Newcomer Ovation award. Credits include: Kris/Speaker in The Best Laid Plans: a Musical, Stella in Darling (Springboard Performance), Enid in Legally Blonde, Charlotte Cardoza in Titanic, Bye Bye Birdie (TUTS), Assassins (Pipedream), Jan in Grease (Footlight Theatre) and Dolly Levi in Hello Dolly (Exit22). 
Ram Sweeney - Colin Sheen
Colin is currently in Cambridge as part of their Anne of Green Gables show.  You may have seen him right here in Vancouver at the Arts Club Production Red Rock Diner.   
Kurt Kelly - Hal Wesley Rogers
Most recently Hal was on stage at the York in the musical Best Laid Plans.  He has studied at Circle in the Square and played Jesus in Fighting Chance's production of Jesus Christ Superstar.  
Ram's Dad/Big Bud Dean/Coach Ripper - Nelson Wong 

New Zealand-born actor, Nelson Wong, was a regular on Here TV's Donald Strachey Mystery Series, playing Kenny Kwon, the detective's trusty sidekick, has appeared in several TV movies including a lead role as Detective Jeff Wong in Lifetime TV's My Silent Partner and as State's Prosecutor Richard Lee on Secret Liaisons (Movie Central), has appeared on such shows as Fringe (FOX), The L Word(Showtime), Psych (USA), and jPod (CBC), and portrayed the twisted Dr. Black in the hit horror feature American Mary (Screamfest’s Best Picture 2012-Twisted Twins Productions).  Currently he can be seen in CBC’s spy drama The Romeo Section.
On stage Nelson has worked closely with playwright C.E. Gatchalian, originating the characterizations of Jeff and Chang Hyun for his world premieres of Broken (2006), and Falling In Time (2011), respectively-now available in book form. He is also a proud member of the improv comic troupe The Bobbers, and the sketch comedy group, Assaulted Fish.
Mr. Fleming/Veronica's Mom - Lori Watt
A Vancouver based actor Lori has been singing, dancing and acting since she was a young girl.  Some of her favourite roles are listed here:

Film:  Rorshach's Mom (Sylvia Kovacs) in The Watchmen, Samantha Garner in Embedded. 
Stage: Lil, in the award winning A Particular Class of Women, Collette in Four Dogs and a Bone, Bo in Criminal Hearts, Angel in Dregs of Society, April Greene in Hot L Baltimore, Friend in Gwynn Hunt's original play Missing and Florence in The Odd Couple (female version), Rocky Horror show with Wicked Awesome Theatre (Ovation Award nominee). 
Kurt's Dad/Veronica's Dad/Principal Gowan - Ken Overbey
Ken is doing double duty on this project and is also our choreographer.  
Bitter Geek - Matt Montgomery
Matt Montgomery is a recent graduate of the Canadian College of Performing Arts in Victoria BC. Born in Edmonton Alberta, Matt  spent his childhood moving around BC until he came to Vancouver to pursue his love for Musical Theatre. He is very excited to be a part of HEATHERS! Some of his recent credits include "Luke" in the Vancouver Fringe production of The OC the Musical, and "Jonathan" in Excavation Theatre's The Old Haunt.
Preppy Stud/Officer Milner/J.D. understudy - Daren Dyhengco
Daren is a recent grad of Capilano University’s Musical Theatre Program. He is very humbled to be given the chance to be the dance captain, an understudy and a swing for this production. Past credits include Albert in The Secret Garden (Exit 22), Ensemble in Hairspray (TUTS) and Brother in The Good Person of Setzuan (Exit 22). He would like to thank the producers, his director, his friends, and as always the never-ending support of his family.

story:
Sour Grapes Productions is Poor

Hello! I'm Genny Yosco of Sour Grapes Productions. My mother and I both moved up from West Virginia to New York and started a theater company because, unfortunately for us, the arts is our passion. We love acting, writing, directing, producing, even costuming! That being said, we've never had the money to do so (but at this point, we just decided that it needed to be done, because you only live so long, and why waste it being sad and unfulfilled, right?).

My mother had been raising me on her own since I was 2 years old, and she decided to further her education after my dad left in order to get a better career - but that landed us in a massive amount of college debts. She and I have always been so enthusiastic about our theater company, but we've never had the money to make our shows as good as they can be. I mean, we barely have the money to rent a decent amount of rehearsal space, so most of our shows rehearse right out of our apartment living room.

If we manage to get any money at all - AT ALL - from this Indiegogo campaign, that would greatly help us out.

What We Need

You might ask yourself "Well, how much does a show really cost to produce?" Here's an example of what it's going to cost us just for our Halloween show, Countess Dracula:

  • Since this show is under an AEA Showcase Code, we needed to buy accident insurance, which cost us a total of $295.
  • Royalties for all of the performances came out to $245.
  • The performance space (3 shows), tech rehearsals (2 nights in the theater), and audition space (2 days) cost us a total of $947.40.
  • Costuming, wigs, props, and set pieces have set us back $333.07
  • Under an AEA Showcase Code, we need to pay the actors a travel stipend, which will total out at $840.
This comes out to about $2660. Now, not all of our shows are the same. For example, our New Year's Eve show, A Fifth Dimension: An Unauthorized Twilight Zone Parody is an original work (meaning that I wrote it myself) so we don't have to pay the royalties for the show, but that has more people in it, so we're going to have to pay more actors. The show that I wrote that got into the FRIGID Festival, CSI: Mayberry - An Unauthorized Parody, also required no royalties, but it also has more actors, it required cop uniforms, and the festival charges shows that they accept around $750 to be involved.

So while we are super excited for all of this to be happening, we are going to be driven into some serious debt over all of this.

Now, I know what some of you more dubious humans are thinking: What about the ticket sales? First of all, under AEA Showcase Codes, we can only charge up to $18 per ticket (so there is NO CHANCE of us charging any sort of "Broadway prices," as some have put it). Secondly, there's no guarantee that people will come. While we have never had an empty audience, we have also NEVER completely made up our losses via ticket sales. We would love to sell out our theater for every performance, but that isn't our reality just yet.

What You Get

Other than the wonderful experience of the theater, you mean? Okay, fine, we get it - you want perks! We totally understand. We have a multitude of options for your viewing pleasure, but here are some highlights:

  • T-shirts with logos from our three upcoming shows.
  • Sour Grapes Productions tote bag! Don't just "go green" with any old tote bag for your next grocery shopping trip - go PURPLE and GREEN! Save the environment AND help us achieve our theatrical goals!
  • Pens that look like lipstick that have our Sour Grapes logo on it (they're cute, we swear)
  • Chapstick! Good chapstick. I, personally, am a chapstick snob, and I will tell you right now that this stuff is SO NICE. We have stuff with our production company logo, as well as logos for our shows!
  • Makeup beauty books! Full sets of makeup, including false eyelashes, in several varieties: Vampire, Enchanted, Diva, and Wicked. Pssst, the Vampire one is my favorite.

We Love a Good Challenge!

We're not in any way saying that these shows aren't going to happen. We've put down payments on theater spaces, we've payed festival acceptance fees, we've fully cast our first show (and have even began casting our second!) - but we know that "theater people" are stereotypically flighty. Here's why you should trust us with your donations:

  • My mother and I each started acting at very young ages, so we're super determined. I myself have been interested in the theater since I was 8 years old, and I have not backed down since. We're both fighters, and we want this company to succeed more than anything.
  • I'm not sure if you've really noticed this, but our theater company is called Sour Grapes Productions. You know what the phrase "sour grapes" means, right? For those who don't, it basically means that we're bitter. Anything or anyone that tries to get in our way only fuels our hate-fire. We make things happen.
  • We don't quit on anything - even when we should. Bad relationships? Nah, keep trying. Too much pizza? Too bad, we gotta eat it all. Super late at night and we should have gone to sleep by now? No, we have costumes to make and scripts to write, our bloodshot eyes can match the pizza sauce all over our shirts.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that not everyone can give us money. We ourselves can barely give us money. Here's other ways that you can help us out:

  • Share our campaigns with your friends! Especially if you know JK Rowling. I don't even need her to donate anything, I just think that she's neat.
  • Come see our shows! We want people to see us do our thaaang. And while you're at it, force your friends and family to come see us, too!
story_txt:
Sour Grapes Productions is Poor
 Hello! I'm Genny Yosco of Sour Grapes Productions. My mother and I both moved up from West Virginia to New York and started a theater company because, unfortunately for us, the arts is our passion. We love acting, writing, directing, producing, even costuming! That being said, we've never had the money to do so (but at this point, we just decided that it needed to be done, because you only live so long, and why waste it being sad and unfulfilled, right?). 
My mother had been raising me on her own since I was 2 years old, and she decided to further her education after my dad left in order to get a better career - but that landed us in a massive amount of college debts. She and I have always been so enthusiastic about our theater company, but we've never had the money to make our shows as good as they can be. I mean, we barely have the money to rent a decent amount of rehearsal space, so most of our shows rehearse right out of our apartment living room.If we manage to get any money at all - AT ALL - from this Indiegogo campaign, that would greatly help us out.
  What We Need
 You might ask yourself "Well, how much does a show really cost to produce?" Here's an example of what it's going to cost us just for our Halloween show, Countess Dracula:  Since this show is under an AEA Showcase Code, we needed to buy accident insurance, which cost us a total of $295.
 Royalties for all of the performances came out to $245.
 The performance space (3 shows), tech rehearsals (2 nights in the theater), and audition space (2 days) cost us a total of $947.40.
Costuming, wigs, props, and set pieces have set us back $333.07
Under an AEA Showcase Code, we need to pay the actors a travel stipend, which will total out at $840.
This comes out to about $2660. Now, not all of our shows are the same. For example, our New Year's Eve show, A Fifth Dimension: An Unauthorized Twilight Zone Parody is an original work (meaning that I wrote it myself) so we don't have to pay the royalties for the show, but that has more people in it, so we're going to have to pay more actors. The show that I wrote that got into the FRIGID Festival, CSI: Mayberry - An Unauthorized Parody, also required no royalties, but it also has more actors, it required cop uniforms, and the festival charges shows that they accept around $750 to be involved.So while we are super excited for all of this to be happening, we are going to be driven into some serious debt over all of this.Now, I know what some of you more dubious humans are thinking: What about the ticket sales? First of all, under AEA Showcase Codes, we can only charge up to $18 per ticket (so there is NO CHANCE of us charging any sort of "Broadway prices," as some have put it). Secondly, there's no guarantee that people will come. While we have never had an empty audience, we have also NEVER completely made up our losses via ticket sales. We would love to sell out our theater for every performance, but that isn't our reality just yet.    What You Get
 Other than the wonderful experience of the theater, you mean? Okay, fine, we get it - you want perks! We totally understand. We have a multitude of options for your viewing pleasure, but here are some highlights:  T-shirts with logos from our three upcoming shows.
Sour Grapes Productions tote bag! Don't just "go green" with any old tote bag for your next grocery shopping trip - go PURPLE and GREEN! Save the environment AND help us achieve our theatrical goals!
 Pens that look like lipstick that have our Sour Grapes logo on it (they're cute, we swear)
 Chapstick! Good chapstick. I, personally, am a chapstick snob, and I will tell you right now that this stuff is SO NICE. We have stuff with our production company logo, as well as logos for our shows!
Makeup beauty books! Full sets of makeup, including false eyelashes, in several varieties: Vampire, Enchanted, Diva, and Wicked. Pssst, the Vampire one is my favorite.
    We Love a Good Challenge!
  We're not in any way saying that these shows aren't going to happen. We've put down payments on theater spaces, we've payed festival acceptance fees, we've fully cast our first show (and have even began casting our second!) - but we know that "theater people" are stereotypically flighty. Here's why you should trust us with your donations:  My mother and I each started acting at very young ages, so we're super determined. I myself have been interested in the theater since I was 8 years old, and I have not backed down since. We're both fighters, and we want this company to succeed more than anything.
 I'm not sure if you've really noticed this, but our theater company is called Sour Grapes Productions. You know what the phrase "sour grapes" means, right? For those who don't, it basically means that we're bitter. Anything or anyone that tries to get in our way only fuels our hate-fire. We make things happen.
We don't quit on anything - even when we should. Bad relationships? Nah, keep trying. Too much pizza? Too bad, we gotta eat it all. Super late at night and we should have gone to sleep by now? No, we have costumes to make and scripts to write, our bloodshot eyes can match the pizza sauce all over our shirts.
    Other Ways You Can Help We know that not everyone can give us money. We ourselves can barely give us money. Here's other ways that you can help us out:  Share our campaigns with your friends! Especially if you know JK Rowling. I don't even need her to donate anything, I just think that she's neat.
 Come see our shows! We want people to see us do our thaaang. And while you're at it, force your friends and family to come see us, too!

story:
LEO is a new contemporary dance and healing arts performance. It is a co-creation of 10 dancers directed by Ron Amit, former Bat-Sheva Dance Ensemble member, and produced by TransformOtion as part of their educational dance program. 
 Who We Are:

In the beginning of this year TransformOtion began a new dance educational project in Portland, OR called the Sun and Moon Courses.  These courses were created from the idea that the body is a powerful tool in personal transformation.  Participants were involved in a deep self-study process that involved philosophies from ancient and contemporary practices.  These workshops were open to the community and were accessible to all ages, genders, and levels of experience.

The Moon Course followed the lunar cycle and focused on development of emotional awareness through movement.  The Sun Course focused on developing the individual artistic voice and a collaborative choreographic process.  This new work, titled LEO, is a culmination of the research that has happened throughout the program.

This new choreographic work is a deep investigation of emotional integrity and physical expression through movement.  It portrays a wide range of emotional content including drama, comedy, risk, vulnerability, connection, and discord.  This dance piece explores the depths of the human experience with self, relationships, and community through the lens of the Leo energy and its’ metaphors.   


TransformOtion Team:

Choreographer/Director: Ron Amit
Manager/Producer: Michael Garber
Dancers: Abby Nace, Angela Kremer, Andrea Larreta, Erica Belfiore, Jenna Chen, Kya Bliss, Lakiah Raine, Lynne Joy Nesbit, Nicholas Petrich and Michael Garber.
LIVE Music: The one and only Danceher Jones!
The awesome musicians from YAIMA! Masaru Higasa, Pepper Proud and Jeff Kimes.
Musical collaborators: Chryseph Honeybear and Isaac Cotec.
VJ: Tommy Newbrey


What we need:

It is our mission to create a high-quality performance that also supports the local community by creating income for local artists.  All funds raised through the fundraiser will be distributed on a need basis to secure the success and quality of the performance.  

Here is a projected budget:

Rehearsal Space Rental: $1500
Theater $700
Dancer Fees:$3000
Costumes: $500
Musicians: $600
Visual Artist and set design : $400
Stage Manager: $500
Rehearsal Manager:$1000
Director/Choreographer: $1500
Graphic Designer: $200
Photographer: $200
Extra Materials $200
Total:$10,300

We have already raised $4,600!  
We need $5700 to reach our goal!



The Impact of Your Donation:

By contributing to this fundraising effort you are creating an opportunity for self-expression and creativity for many individuals.  Art making is inherently a process of self-development and self-expansion.  Donating to this dancing community supports building a community that is supported by vulnerability and authentic connection.

Ron and Michael each bring over a decade of international professional dance experience into the creation of TransformOtion.  They have chosen Portland, OR as their new home and are thrilled to be able to contribute to the thriving communities in the Pacific Northwest. 

Their mission for the near future is to form a new professional contemporary dance company based in Portland, OR and to continue to offering high-quality educational programming that is rich in content for personal and communal development in the performing arts.

Masters of Transition:

We believe in the power of the creative process.  We believe that limitations serve us as an evolutionary catalyst, propelling us into unimaginable capacities of creativity.  We believe in the power of the collective and the impact of each individual's contribution in that collective.  We believe in working with the energy that is offered and being in harmony with our highest potential.  We believe in ourselves.  We believe in YOU!  We are LIONS and LIONESSES!  Let us ROAR TOGETHER!!

Interested in more ways to contribute?

Spread the word! Share this fundraising campaign with the world through social media, email, text, and good old fashioned conversation!  

Do you have a talent or skill that you would like to offer?  Send us an email or contact us on FB!

info@transformotion.org
www.facebook.com/transformotions

story:
Hello out there IndieGoGo! We are the Grey Ensemble Theatre, a group of former Chicago-based artists living and working in Los Angeles. We moved out west to pursue careers in the Film/TV industry, but have been longing for the collaborative, ensemble-based theatre work we left behind in the Windy City. Add to that a desperate need in the industry as a whole for stories devoted to diversity and inclusion and you've got a group of scrappy artists ready to start a production company. We will be launching our first production at this year's Hollywood Fringe Festival and need your help to make that happen!

What We Need & What You Get

Our first production will be F*** My Life , a new play by Danny Bernardo which will have its world premiere at Hollywood Fringe Festival 2016. The play follows a diverse group of 20-somethings as they navigate their lives and relationships on-and-offline without realizing the real life impact of their social media interactions.  We're very excited to bring this timely piece to life, but we're going to need your help to do it.

This is our first production and the money we're hoping to raise will go to the bare necessities to make it happen. That includes the space rental, the administrative fees to be a part of Hollywood Fringe, production needs (such as costumes, props, set pieces), artist salaries, and promotional materials. Starting a theatre company and launching our first production isn't easy (financially or logistically) which is why we are counting on our friends, family, and supporters of live theatre and our mission to help bring this production to life. The box office return that we've projected won't cover all of the overhead, so anything you can contribute to help out would be greatly appreciated. And of course, we've got some fun perks per donation tier: check 'em out!


The Impact

The conversation of diversity and inclusion in theatre has been ongoing for many years now. And while it's starting to get exponentially better through individual companies, the industry as a whole faces challenges in taking action. This first production (which embodies our mission fully) will help us make our presence known in the LA theatre community and build the foundation for us to continue our work in the future. By focusing on work that challenges the audiences perceptions of race, gender, and culture with inclusive casting and staffing, we hope to be an inspiration and a resource for our colleagues in the community. Your donation for this immediate production can help build the groundwork for that goal.


Risks & Challenges

Of course, producing a play has no guaranteed quantifiable success. Especially monetarily. We stand behind this piece, the artists involved, and the process in which we build it. We can only hope (as all artists do) that audiences will connect with the piece as much as we do and continue to support our work. Your donation helps to underwrite our overhead for this production so that our personal monetary losses are minimal should the piece not succeed financially. However, should our dreams and expectations for this piece be met artistically and financially, we will be able to invest any profit made into future productions.


Other Ways You Can Help

We thank you for taking the time to consider a donation for our project. Every dollar donated is appreciated and will be put to good use. Besides donating, the best way you can help our project is to spread the word for this fundraising campaign through your personal networks. We really believe in our mission and this piece and we hope you do too.

story:
Gone Rogue Productions is the touring name of the theatrical performing arts societies from the University of Southampton. This year we're taking 5 productions up to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival: 

  • A Number, by Carol Churchill (with Theatre Group)
  • Numbers, by Kieron Barry (with Theatre Group) 
  • Ordinary Days, by Adam Gwon (with Showstoppers)
  • The Very Nice Improv Show, from Beard of Zeus (with Comedy Society)
  • Drastic Measures, from Southampton Spotlights (with Comedy Society)
 You can find out more about Gone Rogue and our 2016 shows here.
Taking shows to the largest arts festival in the world is an incredible opportunity for us, and we can't do it without your help! 

Why do we need your help? 

Although our supporting societies have been working super hard to fundraise, all the shows would really benefit from a fundraising boost. Taking one show to Edinburgh is expensive, but taking 5 is a major commitment. Your contribution will go towards:

  • The venue
    Venue hire is the most expensive part of the productions, but is an essential part of performing at the Fringe!
  • Transport
    Although our performers pay for their own travel, we need to bring up all our set, props and costume! 
  • Fringe affiliation and publicity
    As well as putting our shows in the Fringe programme, we also need to buy flyers and posters so that audiences know they can come and see us! 
Taking a show to the Fringe is an amazing opportunity for us, and not just because of the festival atmosphere! It's really exciting to be able to experience a more professional environment, especially because of the chance to receive constructive feedback. Participating in the Fringe gives us access to unique, free workshops which are invaluable for those of us considering a career in the performing arts. Edinburgh during festival season is absolutely magical, and we can learn so much, from our own productions and by watching and networking with other companies. Our teams are utterly passionate about their shows, and our performers are looking forward to taking on new stages and audiences! 
Every donation means so much to us, which is why we've provided some fabulous perks to say a massive thank you! We'd also really appreciate it if you could share this campaign to help get us on our way. 
If you've selected a perk which includes a complimentary ticket, you'd like us to tag your twitter handle in a shoutout, or you've got a question about the campain, please get in touch via Facebook, Twitter, or email us at admin@gone-rogue.co.uk!

story:
Talbot House - a home from home: for the radio!

'Talbot House - a home from home' was first performed at The Bacon Theatre, Cheltenham in August 2007 and has been touring throughout the British Isles, France and Belgium ever since. The play tells the true story of the house in Belgium that became a haven in hell for the British Troops in the trenches of the First World War. This house was run by the chaplain Philip 'Tubby' Clayton on the grounds that all men were created equal and therefore regardless of rank or religious leaning, all would be treated equally in Talbot House (the soldiers went on to refer to the house by the army signaller's code of 'Toc H').

It is a wonderful story that illustrates that in the worst of times, positives can be found and created. After the war this wonderful notion of equality inspired Tubby Clayton to establish the TocH Movement - a network of hostels that eventually spread right across the globe offering comfort, shelter and support to whosever needed it.

Talbot House itself still stands in Poperinge, Belgium and the welcome and ambience of the place still evokes friendship and support. It was a personal visit there that inspired me to pen the play with the desire to educate and illustrate a truly wonderful place and man.

It is hoped that this special recording of the play, which will be suitable for radio broadcast, will reach a wider audience than the theatre play could ever do so. 

As a contributor to this campaign you will be personally helping me to tell a story of the Great War that is often overlooked, but one which I am passionate about. The effect of Talbot House was long lasting and did much to alleviate the hardships that the soldiers faced when they returned to Britain - finding it not a country fit for heroes but one in which jobs were few and far between and suffering was widescale. The lesson of Talbot House and Tubby Clayton is that in the direst of times, anyone and everyone can make a singular difference to the well being of their fellow man!

I cannot get this message out there just on my own - but with your help, I know that I can!      

What I Need & What You Get!

This project has been budgeted at £1500. This is on a cost only basis for:

  • Recording studio fees (2 days)
  • Recording engineer fees (2 days)
  • Recording mixing (1 day)
  • Actor fees (expenses only)
  • Recording rights and permissions (use of music and sound effects)
  • Production of master recording
  • Duplication of master recording
  • Artwork design (CD cover/inserts etc)
  • Printing and production of final product (CDs)

Other than making this happen, what will you get out of this?

  • Everyone that supports this campaign will be invited to a launch celebration of the recording.
  • Anyone that can contribute £10 or more will receive a soundtrack recording of the theatre play (as seen here on Amazon) along with a souvenir play programme.
  • Anyone that can contribute £20 or more will receive a soundtrack recording of the theatre play (as seen here on Amazon) along with a souvenir play programme PLUS a CD copy of this dramatisation for radio recording.

Risks & Challenges

Inevitably with any project like this there will be difficulties and perhaps hurdles to overcome - there always are! But, I have self-produced dozens of theatrical productions, recordings, events, publications, workshops and the like........I am not one to give up and I have, to date, never failed to finish what I set out to achieve in the first place. 

If we don't realise the target funding, then we shall go ahead with the recording, but look at ways of cutting the costs - recording quicker (speaking faster!).

Other Ways You Can Help

Please don't feel that this project is just about financial support! Not at all!!!! If you don't feel able or inclined to make a financial assistance, then please stay 'part of the family' and spread the word of the campaign - whether verbally or by social media. It all counts and it all helps!

Thank you so much for taking the time to read and consider this - it really is appreciated!

All the very best

Peter
