story:
Hi There. This is Christine Cali, the director of CALI & CO dance, a small but mighty San Francisco based contemporary dance company founded in 2001. You or your family and friends may have taken a dance class with me around the bay area and beyond or have attended a performance of CALI & CO dance/Matt EL over the years.

The last decade has provided a steady and dynamic climb to sustainability in my dance career. Now in a place where I am out of survival mode after two decades (as many artists experience), I am able to become a supporter of those artists on the continuum in seeking a sustainable life in the arts.

This year we are reaching out beyond our own companies and creative work to support fellow artists in the Bay Area and beyond by presenting: 

WAH! Fest 2016,, a platform for DIVERSE WOMEN choreographers, dancers, musicians, visual artists and light designers who are creating contemporary work through a feminist lens, including those who identify on the gender continuum as female.

LISTEN to our INTERVIEW - All About WAH! Fest on KPFA Radio Women's Magazine (April 11, 2016)
Our vision is in amplifying and widening the impact of women's work in the arts while supporting our local communities in need. 30% of tickets sales for WAH! will support the Homeless Children's Network of San Francisco and the  San Francisco Safehouse.
This is the most ambitious and prolific project that I have propelled into existence in my dance career with 6 performance programs over 3 days featuring over 60 artists and performers. We are excited to ANNOUNCE our talented WAH! Fest ARTISTS:
10 choreographers selected through a juried panel process
*Seda Aybay-Owens/Kybele Dance Theater
*Rebecca Bryant
*Samantha Giron
*Jackie Goneconti, Karla Quintero and Shareen DeRyan in collaboration
*Pearl Marill
*Morgan True, Molly Katzman, Vicky Kapo, Mori Walts in collaboration
*viv dance company (work by Katie Faulkner)
*Nichele Van Portfleet
*Ayana Yonesaka
PLUS - a new work by CALI & CO dance/Matt EL

1 Site-specific CatCallChoir by Heather Arnett (performed all 3 nights)

9 musicians curated by Matt EL
*Ziva Hadar
*Deborah Crooks
*Ellisa Sun @ Cafe LaBoheme 
*Katie Iannitello
*Melissa Lyn
*Lizzie Karr @ Cafe LaBoheme
*Lauren Monheim (CreatureBaby) 
*Katya Bitar
*Banda Sin Nombre @ Cafe LaBoheme

3 panel discussions facilitated by Bay Area women arts professionals 
*Olive McKeon
*More TBA

2 gallery artists
*Maria Doglio
*Kate Langlois

1 Light Designer - Beth Hersh
We have a dynamic team of collaborators on board, including my partner in art and life, musician Matt Langlois/Matt EL, a partnership with the Dance Mission Theater, our fiscal sponsor Dancer's Group, Jenna Valez (assistant), Maria Doglio (Manager) and several volunteers.
We are seeking to raise $10,000 to support the following for WAH! Fest:

Dance Mission Theater Rental: $3500
Artist fees: 

  • 10 Choreographers: $1000
  • 9 Musicians: $450
  • 3 Visual Artists: $300
  • 3 Guest Speakers: $300
  • Light Design: $1,000

PR Consultant: $500

Brochures/Posters/Flyers: $ $500

Festival Administration: $2400

WAH! Fest Curation Panel/Admin: $1000

Reception: $500

This is a labor of love. We are out-of-pocket supporting this festival thus far (which means we are a little crazy but find it necessary to support our community!) This is honestly only a portion of what we need to make WAH! a success  - we need your support to help make it fly! 

Any donations received beyond $10,000 will go directly toward artist fees.

  • WAH!​ Fest will respond to our 21st century art climate
  • WAH!​ Fest will speak to our current artistic trends and practices
  • WAH! Fest will support diverse women artists through rebellious, wild and masterful work 
  • WAH! Fest will value our varied voices, bodies, and minds

Thank you for considering our fundraising campaign and we promise WAH! Fest will be a meaningful, wild, rebellious, masterful and transformative weekend of performances! 

Warmly,

Christine Cali

story:
The Dreamer Examines His Pillow by John Patrick Shanley explores one couple’s struggle to find their way through the chaos of lust, love and commitment. Through three scenes, we follow Tommy and Donna, passionate on and off again lovers. When Donna turns to her distant alcoholic father for advice, an emotional conversation leads her to demand that he confront Tommy.

“The play uses indirection and richly evocative language to make its unsettling but ultimately illuminating points. "…pungent, thought-provoking, original, poetic…and leading by stylized, fantasticated ways to genuinely startling illuminations." —NY Magazine.

“A philosophic dream-comedy about love, marriage, and maturity." —Village Voice.

“Mr. Shanley is a born playwright" —The New Yorker.

So far we have:

-An amazing team

-The rights to produce

-Approved rental of our intimate, 36-seat theater, The Sherry Theater, for a 6 week run, July 8th-August 14th.

We are asking for your support! With your donations, we will be able to:

-Pay for the performance royalties

-Cover the theater rental fees

-Purchase props and costumes

-Cover the costs of set design

-Arrange marketing and publicity

OUR TEAM:

Ilia Volok (director) is a graduate of Moscow Art Theatre School and Lifetime Member of The Actors Studio. LA Theater: The Revisionist (Wallis Annenberg Center for the Performing arts) co-starring opposite Tony award winner Deanna Dunagan,written by The Oscar nominee Jesse Eisenberg, Who Killed Comrade Rabbit? (Blank Theater)-co writer&producer, Vivien (Actor’s Circle)co-producer, Just a Song at Twilight (Write Act Repertory) Cat’s Paw(Actor’s Studio), Ferdinand(Promanade Playhouse), Cassat & Degas (The Hudson Theater), Destiny's Calling (Stella Adler Theater), Chekhov in Yalta (Theater 40) and Fakov in America(American Renegade Theater)co-writer&co-producer. His one-man show Diary of A Madman won the 2013 LA Weekly Theater Award for Best Solo Performance. To this date, Ilia has appeared in over 140 films and television shows. Select Films: Air Force One, Oliver Stone's U-Turn, Indiana Jones 4, The Curious Case of Benjamin Button, The Soloist, Pawn Sacrifice, Water for Elephants, Mission Impossible-Ghost Protocol, Abduction, GI JOE 2, The Immigrant. Recent television includes "The Americans", "NCIS" & "NCIS New Orleans", "Hawaii 5.0", "Two Broke Girls", "Clipped", and recurring  roles on the Michael Bay series "The Last Ship" and  "Scandal". More info on: www.iliavolok.com. Represented by Endorse Management Group. 

Pauline Schantzer (performer/producer) received her training at Playhouse West in Los Angeles. Her recent theater credits in which she has both acted and produced include: The Woolgatherer, The Pride, and Dutchman. Film roles include: The Corridor Defended, The Last Train, and Brick Walls, among others. Pauline is currently writing her first one act play Lollipop.

Ky Soto(performer) was born and raised in Marin County, California, and moved to Los Angeles in 2008 to begin studying acting full time at Playhouse West School & Repertory Theater.He studied there under the coaching of Robyn Cohen, Mark Pellegrino, & Jeff Goldblum. In 2013 he was invited to join James Franco at UCLA in a Franco taught scene study class for the following two years. Ky has two cats and if you ask him nicely he will show you pictures.

David Gianopoulos (performer) is very happy to return back to the stage after a long time away. Last seen on the stage at Laguna playhouse in American Buffalo as Teach (winner of production of the year from OC Weekly). David was nominated for the LA Drama Critic Circle Award for lead actor in the play White People. At the Road Theater Company David was the recipient of a Drama Logue award for his work as Tony in The Vig.  He has performed at The New York Shakespeare Festival production of Henry IV and Richard II. Other theatre credits include: Danny and The Deep Blue Sea. The Glimmering, The Rose Tattoo, and The Bear. TV credits: Cop Rock, The Division, Queer As Folk, Mr. Rock N Roll, All Lies End in Murder, The Last Don, Sisters, CSI, American Dreams, Without A Trace, ER, Castle, American Horror Story.  Film Credits: Air Force One, Under Siege 2, Candy Man 2, Last Request, Brothers in Arms, and Public Eye.

Other Ways You Can Help:

Whether you can contribute financially or not, there are many ways you can help us achieve our goal!

-Share this campaign on Social Media!

-Tell your friends about us!

-Come see the show! Buy tickets here: http://dreamertheplay.ticketleap.com/the-dreame...

OR reserve your ticket to dreamertheplay@gmail.com and pay cash/credit at the door. 

-Bring your friends to the show!

-If you want to donate equipment, talent, labor, or time. Contributions in all forms are valued! Email:dreamertheplay@gmail.com

Follow us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/dreamertheplay/

story:
Short Summary


Ruby Red Burlesque is a Las Vegas-inspired pantomime informed by the foundations of traditional burlesque and musical theatre. Ruby Red Burlesque is produced by Concrete Vertigo Productions, an incorporated not-for-profit in Toronto, Canada. 

With a book written by Cameron Chase Fatkin, and original music composed by Cameron Walker Fox-Revett, Concrete Vertigo Productions’ Ruby Red Burlesque is an electrifying stage adaptation of The Wonderful Wizard of Oz. Combining high-octane choreography and stunning direction by established dancer/choreographer Angela Mahoney (Katy Perry, Jason Derulo, Nick Jonas, Sting, etc...), Ruby Red Burlesque presents a first rate adaptation of a universally acclaimed tale in an effort to discuss topics of sexuality, gender identity, ethnic diversity and body image positivity.

What We Need & What You Get

We are aiming to fund $15,000 to go towards building the costumes for Ruby Red Burlesque. Designed by up-and-coming fashion designer Blaise Crocker (Opera Atelier, Bustle Clothing, Joseph Mimran and Associates), Ruby Red Burlesque will be a runway minded take on OZ, revolutionizing live performance in the city of Toronto. 

Established partners include Swarovski, and Couture Mask.  

The Impact

Having already established critical and commercial success in Vancouver, Canada, Concrete Vertigo Productions' Ruby Red Burlesque will be setting the standard for independent Toronto theatre. Going on record as the biggest independent theatre production this summer in Toronto - spearheaded by the youngest and brightest Canadian talents - Ruby Red Burlesque is ready to strip away the precedents of what it means to be doing theatre on an "indie" level.

EMPOWERMENT. Sexuality, gender identity, ethnic diversity, body image empowerment, and disability positivity are rarely found in Toronto theatre, and when they are found they never measure to their fullest potentials. Ruby Red Burlesque triumphs the stories that go unheard, using the tales that we all know off by heart. Classic Oz characters including Ruby Red’s narrator,  a non-binary-gendered rock n’ roll Glinda, teach Dorothy about love, sexuality and desire. It is time that theatre sees people of all genders, ages, ethnicities and sexualities represented on the stage. 

Performed this August 2016 at Toronto's historic Randolph Theatre (formerly the Bathurst Street Theatre), Ruby Red Burlesque will be reaching 6000+ audience members of various ages, ethnicities, and gender identities - representing each and every one in the story. 

Risks & Challenges

Ruby Red Burlesque has already raised over $35,000 from alternate endeavours. With the show's established financial viability, secured run this August in Toronto, and established partnership, Ruby Red Burlesque has already set the stage for Toronto's most exciting show this summer!

Other Ways You Can Help

Share! We're on Facebook, Instagram, Youtube, the WHOLE LOT! Please get in touch with us at concretevertigoproductions@gmail.com! This is a TEAM effort, and we always want to welcome any form of support on our team!

story:
Hey there! We are Tropical Arts, a Cairns based Theatre Company specialising in producing unique, collaborative and diverse work. Our main stage production, "Shakespeare at the Tanks," is an annual production now in its 9th year at the heritage-listed Tanks Art Centre.  Classical renditions of Shakespeare's work is something we are NOT known for, we have always added a new twist every year from SCI-FI to Tropical Surreal. Our Company's difference does not stop there however!  Tropical Arts has a close partnership with ARC Disability Services and more recently, Deaf Services Queensland who have helped us build a cast TRUELY REFLECTIVE of the community we live in.  People with a disability and the Deaf are only the tip of our diverse community who are onstage, backstage and fully plugged in to the Tropical Arts experience. 

What We Need & What You Get

Tropical Arts is looking for $2000 to re-ignite our website, making it functional again, and to build our company profile through a marketing investment we have never been able to make before. Tropical Arts has such a good message, but it needs to be heard and seen. Every donation matters, not matter how small... From little things, big things grow.

Please consider donating to this lovely little project of ours, as a not-for-profit we put every dollar from ticket sales back into the show and we have little or nothing for stepping up our marketing game, but with this campaign, with your help, we can turn that around :)

story:
LV DANCE COLLECTIVE PRESENTS LORENA VEY

“Two possibilities exist: Either we are alone in the Universe or we are not,” stated Arthur C. Clarke. What if there is a spaceship that could take us around the universe and witness the possibility that we are not alone? Imagine during your tour outside the Milky Way, you stumble down upon a new Galaxy far, far away from our own and land onto a foreign planet called Lorena Vey.

In LV Dance Collective’s 3rd home season concert, titled Lorena Vey, you will leave behind your day-to-day reality and step into a new world of limitless beauty. The procreation of this production is to bring awareness to the significance behind the meaning of “LV”, hence, the title “Lorena Vey”-the middle initials of both directors and the language of our work. Co-Artistic Directors, Kao Vey Saephanh and Martha L. Zepeda Pamintuan have choreographed new works that introduce the beings and creatures that exist on the planet of Lorena Vey. This production will share LV’s voice and aesthetic—beautifully sensitive and thought provoking. 

Finally, our journey as a collective has been long in the making with lots of obstacles along the way that have shaped LVDC in its entirety. This production is more than just another show, it is a long time dream come true that will truly test our ongoing journey; And we can’t do it without your support. Please consider joining us in making our dream come true.  

YOUR SUPPORT WILL HELP US

The generous donations we receive through this campaign will help us pay for:

  • Theater Fees
  • Rehearsal Studio Fees
  • Dancers Compensation
  • Costumes 
  • Lighting Designer
  • Photographer
  • Videographer

LV DANCE COLLECTIVE BIO

LV Dance Collective (LVDC) is a Contemporary Fusion performance company, located in the SF Bay Area under the Artistic Direction of Kao Vey Saephanh and Martha L. Zepeda Pamintuan. LVDC was founded in January 2013 with several projects beginning in 2006. LVDC was awarded the Spring 2014 ChoreoProject Award for Best Choreography by sjDANCEco for their work “Quest For Truth” and the Fall 2014 ChoreoProject Award for Best Choreography sjDANCEco for “Size 9” choreographed by Martha L. Zepeda Pamintuan and was the runner-up for Luna Dance Institutes Choreofund 2 and 4 (Berkeley, CA). LVDC was also selected to participate in: ODC Pilot 63; sjDANCEco Festival; Guest Choreographers for the East Oakland Sports Center Introductory School of Dance (Oakland, CA); and the 2014 and 2015 PUSHfest (San Francisco, CA). Lastly, LVDC has been featured in the East Bay Express, online publication of Teacher Magazine, and a variety of local newspapers and online publications including In Dance Magazine and SF Gate Weekly. LV Dance Collective has had an outstanding two-night sellout home season performance "CODE", August 29th & 30th of 2014, as part of the Garage Resident Artist Workshop (RAW). Due to the success of the show LVDC was asked for an ENCORE performance, which took place on Friday, October 3rd at 8pm at the Garage, which also sold out. This production led to the invitation of LVDC to produce an entire production  “Red Egg” for SPF8.

What if there is a spaceship that could take us around the universe and witness the possibility that we are not alone? Imagine during your tour outside the Milky Way, you stumble down upon a new Galaxy far, far away from our own and land onto a foreign planet called Lorena Vey.

In LV Dance Collective’s 3rd home season concert, titled Lorena Vey, you will leave behind your day-to-day reality and step into a new world of limitless beauty. The procreation of this production is to bring awareness to the significance behind the meaning of “LV”, hence, the title “Lorena Vey”-the middle initials of both directors and the language of our work. Co-Artistic Directors, Kao Vey Saephanh and Martha L. Zepeda Pamintuan have choreographed new works that introduce the beings and creatures that exist on the planet of Lorena Vey. This production will share LV’s voice and aesthetic—beautifully sensitive and thought provoking. 

Finally, our journey as a collective has been long in the making with lots of obstacles along the way that have shaped LVDC in its entirety. This production is more than just another show, it is a long time dream come true that will truly test our ongoing journey; And we can’t do it without your support. Please consider joining us in making our dream come true.  


YOUR SUPPORT WILL HELP US

The generous donations we receive through this campaign will help us pay for:

Theater Fees
Rehearsal Studio Fees
Dancers Compensation
Costumes 
Lighting Designer
Photographer
Videographer


LV DANCE COLLECTIVE BIO

LV Dance Collective (LVDC) is a Contemporary Fusion performance company, located in the SF Bay Area under the Artistic Direction of Kao Vey Saephanh and Martha L. Zepeda Pamintuan. LVDC was founded in January 2013 with several projects beginning in 2006. LVDC was awarded the Spring 2014 ChoreoProject Award for Best Choreography by sjDANCEco for their work “Quest For Truth” and the Fall 2014 ChoreoProject Award for Best Choreography sjDANCEco for “Size 9” choreographed by Martha L. Zepeda Pamintuan and was the runner-up for Luna Dance Institutes Choreofund 2 and 4 (Berkeley, CA). LVDC was also selected to participate in: ODC Pilot 63; sjDANCEco Festival; Guest Choreographers for the East Oakland Sports Center Introductory School of Dance (Oakland, CA); and the 2014 and 2015 PUSHfest (San Francisco, CA). Lastly, LVDC has been featured in the East Bay Express, online publication of Teacher Magazine, and a variety of local newspapers and online publications including In Dance Magazine and SF Gate Weekly. LV Dance Collective has had an outstanding two-night sellout home season performance "CODE", August 29th & 30th of 2014, as part of the Garage Resident Artist Workshop (RAW). Due to the success of the show LVDC was asked for an ENCORE performance, which took place on Friday, October 3rd at 8pm at the Garage, which also sold out. This production led to the invitation of LVDC to produce an entire production  “Red Egg” for SPF8.

story:
Who we are and What we do

Woven Theatre is a new theater company in Nashville formed by three Belmont University Theater Directors. Our goal is to create beautiful, impactful theater using young up and coming artists. Lungs is the final show of our three show season. It opens Friday August 26 and runs until the 28th. 

Lungs is the story of a young couple who want a child but are running out of time. It is a time of global anxiety, terrorism, erratic weather and political unrest. If they over think it, they’ll never do it. But if they rush, it could be a disaster.They want to have a child for the right reasons. Except, what exactly are the right reasons?

Choosing to back this production not only helps this show become a reality, it also helps to shape the next generation of artists. 


What We Need & What You Get

Here is how your money is distributed. 

  • $400- rights to the show
  • $300- to actors
  • $450- to the design team
  • $50- additional expenses
Now the fun part, what you get. If you do decide to back this campaign you could get some or all of the following

  • Reserved tickets to the show.
  • Mention in the program
  • A personalized thank you message from Woven
  • Personal Meet and Greet with the cast and crew

The Impact

We here at Woven Theatre are all heavily invested in our idea of creating new and though provoking theater. We are industrious and hard working and have plenty of experience in the world of professional theater.

Between us we have Assistant Directed, Sound Designed, and Prop Mastered for Verge Theatre Company. Designed for the Nashville Rep and the Nashville Shakespeare Festival. Worked with the Nashville Childrens Theatre and Studio Tenn. Performed and/or Directed with Blackbird, Little Stone, Actor's Bridge, Belmont University, the Nashville Shakespeare Festival, and Lipscomb University. This is just to name a few. Some of us have been nominated and received awards from the Kennedy Center American College Theatre Festival.  

Even if you can't contribute you can still help! Share this campaign! Throw it into the world! Get the word out and if you can, come see the show!

story:
About us

Wrongsemble is a theatre company based in West Yorkshire made up of professional artists and practitioners who all specialise in working with and creating work for young people, schools and families. We make theatre for little and big kids alike, from the young of passport to the young of heart! It all begins with stories, add a splash of colour, a ditty or two, and you!


About the show

The number of dimensions we can perceive, 
The number of miles one finds in a league, 
The number of sugars I like in my tea! 
A hat trick, a trio, a great trilogy...

Three wishes, three witches, three sisters, three pigs, three bears, three beers, three musketeers...

Three actors weave together three famous tales, which incidentally, all feature the elusive number three! Brought to life in a flurry of original live music and brilliantly energetic storytelling, behold as our players burst from their wagon of forgotten fables to re-tell the yarns of Rumpelstiltskin, Goldilocks and Grimm’s Three Wanderers as never before! Three is a brand new piece for everyone aged 3+ by Wrongsemble.


The Impact

Here at Wrongsemble, we are passionate about telling stories and bringing our shows to as many families as possible. Having previously taken the show to the corners of our county, to audiences of all ages, and performing in the most diverse spectrum of venues, we have developed our show into a production for absolutely everyone! A show for all ages, at local and international festivals this summer, ensures adults and children experience the magic of theatre together as a family.

Your donations will help us bring our show to festivals during the Summer, as we spread the words of Wrongsemble and look ahead to a national tour of ‘Three’ in 2017.

What We Need & What You Get

So far Three has toured to communities throughout West Yorkshire during 2016, working closely with Creative Scene, and supported by Arts Council England and the West Yorkshire Playhouse.

Now we want to take our tales to family audiences throughout the UK, from the fields of Deer Shed Festival, to the streets of Manchester, and the hallowed eaves of Summerhall in Edinburgh! We need your support to finance our travel, our accommodation, and the maintenance of our hand-made props and costumes, for the future of ‘Three’ to shine as brightly as it can.  

As a donor to “Three”, you can receive a number of perks; from a mention on the donor’s page on our website, to our soundtrack including a song composed especially for you, or even a name check in one of our shows!


Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot donate, but would like to support Wrongsemble, please share our campaign with your friends, families and networks! Use the indiegogo share tools up above.

Thank you!

story:
Henry V: Agincourt 600

Beowulf meets Scorsese, via the halls of Valhalla and Vietnam
A 90 minute, eclectic, fast-paced, dynamic and physical theatre ensemble Henry V – with a twist.

Struts and Frets Theatre, a registered charity (no.1162917), is proud to present their first production, an all-female Henry V. 

This promises to be a very different retelling to commemorate 600 years since one of the most miraculous victories in British History: The Battle of Agincourt on St Crispin’s Day (25th October) 1415.

The choice of making women tell a story about war is designed to empower women and girls and give them a voice on stage and in the world. This also coincides with the MoD's report that women may serve in close combat roles by 2016 while we aim to prove that "Women can fight just as effectively as men."

Please watch our fundraising video to meet some members of the cast and to hear why we need your money! With a cast of 14, travel and accommodation to Edinburgh, venue hire, rehearsal space hire, costumes, props, travel expenses and, of course, paying the actors, this ambitious, epic retelling comes at a price!

We’re delighted to have performed two previews at the Edinburgh Festival in August at the lovely George Next Door L (venue 430), 9 George IV Bridge, Edinburgh EH1 1EE.

Our London run will be at the hauntingly beautiful and therefore entirely appropriate Peckham Asylum Chapel from Sunday 11th October to Thursday 15th October, as near as we could get it to 25th October!

Brought to you by Struts and Frets (S&F) Theatre: http://strutsandfrets.org.uk/henry-v-agincourt600/

story:
A little bit about Cirque Roots

Hi there! We are Cirque Roots, a grassroots artist collective started in 2011 with a vision to inspire the community to engage in circus-inspired arts.  We love to co-create in the community through conscious events, classes, and workshops.  

Cirque Roots is a magical place where we let our imaginations run free. 

Our classes provide a space for the Tucson community to participate in circus arts, stay in shape with alternative fitness and fun, and discover ways that they can get involved with performance art.  

We also have an active performance crew with a range of experience in circus, and have been collectively performing over the past six years.  We've directed and produced three original theatrical productions and currently have two more big projects in production, one of which is what this Indiegogo is ALL about! 

Let me tell you more...

About Alice OnLine (AOL)

"If you don't know where you are going, any road will get you there"

Honoring the 150th anniversary of Lewis Carroll’s children’s book Alice’s Adventure in Wonderland , Cirque Roots presents Alice On Line (AOL), a theater production scheduled for December 12, 2015 at the Tucson Museum of Art. 

AOL is a satire based on the connection between online social media and the ridiculous world of Wonderland. 

The setting is the Mad Hatter's Tea Party, where Alice is forced to explore the impact of being in a surreal environment and struggles with personal and social identity.  

Each character at the tea party embodies a different personality in wonderland, as would commonly be seen on social media, such as 

(1) the curious & innocent

(2) the paranoid conspiracy theorist  

(3) the creeper 

(4) the consumed consumer

(5) the devils advocate. 

The story is told through high-­flying stilt acrobatics, partner acrobatics, stilt dance, modern hoop dance, shadow screen dance and projection. Along with a live, roaming two­-person band offering additional funky fresh sound effects. 


Why the Indiegogo & Where Your Contributions GoGo

"If I had a world of my own, everything would be nonsense.  Nothing would be what it is, because everything would be what it isn't."

Well you see, we are here to ask for support from our community.  We love creating works of art for all to enjoy and the stakes (and budget) just got a little higher with this one.  

We have high aspirations for professional lighting and moving, mechanical props. 

THE ESSENTIAL PROP: a magic table, YES! MAGIC!

Without giving too much of the magic away, we’ll just say this: the major turn of events for Alice is when she grows and shrinks in size. This essential and intricate table will allow the illusion of growing and shrinking. 

Sounds exciting, huh?! :)

Okay, you want more…we can tell. 

Well, don’t tell anyone, but, this table will have a shadow screen/projector set up incorporated into it. How will this work you ask... you'll have to come and see it for yourself!  

Most of our perks include tickets to the show.

Aside from our magic table, we'll be contracting a support crew, and of course we’d love to be able to pay the cast for the many hours of practicing, rehearsing, and performing.  *Stay tuned for video updates of their progress!*

This tea party will come to LIFE with your help!! 

See the figure below for a break down of costs.



Thank you for checking out our Indiegogo and we appreciate your contribution of any kind.  We are thrilled to share our art with you, please follow us further at:

https://www.facebook.com/cirqueroots

https://instagram.com/cirqueroots/


Wanna Know Even More About AOL?

"I'm not crazy, my reality is just different than yours."

While Alice in Wonderland as source material is often used as an excuse for the surreal, Alice OnLine ​uses its source material to highlight the surreality of the Internet, through which modern youth are developing their personal and social identities. Just as Alice is swept along by the inexplicable logic of Wonderland, so are many modern youth internalizing the logic of the Internet as if it were an accurate microcosm of the world outside of the Internet.  The tea party, where much of ​AOL​ is set is an allegory to social media, where Alice as the embodiment of innocence is forced to deal with the various character types that thrive in environments such as Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and webboards. The Mad Hatter, unable to filter the limitless information available online for credibility is a conspiracy theorist; the March Hare represents the sexual predator; the Dormouse is consumed by social media and is thus detached from her present surroundings; and the Cheshire Cat is a troll and trickster. 

These are the role models for Alice in Wonderland, just as they are the role models for modern youth growing up in an increasingly pervasive Internet culture.

The cast of AOL is Paul Galbraith, Stephanie Cortes, Zoe Anderson, Leanne Rogers, and Aaron Farber. 

Our collective goal is to collaborate with qualified Tucson talent in physical theater, live music, moving scenery and magic props. All of the cast members professionally train and perform circus/theater. The collective skill of our cast members include professional training in stilting and theater with Carpetbag Brigade/Nemcatacoa teatro at The Global Stilt Congress; and acrobatic training with Acro Montreal, Acrogasm, and Dutch Acro. 

Paul Galbraith­­--scriptwriter, co­-producer, and actor for AOL ­­was the director of a troupe in Baltimore, MD that produced narrative burlesque shows confronting social issues with humor and eroticism, including Strip Club Time Machine’s examination of the historical reference points that produced strip club culture and Bra & Garter’s confrontation of institutionalized misogyny in the American criminal justice system.  

The musicians for AOL are Mik Garrison and Scott Kerr of ​Mik & Scott​, a funky Tucson band described as “funk soul jazz hip-­hop” that is perfect for this production. They convert common household items into musical instruments, and it is exactly what one would expect for the music at a tea party in Wonderland.  

The food and drinks are provided by Dante's Inferno, a fun and funky selection of tapas and creative cocktails will sweep you off of your feet. 

This will be our 3rd theatrical production at the Tucson Museum of Art.  The other two were Feather​, a Blackfoot tale of love, betrayal, and renewal; and ​The Conscience of Love​, a journey through the major emotions associated with love. We strive to leave the audience with an inspirational, positive message and question their own stories and values.

It's cool if you can't contribute money

There's other ways to help!

  • Volunteer!  Ticket sales, ushers, backstage help, set constructions, costumes, just let us know you're interested in being an AOL volunteer.
  • Spread the word!  Use indiegogo share tools, email, call, text your friends and family. Blog.
  • Like us!  On Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and in real life.

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Short summary

I am a San Francisco-based, freelance choreographer. I danced professionally with ballet companies around the country and now I teach ballet at ODC School and choreograph. I've choreographed five ballets in the past year to sold-out audiences, and this next season will be even more exciting!
   The Nymph's Lament is a quartet based on Monteverdi's Lamento dello Ninfa. I was chosen to be part of the Resident Artist Workshop at SafeHouse/Kunst-Stoff, and my supremely talented dancers will perform on February 7-8, 2015.
  I also was chosen to be part of ODC's Pilot Project. For this exclusive residency, I am going to be working on a ballet based on an African novel, "My Life in the Bush of Ghosts," by Amos Tutuola. I'm collaborating with composer/cellist Adam Young,  who is creating original music for the piece. The work is dramatic and fierce.

What We Need & What You Get

I'm asking for $3,250 to pay my artists and for rehearsal space. It breaks down to this:
Nymph's Lament: 5 dancers @ $12/hr for 25 hours = $1,500
Bush of Ghosts: 4 dancers @ $12/hr for 25 hours = $1,200
                               composer/musician $300
Studio rehearsal space: 25 hours (for Bush of Ghosts) @ $10/hr = $250

Total: $3,250

As a contributor, you get the satisfaction of helping some extremely talented artists. Depending on the amount of your contribution, you also will get to see the artists at work! Rehearsal invitations, post performance shmooze and free concert tickets. PLUS, you can have private lessons with the choreographer and a special thank you in the official programs.

The Impact

Funding for the arts has dramatically decreased recently. My dancers and I have trained for our profession since we were small children. They deserve to be paid! Your contribution will go directly to the dancers. I am paying the dancers before anything else and will pay for studio space myself unless the campaign gets fully funded. You can have a direct impact on the lives of Nicole, Demetria, Julie, Sophia, Stephen, Annalise, Joshua, Cole, Vincent, Ilana and Adam. They are all talented artists who make their living from dancing. Please help me pay them fairly.

Risks & Challenges

These shows are going to happen.  All of your contributions will go towards making the process smoother. I've been working on the choreography for these works for months (way before we go into the studio). Creating and performing is challenging, but that's why we artists love it!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you were planning on giving me a holiday gift or a birthday present-- contribute here instead! Even $5 can help us on our way. If this isn't a time that you find yourself able to contribute financially then please share this with your friends! And consider coming to a performance! We'd love to see you.
story_txt:
Short summaryI am a San Francisco-based, freelance choreographer. I danced professionally with ballet companies around the country and now I teach ballet at ODC School and choreograph. I've choreographed five ballets in the past year to sold-out audiences, and this next season will be even more exciting!   The Nymph's Lament is a quartet based on Monteverdi's Lamento dello Ninfa. I was chosen to be part of the Resident Artist Workshop at SafeHouse/Kunst-Stoff, and my supremely talented dancers will perform on February 7-8, 2015.  I also was chosen to be part of ODC's Pilot Project. For this exclusive residency, I am going to be working on a ballet based on an African novel, "My Life in the Bush of Ghosts," by Amos Tutuola. I'm collaborating with composer/cellist Adam Young,  who is creating original music for the piece. The work is dramatic and fierce. 
  What We Need & What You GetI'm asking for $3,250 to pay my artists and for rehearsal space. It breaks down to this:Nymph's Lament: 5 dancers @ $12/hr for 25 hours = $1,500Bush of Ghosts: 4 dancers @ $12/hr for 25 hours = $1,200                                composer/musician $300Studio rehearsal space: 25 hours (for Bush of Ghosts) @ $10/hr = $250Total: $3,250As a contributor, you get the satisfaction of helping some extremely talented artists. Depending on the amount of your contribution, you also will get to see the artists at work! Rehearsal invitations, post performance shmooze and free concert tickets. PLUS, you can have private lessons with the choreographer and a special thank you in the official programs. 
  The ImpactFunding for the arts has dramatically decreased recently. My dancers and I have trained for our profession since we were small children. They deserve to be paid! Your contribution will go directly to the dancers. I am paying the dancers before anything else and will pay for studio space myself unless the campaign gets fully funded. You can have a direct impact on the lives of Nicole, Demetria, Julie, Sophia, Stephen, Annalise, Joshua, Cole, Vincent, Ilana and Adam. They are all talented artists who make their living from dancing. Please help me pay them fairly.
  Risks & ChallengesThese shows are going to happen.  All of your contributions will go towards making the process smoother. I've been working on the choreography for these works for months (way before we go into the studio). Creating and performing is challenging, but that's why we artists love it! 
  Other Ways You Can HelpIf you were planning on giving me a holiday gift or a birthday present-- contribute here instead! Even $5 can help us on our way. If this isn't a time that you find yourself able to contribute financially then please share this with your friends! And consider coming to a performance! We'd love to see you.

story:
Alyce Finwall Dance Theater will be presenting a new dance/theater work for the San Francisco International Arts Festival at Fort Mason.  This new work, titled “RUNE” is loosely based off the Norse myth of Ragnarök, which portends many disasters in the human world and is then repopulated by two human survivors.  The piece is not a literal re-creation of the myth; rather, it is an exploration of the emotional elements that make up the story and its subliminal metaphors.  It is an abstracted language, one of mysterious patterns and meanings reflecting the turmoil and anxiety, humor and love in our modern lives.  The piece utilizes spoken word in both Norwegian and English interwoven throughout. Much of the movement is performed in silence, or to a fantastically avant-garde soundscape by Bay Area musicians “glou glou” (Gretchen Jude and Arjun Mendiratta), and composition for piano by the Hong Kong based composer Lo Chao.  Performing in “RUNE” are the amazing dancers Kristin Damrow and Ashley Brown.

We are looking to raise $2,000 to help pay for artist salaries, studio rental and production costs.

Other Ways You Can Help

Come see our performance at the San Francisco International Arts Festival: 

http://www.sfiaf.org/alyce_finwall_dance_theater_rune

story:
I am Steve Karol, author of "One Hundred Horses".  I have a degree in architecture and a passion for the arts. You can read about me and see my art and photography on my website Steve-Karol.artistwebsites.com.

The story starts as an autobiographical piece that ends up taking you on an epic journey through China during WWII. It's a contrast of the beauty created by cultural collaboration and the ugliness created by war. 

We are currently working on a production for three performances in the 2015 Kansas City Fringe Festival. The local Chinese Community have fallen in love with the story. One member is translating the script into Chinese for a future production in China.

Funds are needed for technology upgrades in software and computers for the video backdrop to the story. Stills from the video can be seen on my website. Funds will also be used for other production cost including marketing, fees, materials and technicians. 

The goal is to raise seed money to help create a production company worthy of Broadway and eventually a motion picture. The Kansas City Fringe Festival is the first stepping stone for this endeavor.

story:
Art Moves Global Dança Exchange

Dear Art Mover,

I'm a Maine native mother of two adult sons who opened a dance studio in my hometown in 1988 and then purchased the three-story building in 1993. Hundreds of dance classes, rehearsals, performances and festivals later, the building needs some TLC. After the recession and two hip replacements, I had to move into the building and sell my home of 20 years at a loss. I am lucky to be able to walk and dance again, but I have yet to recover financially. It's time to reach beyond my generous family and friends for help.

Properly welcoming and supporting dancers near and far – that is my dream. I have poured my heart and soul into this dream, into this building, and I am grateful that it has in turn fostered the creativity of so many...and now, the many includes a bevy of dancers and choreographers south of the border who are eager to share with our local community, which has brought other blessings to the building – musicians, visual and healing artists. Please help this continue far into the future.

It will cost upwards of $100,000 to do this -- roof and plumbing leaks, electrical and thermal upgrades, general repairs. If you donate to the building, then you will become part of it -- one way or another! Every dollar raised will go into repairing and improving the building and supporting quality exchange for artists who stay here.

Having a concert dance studio in a small town has been no easy task. So many people have studied, created, expressed and discovered themselves here. The positivity is palpable. It is so important that this continues to grow both in our neighborhood and far beyond our borders. Nothing is more important right now than making everlasting connections with people from a culture different than our own. It's how we discover our best selves.

I know that tackling this project will unleash some surprises. After dealing with an old building like this for nearly 30 years, nothing scares me for too long. Here in independent, do-it-yourself Western Maine, we have superb local contractors and skilled and responsible people who value quality.

story:
We love Pinter!  You'll love Pinter when you see this show!

This is a unique production.  We've remained true to the original vision of the author by staging the play in the 1970s, the era it was written for.

We're focussing on the brilliantly complex and tormented characters, and the lush and deep dialogues that make Pinter such a joy to act, and to watch.


Why are we asking for money?

We need to pay $2500 for the deposit on the theater..

That's where you come in.

The theater needs the money up front, or we can't do the show.  We know people will love this show.  We know they (you!) want to see it.  And we know people will pay $28 ($25 on Sunday!) for a ticket.

So we're asking you to simply buy your ticket now, so we can guarantee the theater the rental fee.  That's fair, isn't it?

And since we're asking for you to buy a little early, we're saying thanks by knocking $5 - $8 off each ticket when you purchase through our Indiegogo campaign.

Of course, if you can't see the show but want to see it happen anyway (we LOVE people who support the arts this way) we've got other perks just to say thanks for your support.

What's so special about this show?

Glad you asked! Here's the short list:

  • Pinter
  • A great cast (did I mention that three of us are graduates of PCPA?
  • Live Motown music. A live band onstage playing Motown music during the play!
  • Pinter!

Find out all about the cast and the show on our web site: betrayalnoho.com.

What are you waiting for?

We're looking forward to seeing you at the show!

Choose any one of the perks to select the night you want to come.

Remember, if you can't make it to the show, you can still make it happen!  There are perks for you, too.  

And if you just can't part with your cash, at the very least, share us with your networks.  We will be grateful!

* Command performance perk date is subject to cast availability. If you purchase this perk, we will work with you to find a date that works for the cast and your event.

story:
Synopsis

OF LETO explores the perennial tension between love and duty. It surrounds the story of two estranged siblings lost in a mid-century Minnesota town, surrounded by friends, social expectations, costly secrets and a war. Adopted by two different families from different social castes, James and Sarah grow up as friends without knowledge of their relation .As time often shows us, love and duty creates havoc in our lives, and when James and Sarah are forced to part ways by an overbearing, secretive father, James is left to choose: is life better not knowing?"

                               

What is This "Thesis?"

This project came to mind after working on a similar senior creative project, Invincible by OF LETO's orchestrator, Drew Nichols. Though this project is not a full production, the impact and labor required are just as intense - if not more! Our production team and rehearsal schedule are designed for efficiency and effectiveness: 12 rehearsals in three weeks starting in October 2015! Same goes for our budget: $5,000 designated to creative resources. We want display the best possible work using the best possible talent in the best possible of environments: student work development at the collegiate level.

  • This thesis is a staged concert reading: there are no sets, lights, props or fancy backdrops. Blocking is minimal and the use of a narrator is employed to guide the audience and plot.
  • Focus is driven to the story and the effectiveness of music. REMEMBER: this campaign is designed to fund the education of those involved by allowing us to focus on the foundation of an effective production: story and music!

Why This Matters

Creative institutions are experiencing budget cuts nationwide, and it directly affects the ability of students to reach their full potential and receive a full education. This production is a way to combat those who diminish the importance of the fine arts and its impact on the future of children, students, and life!

  • You are supporting the first-of-its-kind collegiate, cross-discipline collaboration within the School of Music and likely Arizona State University!
  • 40 dedicated and talented students will be able to showcase their talents and help create a network of determined and disciplined fine arts collegiate, professional and education individuals.
  • Your support helps advocate for the new age of contemporary art in music and theatre.

Budget

Each production on Broadway, Off-Broadway, Off-Off Broadway and even in Arizona has a producer - or several. We'd like you to be one of ours! Our budget is very structured to ensure that we can get the most from every donation and help advance education in performance art and practice, student work development, team development, and the creative process. With your donation, the following are possible:

  • Full orchestration for 12 instruments coupled with 16 voices!!!
  • Printing of all scores and librettos, advertisements, and programs.
  • Marketing materials and promotional items
  • Professional filming
  • Professional audio recording
  • Meals during final dress and full run-throughs

story:
A  BIT ABOUT ME:

I am a dance artist from Israel, a daughter of Russian immigrants, currently living in Berlin. I grew up in a country where distinct cultures, identities and languages constantly conflicted and resulted in misunderstandings and confrontations. This made me reflect on my own contrasting backgrounds, making me consciously sensitive on how my cultural identity shapes the way I act in the world and understand it. My interest in intercultural communication has driven my artistic work towards the interplay between cultural identity and potential conflicts. In the past few years, as a dancer, teacher and choreographer, I have developed a dance education program for children in the Lake Studios Berlin- a dance/art and residency center and created a dance project at a refugees’ shelter in Friedrichshagen, Berlin.

ABOUT THE PROJECT :               

Next January I will work for a period of three months in “Multicorps Choreography Centre” in Benin, West Africa. It is an important dance center in the city of Cotonou, striving to establish and develop art exchanges between the local scene and dancers from abroad. I was invited by Marcel Gbeffa, the artistic director of the center, to create a dance project that will explore movement as a form of intercultural communication. Intercultural communication occurs when individuals or groups of different linguistic and cultural origins interact. I use movement as a form of a nonverbal communication and an important way to learn and reflect on how one's cultural systems such as language, medicine or technology work in relation to other cultural systems. While working with children and professional dancers from the center, I will discover the rich and inspiring Beninese culture, vodun religion and traditional dance forms, which will become the basis of our exchange.

PART I - WORKSHOPS FOR CHILDREN: 

I will give dance classes to children of various ages and social/economical backgrounds, while learning their traditional movement and music styles. I will then integrate the shared movement language, with Israeli folk dance, partnering skills, improvisation tools and circle dances. Rather than focusing on a specific aesthetic, we will use common human patterns, such as walking, jumping, running or rolling. These elements will support children's coordination, body connection, tolerance, curiosity, self-confidence and awareness. While communicating through movement we can embody our diversities and find a meeting point. I believe that underneath all our cultural and social differences, lies the body and the dance we can create together.

PART II - ART RESIDENCY:

In the second half of the period I will develop a dance piece in collaboration with professional dancers from the center. The body of work will be based on the material explored in the children’s workshops: partnering and improvisation techniques together with circle/traditional dances. Through this we will investigate the way two or more dancers of different social and cultural backgrounds relate to one another, and offer an alternative path to deal with potential conflicts. I find it fascinating how children follow their instincts and intuition, displaying directness in exposing feelings and thoughts and wonder how much can we as adult dancers learn from their ways of communicating. The piece will be presented at “Centre Choréopgraphique Multicorps” at the end of the residency, and in Berlin, in October 2017 (As well as in potential theaters/venues in Benin).

 

 

WHY SHOULD YOU SUPPORT THIS PROJECT:

  • Dance is proven to help children mature physically, emotionally, socially, and cognitively. Therefore I believe each child should be able to access movement activities, regardless of his/her financial abilities.
  • A cross cultural exchange can develop tolerance, curiosity and awareness of the ‘Other’ on a social, as well as personal level.
  • Dance has the potential to cultivate an ongoing dialogue which develops a social project through art. The meeting point between my background and the Beninese tradition will enrich my artistic and social work.
  • Through this exchange I would observe conflicts as opportunities for potential mutual growth, rather than an end point.

 

YOUR CONTRIBUTION WILL HELP  FUND:

1. Travel and visa costs from Berlin to Benin

2. Residency costs at the “Centre Choréopgraphique Multicorps” (studio rental)

3. Dancers salary (rehearsals, travel and performances)

4. Equipment and props required for the work (music, art and craft supplies)

       

OTHER WAYS YOU COULD HELP:

Everything helps!

Seriously, EVERYTHING! Believe me, I completely understand if you cannot financially contribute, but if you find this project inspiring and you want to help make it happen, here are some FREE ways to do so:

        •        Tell your friends and family

        •        Share it on Facebook, Twitter or Instagram                            

        •        Plop it in an email

        •        Send it to your colleagues at work

        •        Etc.

Let's make some change together!

I cannot thank you enough…

 

Thanks   !    Merci   !   Danke   !   Спасибо   !   תודה

story:
Proudly representing the North West

It’s official and it’s a big deal - Ludus Youth Dance Company (LYDC) has been selected, from talented youth dance companies across the UK, to represent the North West and perform at the National U Dance Festival 2017 at the Birmingham Hippodrome from 13th to 16th July.

Why it’s a Big Deal

This talented, energetic, creative and committed group of young people have worked incredibly hard for this amazing achievement, so that’s already a big deal. But what’s also a big deal is the topical dance theatre piece they’ll perform called ‘Back to the Workhouse?’ by Lindsey Brocklebank. At a time when young people are statistically less likely to vote, the piece aims to get young people involved in political debate

Giving young people a voice

So, this is a BIG DEAL because it aims to give young people A VOICE.

What’s the deal for you?

By getting involved with this project, you will not only help to get LYDC to Birmingham to take part in this high profile event, allowing them to:

  • perform and showcase their talents
  • learn and share experiences with other talented young dancers from across the UK in classes, workshops, career sessions and social activities

you’ll be:

  • giving valuable support to the arts
  • nurturing young people’s talent and skill development
  • creating career development opportunities
  • encouraging young people to be more politically aware

What’s needed to make this happen?

Ludus Dance is a charity (reg no 1144163) that works to challenge, inspire and engage people through dance across Lancashire. You can help us raise £900 towards attendance fees and travel to enable LYDC’s young members to participate.

The company is not funded other than by the young participants themselves, so each and every one of them will be working hard to raise as much money as possible through loads of other fundraising events too.

Thank you

Let’s raise as much as we can to get them to Birmingham to fly the flag for #young people #talent #arts #Lancashire. Thank you for your donation. Ludus Dance is also part of a government scheme to encourage private giving to arts and culture, so every £1 you donate will be matched pound for pound.

What you get

We’ve put together a little package of 'perks' that will recognise your contribution and express our and LYDC's thanks.

Whether you are able to donate or not, we'd be hugely grateful if you would share the campaign with others who might be able to help. Or perhaps you can help in some other way? Please get in touch!

Risks & Challenges

This is one element of LYDC's fundraising plan for the U Dance project. We are doing whatever we can to help them secure success in these activities by providing support and setting achievable targets. However, we recognise that there is always a risk that the overall financial target will not be met. In this (unlikely) scenario, we would work with the group to explore additional funding streams or options.
story_txt:
Proudly representing the North WestIt’s official and it’s a big deal - Ludus Youth Dance Company (LYDC) has been selected, from talented youth dance companies across the UK, to represent the North West and perform at the National U Dance Festival 2017 at the Birmingham Hippodrome from 13th to 16th July.Why it’s a Big DealThis talented, energetic, creative and committed group of young people have worked incredibly hard for this amazing achievement, so that’s already a big deal. But what’s also a big deal is the topical dance theatre piece they’ll perform called ‘Back to the Workhouse?’ by Lindsey Brocklebank. At a time when young people are statistically less likely to vote, the piece aims to get young people involved in political debateGiving young people a voiceSo, this is a BIG DEAL because it aims to give young people A VOICE.What’s the deal for you?By getting involved with this project, you will not only help to get LYDC to Birmingham to take part in this high profile event, allowing them to:
perform and showcase their talents
learn and share experiences with other talented young dancers from across the UK in classes, workshops, career sessions and social activities
you’ll be:
giving valuable support to the arts
nurturing young people’s talent and skill development
creating career development opportunities
encouraging young people to be more politically aware
What’s needed to make this happen?Ludus Dance is a charity (reg no 1144163) that works to challenge, inspire and engage people through dance across Lancashire. You can help us raise £900 towards attendance fees and travel to enable LYDC’s young members to participate.The company is not funded other than by the young participants themselves, so each and every one of them will be working hard to raise as much money as possible through loads of other fundraising events too.Thank youLet’s raise as much as we can to get them to Birmingham to fly the flag for #young people #talent #arts #Lancashire. Thank you for your donation. Ludus Dance is also part of a government scheme to encourage private giving to arts and culture, so every £1 you donate will be matched pound for pound.What you getWe’ve put together a little package of 'perks' that will recognise your contribution and express our and LYDC's thanks.Whether you are able to donate or not, we'd be hugely grateful if you would share the campaign with others who might be able to help. Or perhaps you can help in some other way? Please get in touch!Risks & ChallengesThis is one element of LYDC's fundraising plan for the U Dance project. We are doing whatever we can to help them secure success in these activities by providing support and setting achievable targets. However, we recognise that there is always a risk that the overall financial target will not be met. In this (unlikely) scenario, we would work with the group to explore additional funding streams or options.

story:
Michael Allen Harrison and Alan Berg established Harrison-Berg Presents to bring  their award winning musical Soul Harmony to a national audience. Soul Harmony is a transformative musical in the traditon of Showboat, South Pacific and La Cage au Folles. Bringing the classic songs of Deborah, Sonny and the Orioles to life for a new generation. With a score of new award winning songs Soul Harmony takes a deep dive into the racism of its time and resonates profoundly with our own with a shattering and healing true story. 

  • We are asking your help in the casting and production costs as we look forward to our first national premier. We believe Soul Harmony is heading straight for its ultimate goal, to entertain with a story that is life changing for the audience and returns Sonny Til to his rightful place in musical history. Both Deborah Chessler and Sonny Til's families have been at the heart of the creation of Soul Harmony. Sonny's grandson De'Sean Dooley portrays Sonny and has his grandfather's musical power. Monica Rodrigues portrayal of Deborah Chessler has been called 'spot-on' by Deborah's daughter Wendy, and historic R&B radio host, and archivist, Charlie Horner. 
  • Help to reach a national audience and support our vision to help heal the world. We believe many will find their own story in Soul Harmony. The show entertains on a theatrically extraordinary level, presents important history and communicates directly to people's heart's and the concerns of today. 

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Our goal is to raise $50,000 in funding for preproduction costs, cast salaries, set and costume design and creation, publishing musical charts and scripts. 
  • To thank you for helping us create and present Soul Harmony we have created fabulous perks that include great seats for you, giving the gift of students attending Soul Harmony. You can enjoy an evening with our artists in your home or selected setting,  receive private recordings from newly opened Sonny Til archives, and the original cast album. Ten Percent of all funds raised will be given to a local West Chester food bank. 
  • All funds raised will be used for the West Chester production of Soul Harmony.

The Impact

  • Soul Harmony not only brings to the stage an extraordinary and largely lost story of American history of the Orioles rise to change modern music, but reveals the game changing partnership between a Jewish woman and five great African-American artists. It challenges racism and anti-semitism, as Deborah and the Orioles did. There is no story like this, and you can give it life and power on the stage. Michael Allen Harrison and Alan Berg have a consistent record of musical successes. Between them they have received 15 musical theater awards. Their three shows have all had a powerful impact bringing hope and joy to thousands and they both truly believe Soul Harmony and it's powerful music will deliver an inspiring message for change.

Risks & Challenges

We are in a process of bringing together our first national production. We have chosen our site carefully and the people at Uptown! Entertainment Alliance in West Chester are very creative and friendly partners. We have developed a 'brain trust' to step forward. Michael Allen Harrison brings extensive experience in major productions, and Alan Berg brings major project management experience. We wrote the show, we believe deeply in it. As does our cast. We need your support to give Soul Harmony a chance to change lives and create an evening that make people understand and believe in the power of theater. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We invite everyone to share the message of our show, to go to the Uptown Website and buy tickets now, and to let us know if you know people who would like to go and need a ticket.

With extreme gratitude,

Michael and Alan

story:
This is who we are and what we do...

FALLEN ANGEL by LIAM RUDDEN starring CHRIS O'MARA

Award winning writer and director Liam Rudden (Brighton Fringe Best Theatrical Performance Award) is to premiere his first new play for three years at the 2017 Brighton Fringe.

Fallen Angel, a disturbing new supernatural thriller, will receive its world premiere at Sweet Venues' St Andrew’s Church, Waterloo Street, Hove, running from 5-13 May (not 11) 2017, at 8pm nightly.

Beat. Beat. Beat. Do you believe in faeries? Beat. Beat. Beat. Meet Angel, he does, but not the type that play at the end of your garden. Beat. Beat. Beat. The faeries he has encountered are far more sinister, dark and manipulative. Beat. Beat. Beat. And he should know, they've tortured him for the last 500 years.

Inspired by the age-old legend The Faerie Boy of Leith, Fallen Angel stars Chris O'Mara in his professional acting stage debut, and is a LRStageworks & Aramoc Co production in association with Sweet Venues. The team is completed by assistant director Edward Cory and soundscape artist Erik Grieve, both of whom worked on the award-winning production of Thief. 

Not suitable for under 16.

Tickets go on sale from www.sweetvenues.com in March 2017

Social Media: Follow @FallenAngelPlay on Twitter #DoYouBelieveInFaeries #FallUnderHisSpell

Like Fallen Angel on Facebook www.facebook.com/FallenAngelPlay

 

Meet the Fallen Angel family... 

  • Liam Rudden: Writer and Director

Liam Rudden wrote and directed Thief, which won the Brighton Fringe Best Theatrical Performance Award in 2014. Thief later played Edinburgh, London, Orkney and was invited to appear on New York's Broadway, where it won huge approval.

Previously, Liam directed Glenn Chandler's five-star play Killers, which also debuted at the Brighton Fringe (2013). His other works include the award-winning Silence In Court and the sell-out productions Conflict In Court and I Ran With The Gang: The Story of the Original Bay City Roller.

Liam says, “Fallen Angel is a piece I have been working on for three year now. Like Sailor, the protagonist in Thief, he is a dark creation and never quite what he appears. The piece is a supernatural thriller... or is it?

"I always knew I wanted a dancer to play the role, but a dancer who could act. When Chris and I met on the set of the film Miser's Dream earlier this year, I knew I had found the person to bring Angel to life."

Follow Liam on Twitter @LiamRudden Like on Facebook www.facebook.com/LiamRuddenTimeline

  • Chris O'Mara: Angel

Dancer and actor Chris O'Mara makes his stage acting debut in Fallen Angel, however, Chris is no stranger to acting, with film credits that include IronStar film titles BloodLoss, The Clearing and Best Friends Come in Boxes. Chris will also feature in Ironstar's upcoming sci-fi thriller Tellurian.

Other film work includes Kingdom: Fall of Illandrieal, and the musical movie Miser's Dream, both due for release shortly.

Being cast as Angel, is something very important to Chris who explains, 

"Fallen Angel is not only my professional stage acting debut, it is an opportunity to finally take control of my future and become the person I have dreamed of since I was a child.
It's also a chance to show my ability. It's about collaboration, combining my contemporary dance background with acting and theatre to create something unique.

"Theatre, of course, is taking a battering at the moment through funding cuts and it's difficult not to feel defeated already. Knowing that the public, our 'Angels' are still supporting the arts, and in particular Fallen Angel, is comforting and what encourages us to keep creating difficult, yet engaging, work. 

"From a personal point of view, it's a 'Yes, we believe in you. We support you and we want you to succeed.' We don't hear that enough in this line of work.

"Fallen Angel isn't just a play. It's not one man on a stage convincing an audience to come on a journey with him for an hour or so. It's not just a script, it's not just a character. It's a reflection on who we are as people, as society. 

"It's an escape from reality, whilst looking viewing it from afar and from the moment it  begins until hours, or even days after it finishes, audiences will feel more alive and emotionally heightened than they may have ever before. 

"It's an extreme ride. And it's one that we feel utterly compelled to share. By becoming part of our Fallen Angel family, you can feel the rush too and help others join the experience.

"You'll also make a wee 10-year-old Arbroath boy, dressed as a monkey for the local panto  reach those dreams of becoming the person he also wanted to be. Not everyone has a faerie to help make their dreams come true, I hope I might have some Angels."

Follow Chris on Twitter @aramoc Like on Facebook www.facebook.com/chrisomaraartist

  • Sweet Venues: Fringe Venues and Partner

Sweet Venues is dedicated to expanding the view and are more than just a venue space. You’ll find Sweet Venues in cities around the UK with spaces at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, Brighton Fringe and in Dundee. Whether you visit Brighton, Edinburgh or Dundee you’ll find high quality venue spaces with excellent facilities in central locations, programming the very best in local, national and international theatre.

From physical theatre and dance to new drama. From children’s workshops to open mic nights. From world music to mind-reading. Whatever you’re looking for, you’ll find it all at Sweet.

JD Henshaw, artistic director of Sweet says, “We are as proud as we are excited to be bringing Fallen Angel to premier at Brighton Fringe.
“The opportunity to help produce new work from the Brighton award-winning team behind Thief allows us to promote the core strengths of debuting new theatre at England’s largest arts festival, strong writing, challenging performance, and the joy of working with a company that embodies the ethos of Fringe theatre.
“We look forward to introducing our audiences to Angel and his world.”


Follow Sweet Venues on Twitter @SweetVenues 

Like on Facebook www.facebook.com/SweetVenues

LRStageworks is an award-winning not for profit theatre production house specialising in immersive, intimate Fringe theatre. Visit www.lrstageworks.com 

Follow on Twitter @LRStageworks Like in Facebook www.facebook.com/LRStageworks

 

What we plan to do...

Funding a new production is never easy, especially when you are doing so from your own pockets. We therefor rely on people who believe in what we do to help us, and in return we ensure that support is repaid in kind. 

If you believe everyone should have access to theatre regardless of age, class or social status, then read on. We produce small-scale intimate theatrical experiences that entertain, challenge and create discussion in equal measure. 

The money raised here will go towards travel and accommodation as well as start up fees - registration, public liability insurance, press and marketing- for our 2017 Fringe run in Brighton, where the show will premiere.

Fallen Angel will then continue to a three week run at the Edinburgh Fringe in August and hopefully further afield in October. 

Please look at our benefits and see if there is any way you can help us fulfil our dreams.

story:
A New Collaboration

Nearly two years ago, director Jess Chayes and playwright Adam R. Burnett began a dialogue of collaboration. After years of mutual admiration, Adam and Jess were eager to build a new work together utilizing the processes they’d developed through their respective theatre companies – Buran Theatre and The Assembly.  By combing creative forces, Adam and Jess imagine this project as a Super Group collaboration; The Traveling Wilburys of NYC independent theatre.

With the support of The Performance Project at University Settlement, Jess and Adam will present the very beginnings of this new project, featuring performers Kate Schroeder and Ramon Torres, and designers Ethan Gould, Emma Rivera, and David Pym.

With the landscape and geological history of Kansas and the Flint Hills as a feeder for the language, HOLIDAYS IN/ COYOTE originates from the vacation trends of Burnett’s childhood. Unable to afford proper vacations, his family would check into the Topeka Holidome for long weekends – an affordable resort-like hotel for the middle-class that proliferated throughout the 1970’s and 80’s in the Midwest before disappearing in the late 90’s. Equally influenced by the interiors of the sitcom Roseanne, the only home and family on television that represented the lower middle-class American experience while simultaneously presenting progressive platforms, Jess and Adam will explore this work through the lens of "coming of age" in the middlest part of the country.

Jess and Adam are raising funds to pay creative collaborators and subsidize ticket prices, ensuring access to everyone who wants to attend this initial work-in-progress showing.

This is a massive project that will continue development throughout the summer at a residency at Lake Tofte in Minnesota. Your early support will ensure that the artists are able to continue work and fully realize the production within the coming years.

 

The Risks & The Need for Support

Creating experimental theatre comes with a gamut of risks, especially when the creation is unsupported institutionally. Jess and Adam have spent the past year applying for opportunities to develop the work and they are grateful that University Settlement has provided them with a week to workshop and share our findings. At such an early stage, they are still in exploratory mode, discovering what this thing is: not quite a play, not quite autobiography; the main character is a Holidome that transforms into a Coyote and then Amelia Earhart, and multiple characters never say word at all. There is a pool that licks itself. And a glacier that arrives in the parking lot.

These are the wild, large and poetic occurrences that shape the world. We can only discover their full identity and potential by getting on our feet, into the rehearsal room, and then presenting our findings to an audience.

Adam and Jess arrive at this project with over two decades between them of creating, producing and presenting new performance works in NYC. The challenges of self-producing are intimately known, but they also know this is often the only way challenging new work can be realized.
