story:
And flights of angels sing thee to thy rest!

Dan Owenby.  Laura Edwards Root. Gerry Diftler.

If you love Knoxville theatre or have performed on local stages for many years, you have probably worked with and respected one of these wonderful people.

Let me tell you about them.

Dan was the actor's actor. He worked with everyone and always took it upon himself to create social opportunities for the cast, especially out of town actors. He played anything and everything and his sheer joy at being on stage was infectious.  He used to wear a shirt reading 'The Happiest Actor in the World'. And he was.

Laura was, simply, the funniest woman I've ever known. She could turn even the dullest scripts into laugh fests with her off beat line readings and quirky stage presence. Her generosity of spirit and willingness to pitch in meant so much to this theatre, She had stepped away from the stage but I was hoping to lure her back. Laura was serving as a board member of Flying Anvil Theatre when she unexpectedly passed away in 2013. 

Gerry is a local legend who was instrumental in getting the first community theatre off the ground. From New York, she brought a new professionalism (and a very sophisticated sense of style) to the area - as an actor, director and producer. A natural raconteuse and impresaria (she would have approved of those words, I think!) Gerry taught us all to think bigger and aspire to more.

WHAT WE NEED:

We'd like to do these rooms up right - with first class lighted make up mirrors, plenty of costume hanging space and comfortable chairs. Our green room will be furnished with modern furniture and kitchen equipment. (Actors run on coffee, you know,) We'll add custom designed plaques with info on our honorees. We've budgeted $4000 per room. 

THANK YOU

Anyone who donates will be invited to take a video tour of the finished spaces on You Tube. We'll post videos of our progress and our dedication ceremony.

Large donors ($500 or more) will be invited to the dedication ceremony, date to be announced later,

If you donate because you know one or more of our honorees, please leave us a story about them in your comments, We'll include them in our dedication ceremony, crediting you.

Funds will go directly to painting, equipping and furnishing the rooms. Any excess will be used to further Flying Anvil Theatre's programming. (Check out flyinganviltheatre.com)

THE IMPACT

If you're an Knoxville actor, you know how fragmented the community is and how seldom we get together to reflect on our shared experiences and history. We hope that the plaques on the door of each room remind all of us that we are part of a greater community with a long history - that we are all connected and how we treat one another is our greatest legacy.   

We are so grateful for our beautiful new home at 1300 Rocky Hill Rd and we will do great things there. But we want to imbue each room with meaning. You can help us do that by honoring these wonderful performers.

 

Risks & Challenges

If we don't raise a penny, we will still honor Dan, Gerry and Laura by naming these rooms after them.  But we want the spaces to be special, so we hope you'll help however you can.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us get the word out by sharing this campaign. Use the Indiegogo share tools. Tell people about it. And if you would like to host a fundraiser for one of these actors, let us know. We'll help you make it happen.

And remember - we want your stories about Dan, Laura and Gerry. Please share in the comments. 

THANK YOU!

Jayne Morgan and the Flying Anvil Theatre Board of Directors.
story_txt:
And flights of angels sing thee to thy rest!
Dan Owenby.  Laura Edwards Root. Gerry Diftler.
If you love Knoxville theatre or have performed on local stages for many years, you have probably worked with and respected one of these wonderful people.
Let me tell you about them.
Dan was the actor's actor. He worked with everyone and always took it upon himself to create social opportunities for the cast, especially out of town actors. He played anything and everything and his sheer joy at being on stage was infectious.  He used to wear a shirt reading 'The Happiest Actor in the World'. And he was.
Laura was, simply, the funniest woman I've ever known. She could turn even the dullest scripts into laugh fests with her off beat line readings and quirky stage presence. Her generosity of spirit and willingness to pitch in meant so much to this theatre, She had stepped away from the stage but I was hoping to lure her back. Laura was serving as a board member of Flying Anvil Theatre when she unexpectedly passed away in 2013. 
Gerry is a local legend who was instrumental in getting the first community theatre off the ground. From New York, she brought a new professionalism (and a very sophisticated sense of style) to the area - as an actor, director and producer. A natural raconteuse and impresaria (she would have approved of those words, I think!) Gerry taught us all to think bigger and aspire to more.
WHAT WE NEED:
We'd like to do these rooms up right - with first class lighted make up mirrors, plenty of costume hanging space and comfortable chairs. Our green room will be furnished with modern furniture and kitchen equipment. (Actors run on coffee, you know,) We'll add custom designed plaques with info on our honorees. We've budgeted $4000 per room. 

THANK YOU
Anyone who donates will be invited to take a video tour of the finished spaces on You Tube. We'll post videos of our progress and our dedication ceremony.
Large donors ($500 or more) will be invited to the dedication ceremony, date to be announced later,
If you donate because you know one or more of our honorees, please leave us a story about them in your comments, We'll include them in our dedication ceremony, crediting you.
Funds will go directly to painting, equipping and furnishing the rooms. Any excess will be used to further Flying Anvil Theatre's programming. (Check out flyinganviltheatre.com)

THE IMPACT
If you're an Knoxville actor, you know how fragmented the community is and how seldom we get together to reflect on our shared experiences and history. We hope that the plaques on the door of each room remind all of us that we are part of a greater community with a long history - that we are all connected and how we treat one another is our greatest legacy.   
We are so grateful for our beautiful new home at 1300 Rocky Hill Rd and we will do great things there. But we want to imbue each room with meaning. You can help us do that by honoring these wonderful performers.
 

Risks & Challenges
If we don't raise a penny, we will still honor Dan, Gerry and Laura by naming these rooms after them.  But we want the spaces to be special, so we hope you'll help however you can.

Other Ways You Can Help
Please help us get the word out by sharing this campaign. Use the Indiegogo share tools. Tell people about it. And if you would like to host a fundraiser for one of these actors, let us know. We'll help you make it happen.
And remember - we want your stories about Dan, Laura and Gerry. Please share in the comments. 
THANK YOU!
Jayne Morgan and the Flying Anvil Theatre Board of Directors.

story:
Who are we and what's The Local?

We founded Try This At Home Theatre during our third year of study at the University of Sheffield when we had the idea of writing a one hour comedic musical about the internet, entitled 'Character Limit'. The show previewed at 2014 Platform Performance Festival in Sheffield where it won 'Best Act', before heading up to Edinburgh for a ten date run at C Venues, where it received a 5 star review from Broadway Baby.*

At the same time we heard that Dom's local, The Alexandra, had been shut down to be converted into flats. In the following months, we learned more about the shocking rate of UK pub closures as well as the efforts made by some to save their locals, and were inspired to write a new show about community, loss and adapting to change.

What We Need & What You Get

From coaches to venue hire, accommodation to construction of A COLLAPSABLE BAR ON WHEELS!, there are a lot of things to pay for in order to get a show to the Fringe. This run will cost us an arm and a leg but with your help we can put a significant dent in the cost.

And if not for us, do it for the pubs! And if not for the pubs, do it for the perks! That's right, we're offering some adorably drink-themed perks to our backers, ranging from album downloads and signed CDs, right up to free tickets and a signed and bound copy of the script. Not too shabby, eh?

      Other Ways You Can Help

      If you can't contribute any money to this project, please help by sharing the link and telling your friends, if you know someone who is interested in musical theatre and helping a small company reach their goal, tell them about us!

      What's at stake here?

      Not to blow our own slice of cake here but we really think that we've written a good show and we hope that you do too. If you'd like to hear the album we released of the show's music, then there's a link to our Bandcamp page below.** But what we're proudest of is that it has the potential to make people think about their relationship to their community. If 'The Local' encourages anyone to stand up for their local pub, or any pub for that matter, against the commercial and political forces that threaten them then this will all have been worth it.

      Thanks for reading. Please give generously.

      *http://broadwaybaby.com/shows/character-limit/7...

      **http://trythisathometheatre.bandcamp.com/album/...

story:
Short Summary

I'm Molly Ross, a puppeteer and I am heading to the Chicago International Puppetry Festival to create a new work in progress, Tumbling Amid the Rocks, at the University of Chicago’s Performance Lab in the Logan Center.

But I need some extra money to get our puppets and equipment to Chicago in time for the show. 
 

What We Need & What You Get


Your contributions help our gear not get stuck somewhere between Key West and Chicago.  We need to raise $1,538. That’s one dollar for every mile between Key West and Chicago. 

As a way to thank you for helping make this possible, we have some fun perks. 
 
$5 Good Karma: Get a thank you online and at the show for helping get our gear to the show and know that you have earned good karma!
 
$25 A postcard kiss from Chicago or a hug at the show on Jan 28th.
We will send you a postcard from Chicago or if you are in Chicago we will give you a GIANT hug at the show on Jan 28th.
 
$50 A digital “Papercut”  from our shadow puppets that you can download and print or put on the screen of your computer or phone.
 
$75 "Virtual" Studio Visit:  I keep a detailed online “studio” that documents our process. You will get access to this site to follow along with the progress of the project plus we'll send you a postcard kiss.
 
$150 An artist book based on this project plus postcard kiss. 
 
$250 All the above plus extra good karma!

$500 Original Papercut plus all the above.  

More Info

 The funds we raise will pay for round trip shipping of our equipment and puppets. 

Tumbling Amid the Rocks is an overhead projector shadow puppet performance inspired by the adult life of writer Opal Whiteley, whose childhood journals from the woods of the Pacific Northwest made her an international star in the 1920's, but whose later life went into a dramatic spiral when their authenticity was questioned. 

The Dream Team!  
ellen cherry: Music  & performance
Annie Howe: Puppets & performance
Molly Ross: Direction, puppets & performance

Annie, ellen and I have worked for over a decade on many creative projects together. Under the umbrella of the organization, Nana Projects, were able to tour our shows nationally and intend to tour Tumbling Amid the Rocks to Key West and other locations in the next year.

Crazy? Probably. 

 I know it’s crazy to try and pull off a crowd funding campaign in just a few days, but we need your help.  And I know so many of you are happy to invest in independent artists and their original works.   

More ways to help-SHARE!

Please Share this with all your friends!  A little goes a long way when we all help each other out.  And come to the show on Jan 28 at the Logan Center.  Also, check out all the brilliant shows that are part of the Festival.

Love, molly

+ annie & ellen

story:
About US:

Chamacos is an Austin based dance company led by Aurelio Planes and Inna Grudtcina. Aurelio is a Cuban dancer and choreographer who has a several year experience of working with the leading dance companies in Cuba. Inna Grudtcina is a russian dancer and choreographer. She traveled to South Korea, Spain and Israel pursuing her dance career. Aurelio and Inna decided to combine both of their rich dance experience and create a dance company with a unique voice.

For the short period of 8 month the company has presented one full evening-length work, two 10 minute dance piece, a short dance film, and numerous dance videos. A duet from their debut show will be presented at Austin Dance Festival on April, 7th 2018. The company offers classes in Cuban Modern Dance technique mixed with floor work. We offer a platform for physical exploration and vigorous dance training to professional dancers of any backgrounds and nationalities. We are passionate about dance and push ourselves beyond our limits. 

We see our mission in getting more people involved in the art of dance by providing original and thought provoking performances. We believe that dance has power to influence minds and lives of people when both technique and genuineness are present.

About Looking Up:

We have been in process of our new production,"Looking up", since February, 2018 with a total of 90 hours of rehearsals. "Looking up" is the new collaborative project between Chamacos Dance Company and ProyectoTeatro. This project utilizes Cuban contemporary dance to explore a new vision of the human experience inspired by the apocalypse. Dancers embodying community endure a cruel and visceral confrontation against the four horseman whom have arrived to end life. This timeless physical confrontation pulls us into a space beyond the body, where generational cycles force us to reflect on our role as human beings in society.

This project was created with a musical selection of international icons that span different eras and different time periods. 

What We Need & What You Get

In order to bring this show to life, the campaign is seeking to raise funds to cover costs spent on production, such as costumes, promotional materials, equipment rental, stage props. What we value the most is our dancers whose hard work, sweat,energy, professionalism and commitment deserve to be financially rewarded.

Breakdown: Funding

Dancer stipend: $1500

Rental Equipment: $400

Promotional Campaign: $500

Costumes: $500

Props: $100

"Looking up" is supported by unique perks in order to engage people of Austin in the Arts. Support comes from Movin' Easy Dancewear, Once Over Coffee, Genuine Joe coffeehouse, Once Over coffee bar and One Academy of Dance.

Your donations will not only help our dance company to thrive but it will have a much greater effect. It will raise an awareness in the dance community of Austin, give an opportunity to Austinites to witness Cuban Contemporary Dance, an art form that is rarely seen not only in Austin but in the whole United States. On the larger scale your support will create more opportunities for Austin based dancers to create and perform, bring more talents to our city and help develop Austin dance scene.

Every dollar amount is welcome and appreciated in our journey towards funding LOOKING UP. 

Spread the word by sharing our campaign through Facebook, Instagram, and Email, and post about us by using the hashtag #chamacosdance. Every time you share this campaign with others we are one step closer to reaching our goal.

Thank you!

story:
Short Summary

Hello, My name is Anthony Gelsomino and I have been the Artistic Director of Lucky Devil Theater Company since its inception in 1998. I have been making plays and taking chances with LDTC for the past 20 years with over 10 productions.  With a penchant for LGBTQ themes and a soft spot for comedy, LDTC has survived to reinvent itself once again with Provincetown Murder Mystery.

Having fallen in love with Provincetown, MA and eventually purchasing a home there, I wanted to write the ultimate love song to Ptown. With that, Provincetown Murder Mystery was born. A fast paced, joke a minute farce that had all the elements of an LDTC production: drama, drinks, drag queens and decapitation. Who could ask for anything more?

Once written but twice shy, I brought a reading of PMM to the NY stage to see if people, well, thought it was remotely funny. And they did. They chuckled and guffawed with delight. So, with the help of the suprisingly adept Antony Raymond, we took this reading to Provincetown, MA for one night only. We even cast local favorite Liza Lott as Lozenge, the drag queen with a dream of gold. The cast was as follows:

Narrator: Eric Doviak, Danthony: Gene Dante, Bleache: Devin Melillo, Lozenge: Liza Lott, Dimitar: Ben Dawson WATCH IT HERE: https://www.facebook.com/anthony.gelsomino/vide...

We filled the Crown & Anchor with eager locals and some drunk tourists, who responded with resounding laughter to the show. We then knew we had to bring it back, off book and on the mark.

One weekend in Tennessee, I asked Lucky Devil Theater Co’s other founding member Von Parish, to do the math on bringing this fully realized show to the stage. She did, and armed with a mimosa, she came up with a budget of $30k. Guess we need to raise some dough.

What We Need & What You Get

Since we are a NY based company, we need to rehearse this show in NYC and bring it to Ptown. That means money. It also means we are going to try and do something people never do: PAY THE ACTORS! So the money we raise will go the following places:

Rehearsal space in a not very glamorous NYC rehearsal space for a week rehearsal period.

Costumes & props. We will admit, one prop is a flying dildo.

Something we will call a set. 

Transportation for the actors & crew to/from Ptown. 

Housing in Ptown.

A stipend so that crew/actors can eat food each day.

Promotional materials so people know what we are doing.

Cargo charges to get Liza Lott & Gene Dante from MA to NYC for rehearsal.

Technical assistance that helps make theater magic.

We actually need more than the $10,000 we are asking for here. Remember Von’s $30,000 budget? Well, I wanted to be realistic and put a goal that seemed reasonable and didn’t make us look like losers if we didn’t hit it.

I’d like to tell you that you are saving a hungry child from diphtheria or a rescue dog from Cujo-ism..but you are not. Instead you will help us bring something much more needed in the world today: GAY THEATER. LDTC is not making a profit from this production; we will be lucky if we remotely break even. So feel good in knowing every penny we raise is going into making the funniest, most satisfying play about a ghost dildo you’ve ever seen. 

So please, if you find any solace in a great night out with irreverent theater, give us a chance to make the children’s laughter remind us how it used to be.

story: I've been working in dance, performance art and video for over 40 years. This is my first serious attempt to make a work of dance for the camera. Your contributions help to take my work to a new level. A year and a half ago an Indiegogo campaign raised $1500 towards the production of the film. All filming has been completed. Composer Francesco Beccaro has composed four lovely pieces of original music for the film. We are entering the final stage of completing the film but need $1500 to finish the final editing, mixing and mastering of the film and music. With your help the film will be finished and begin screening at festivals around the world. 32 contributors have already supported the project. Please let us add your name to the list. Contributors will be invited to the film release party and premier screening which will be presented at Dixon Place in New York City on January 18. 2018. Thank you for your support.

story:
Shakespeare and Me 

Do you remember that moment in "10 Things I Hate About You" when Kat's best friend says about William Shakespeare, "We're involved"? I didn't think I was going to prom with him, but I get where she's coming from. I did my first Shakespeare play in fifth grade. It was in the gifted program, and we did a (very abbreviated) version of "A Midsummer Night's Dream". I traded Shakespeare quotes with bad boyfriends in undergrad, and I met my husband at an audition for Georgia Shakespeare shortly after getting my BFA. I've performed Shakespeare professionally, and chose my graduate school largely because of UCF's relationship with the Orlando Shakespeare Theater. I've been in Romeo and Juliet 4 times. You get it, I'm a big fan.

Shakespeare and You

But what do you think of when you hear the name Shakespeare? I know if you asked my mom, she'd say it conjured memories of tortuous high school reading assignments. She's supportive of my Bard obsession, but there's no love lost between her and Will.

I think a lot of people feel that way. 

There are lots of reasons that I've selected this as my thesis project. I can give you the rundown from my abstract about Gender Theory, female representation, subversion of societal roles, but let's be honest, you don't want to read about that. (If you do, let me know and I'll send you drafts along the way as I write!) I think the most important reason for you to know is this: I want to share my love for Shakespeare. I want to make Shakespeare accessible. I want to put on a production that is immediate, easy to understand, and fun. I want you to come see the show and have your mind changed about what Shakespeare can be, and then I want to talk to you about it!

What We Need & What You Get

I have a lot of support from both the University of Central Florida and the Orlando Shakespeare Theater, particularly when it comes to space. They are graciously donating rehearsal and performance space for which I am incredibly grateful!
 
As both a research project, and a fully mounted production, we do have other expenses that I need your help with.
 
The $2000 I am seeking to raise is going to the following categories:
  • Paying technicians and OST staff for their time
  • Costumes
  • Set
  • Marketing 
  • Programs
  • Research Materials

Your financial support will allow us to have production that looks as great as it sounds! As a token of our gratitude, we will be offering VIP tickets, signed scripts, and thank yous in our programs and in my published thesis.

The Impact

Less than 16% of Shakespeare's roles were written for women. Opportunities for women to perform his words can be few and far between, but your contribution can help change that.

  • Your support gives women the chance to speak Shakespeare on a professional stage
  • Your support aids in the continued education of some of Central Florida's brightest minds.
  • Your support gives opportunities for students to see affordable theatre.
  • Your support allows me to make an academic contribution to my field. 
  • Your support makes this production possible.

Risks & Challenges

There are always challenges in the theatre, but as we say "The Show Must Go On". We are working on a tight budget, and the performers, technicians, and stage managers are all donating their time to the project. I am determined to mount this show regardless of the money we raise here, but every dollar makes it a smoother and more successful road to opening night.

Other Ways You Can Help

The biggest way you can help is by coming to our show! The core of this production is research and audience involvement, so the best way you can help is by showing up! 

Be on the lookout for a Facebook event as we get closer to the date!

I'm going to be spending the next year and a half talking and writing about women and Shakespeare, so please reach out any time to chat about it! I'm passionate about this work, and I love sharing it with people!
story_txt:
Shakespeare and Me 
Do you remember that moment in "10 Things I Hate About You" when Kat's best friend says about William Shakespeare, "We're involved"? I didn't think I was going to prom with him, but I get where she's coming from. I did my first Shakespeare play in fifth grade. It was in the gifted program, and we did a (very abbreviated) version of "A Midsummer Night's Dream". I traded Shakespeare quotes with bad boyfriends in undergrad, and I met my husband at an audition for Georgia Shakespeare shortly after getting my BFA. I've performed Shakespeare professionally, and chose my graduate school largely because of UCF's relationship with the Orlando Shakespeare Theater. I've been in Romeo and Juliet 4 times. You get it, I'm a big fan.
Shakespeare and You
But what do you think of when you hear the name Shakespeare? I know if you asked my mom, she'd say it conjured memories of tortuous high school reading assignments. She's supportive of my Bard obsession, but there's no love lost between her and Will.
I think a lot of people feel that way. 
There are lots of reasons that I've selected this as my thesis project. I can give you the rundown from my abstract about Gender Theory, female representation, subversion of societal roles, but let's be honest, you don't want to read about that. (If you do, let me know and I'll send you drafts along the way as I write!) I think the most important reason for you to know is this: I want to share my love for Shakespeare. I want to make Shakespeare accessible. I want to put on a production that is immediate, easy to understand, and fun. I want you to come see the show and have your mind changed about what Shakespeare can be, and then I want to talk to you about it!
What We Need & What You Get
I have a lot of support from both the University of Central Florida and the Orlando Shakespeare Theater, particularly when it comes to space. They are graciously donating rehearsal and performance space for which I am incredibly grateful! As both a research project, and a fully mounted production, we do have other expenses that I need your help with. The $2000 I am seeking to raise is going to the following categories:
Paying technicians and OST staff for their time
Costumes
Set
Marketing 
Programs
Research Materials
Your financial support will allow us to have production that looks as great as it sounds! As a token of our gratitude, we will be offering VIP tickets, signed scripts, and thank yous in our programs and in my published thesis.
The Impact
Less than 16% of Shakespeare's roles were written for women. Opportunities for women to perform his words can be few and far between, but your contribution can help change that.

Your support gives women the chance to speak Shakespeare on a professional stage
Your support aids in the continued education of some of Central Florida's brightest minds.
Your support gives opportunities for students to see affordable theatre.
Your support allows me to make an academic contribution to my field. 
Your support makes this production possible.


Risks & Challenges
There are always challenges in the theatre, but as we say "The Show Must Go On". We are working on a tight budget, and the performers, technicians, and stage managers are all donating their time to the project. I am determined to mount this show regardless of the money we raise here, but every dollar makes it a smoother and more successful road to opening night.

Other Ways You Can Help
The biggest way you can help is by coming to our show! The core of this production is research and audience involvement, so the best way you can help is by showing up! 
Be on the lookout for a Facebook event as we get closer to the date!
I'm going to be spending the next year and a half talking and writing about women and Shakespeare, so please reach out any time to chat about it! I'm passionate about this work, and I love sharing it with people!

story:
A Summary of Dancing England and the re-boot

As you probably know by now, Dancing England was a incredibly successful series of traditional dance showcase events run between 1979 and 1987 at the Derby Assembly Rooms. 30 years later, it happened again. Sheffield, 2017.

We think there's enough interest out there to run the show again, and make it a regular event.

My name is still Edwin Dyson and along with Phil Heaton, Arwen Heaton, Amy O'Brien, and Eilidh Smith, I'm one of the organisers for Dancing England 2019. I have strong family connections to the initial series, and Arwen was the organiser of the Daughter of Dancing England events.

I was there between 1979 and 1987, soaking up the atmosphere, enjoying the traditional dancing and being entranced by re-enactments of some of our most interesting and unique folklore customs. I MC'd the 2017 event, Arwen stage managed the whole affair, Phil sold posters, programmes, and more importantly put the bulk of the acts together, and Eilidh and Amy admirably ran backstage.

We've a good team in place for Dancing England 2019, and some great acts already lined up for you to enjoy; including some old(er) faces dancing Cotswold Morris, Rapper Sword, Step Clog, Molly, Longsword, Border Morris and North West. But joined together with younger teams, both aiming to showcase the tradition and the vibrancy of traditional dance in the UK. 

After the 2017 re-boot, we realised that there's a wealth of good feeling and nostalgia out there for Dancing England, and we know people really want it to happen again. We need some more help to get the 2019 event under way, deposits need paying, publicity material needs printing and shipping.

If you choose to take part in this crowdfunding exercise and contribute to Dancing England 2019, you would be joining us in ensuring that some of our fantastic traditional and revival dancing teams are seen by a wider audience and that our more unique folklore customs are kept alive and known.

Might you be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

I'll break this down for you in more detail:

To run an event like this takes money, there's no bones about it. We need to raise approximately £2750 to pay for venue deposits and the like.

Tickets will go on sale in due course through the venue, but we want to get Dancing England 2019 set up on a firm financial footing first. This will hopefully ensure some stability for the future. The organisers will also be contributing financially to the event. We've also applied for National Lottery money, and grants from other sources too.

There are two types of crowdfunding for this project. Firstly you could become a Patron of Dancing England. This costs £40 and in return you would receive our heartfelt thanks, a mention in publicity, early entry to the event enabling you to get one of the best seats in the house and a free programme and poster.

Secondly, if you felt unable to be a Patron, you could be a Supporter of Dancing England in return for £10 of your hard earned money. This would again earn you a significant amount of gratitude, a thank you in the programme and the knowledge that you've helped a much-loved and oft-missed traditional dance event take place once again.

The Impact Of Your Funding

Your funding contribution will make a real difference to Dancing England and the people that want to come and watch the teams take part.

England is full of peculiar and exciting customs and traditions. Dancing England enables people to experience and appreciate our vast wealth of cultural heritage.

Dancing England was a glimpse of spring in the depths of winter. It was a highlight on people's calendars. It was valued and loved. We think there's enough love for this to happen again.

Risks & Challenges

Of course there are risks in organising an event like this. With proper planning we can mitigate most or all of those.

We are starting small. By 1987 Dancing England had grown to an audience of 2000. Our new Nottingham venue has a capacity of 700.

We will be harnessing the power of social media to spread the message, build enthusiasm for the event and to crowdfund Dancing England.

If, in the sad event, we don't raise a sufficient amount of monies, we will work with the venue to see how they can help. If in the sadder event that doesn't work, then we will refund everyone's contributions and say thank you.

We don't want that to happen.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that you might not be able to help financially at this point in time, but that doesn't mean that you can't assist in other ways.

Please help us to get the word out and make some noise about Dancing England.

Please Share, Like and Retweet this crowdfunding campaign on Facebook and other social media

You could also use the Indiegogo share tools!

Why not get in touch and ask for a flyer or poster to take along to your local folk club or dance practice?

Thank you for reading the pitch so far. Now, might we ask you for that contribution? Find 'Select A Perk' at the top right of this page and choose one! Thank you.

story:
Who We Are

We believe in the power of a good ghost story.

Ghosts, an original play by Elford Alley, features everything that attracts people to the paranormal while exploring themes of loss, how we cope with our loved ones, and how past relationships twist to become their own ghost stories.

In 2017, producer Charlotte Corneliusen and director Kathleen Barth teamed up to bring the play to life, The result was the play's original one-act run at the Little Theatre of Alexandria, which opened to rave reviews and sold-out crowds. The team submitted their production to the 2018 Capital Fringe Festival and was accepted-- a big deal!

Now, Charlotte, Kathleen, and Elford are proud to team up again to bring the full-length version of Ghosts to Washington, D.C.

About the Team

Kathleen Barth is a director active in the D.C. area. As a director, she feels passionate about staging new works and extending opportunities to women artists. She was particularly drawn to Ghosts because of its portrayal of the depths of people in anguish and grief and the dark shades of human nature. Kathleen directed the original one-act version of Ghosts at the Little Theatre of Alexandria's "Creepshow", hosted by the NextGen committee, and now she is delighted to direct the new full-length version of Ghosts that will premier this summer at the Capital Fringe Festival.

Charlotte Corneliusen is a creative producer, screenwriter, casting director and production designer, who has lived in the DC area, since 2009. She began her career in film in 1998 and has worked on big-budget documentaries, independent films and television series, in Canada and Germany. She started producing theatre in 2017 and co-produced the one-act version of Ghosts, at Little Theatre of Alexandria, last fall. She loved the original version of the Ghosts script and her experience working with Elford and Kathleen. She is proud to team up with them again to bring a full-length version of the play, with a talented cast and crew, to Capital Fringe in July. Charlotte believes in the story and her team so much that she is self-producing and requests your support as an independent theatre artist.

Elford Alley is a playwright and novelist from Texas. He's always believed in the power of a good ghost story. He's incredibly grateful to Kathleen, Charlotte, and Dennis, not just for choosing his work, but for helping him improve and expand the story in so many wonderful ways.

What We Need & What You Get

Your donation will help pay the cast and crew, cover Fringe venue fees and insurance costs, purchase set pieces/props/costumes and provide a marketing budget, so that we can not only put on the best play possible, but also to reach an audience who may not know much about their local theater scene.

To make this production a reality, we have a modest fundraising goal of $1,500. Here's how our budget breaks down:

  • 30%: Fringe Fees/Venue
  • 30%: Artist Stipends
  • 15%: Costumes/Set Pieces/Props
  • 12%: Insurance
  • 10%: Marketing/Printing
  • 3%: Transportation

The Impact

Our wish to bring Ghosts to the Capital Fringe Festival goes beyond our desire to bring a good ghost story to the stage. We believe in the power of community and keeping the local, independent arts scene thriving by providing a fun, genre piece that appeals to lovers of theater, sci-fi, horror, and mystery.

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us by getting the word out by sharing this campaign via social media -- It's a tremendously effective, cost-free way to help us grow. 

Tell your friends and family about our production. Join us this July at the Blind Whino in Washington, D.C. and experience what we've worked tirelessly on for the past year!

story:
"A show that not only should be seen, but needs to be seen."

Partnering with Broadway Cares: Equity Fights AIDS, A.N.O.N. Production is bringing back their widely heralded production of SNOW. Written by Ashley Griffin - creator of the pop culture phenomenon FOREVER DEADWARD (New World Stages,) SNOW recently received a developmental reading at Playwrights Horizons, and has been praised as "A show that not only should be seen, but needs to be seen," "Genius," "Brilliant," and "Darkly Moving." 

SNOW was performed as a workshop piece last year in 2016 which led to a developmental reading at Playwrights Horizons featuring Jennifer Regan and Christian Coulson, directed by Rachel Klein. To solidify producers for a significant commercial production, and to raise money for the wonderful Broadway Cares, Equity fights AIDS, A.N.O.N. Productions is planning on bringing a production of SNOW to the stage this fall.

But in order for us to do that, we need your help.

Utilizing a structure similar to THE HOURS and CLOUD ATLAS, SNOW explores the power and nature of storytelling through three disperate storylines that all revolve around the classic fairy tale SNOW WHITE - the Grimm Brothers who originally collected the tales, a Victorian theatrical family whose lives begin to mirror SNOW WHITE, and a modern day young woman living with her abusive mother. SNOW asks whether the things at the heart of our beloved stories - hope in a hopeless world, love that will last forever are really true, or nothing more than "lies breathed through silver."

Not only will contributions allow us to bring this important work to the stage, the more we are able to raise, the more we will be able to donate to Broadway Cares.

story:
Short Summary

The performers of Guilty Pleasures Cabaret are professional dancers, singers, and comedians who live and work in New York City performing their show every two weeks at renowned cabaret venues.  Many of the performers have international and domestic touring experience, and sought out the need to produce and direct a show that created a positive image of women in show business. 

This campaign is important to us because after years of auditioning and being part of shows where we're constantly told what to look like, what to wear, and that we weren't sexy enough, we wanted to create a show that embraced individuality and our unique talents.  

We're growing to a point where we're receiving offers to perform at large domestic and international venues.   These are valuable opportunities to spread our message, share our unique art-form, grow our fanbase, and expand our business. 

What We Need & What You Get

Funds collected from our campaign will go towards

  • ($3,500) Airfare, transportation, and dancer salary for a tour in Belize 
  • ($2,250) Airfare & transportation for a tour in Colorado
  • ($2,250) Airfare & transportation for a tour in California
  • ($2,000) Salary for touring dancers

Contributor perks include: show tickets, merchandise, and VIP access to GPC Art Bar events.  If we don't reach our entire goal, the collected funds will go towards dancer's salaries for current NYC shows. 

The Impact

Did you know that females only comprise 5% of the CEO's and 7% of show business directors in the nation?  By contributing to this campaign you're personally supporting young female entrepreneurs and producers. 

Risks & Challenges

Our main source of revenue comes from ticket sales.  Our venues usually take up to 50% of our ticket sales, then after paying performers, costumes, rehearsal space, and marketing materials - many times we're lucky if we break even.  Going on a tour requires a certain amount of money upfront.  As we start expanding our brand to markets outside of NYC, it will be easier for venues to book us and fund the cost of our show entirely.  

We're savvy when it comes to pinching pennies to work with what we do (or don't) have.  We know how to budget our funds, reuse costumes, recycle marketing materials, and work side jobs in exchange for studio space. 

Every contribution amount is important, and no amount is too small, but if you really can't contribute funds right now please share our campaign with your friends and family via the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Is it too late to become the person you were meant to be?

I’m Ben Hollis, best known for hosting “Wild Chicago” on WTTW. Few of you realize I am also a theater artist and performer who sings and writes songs. I love my TV work. And I am long overdue in showing another side of myself. Surviving a rare brain vessel condition gives me a chance to do so. I am so grateful.

This creative effort takes the form of a solo show (with support from master rocker John Siegle, formerly of the Insiders.) I’m singing songs and telling stories about my life before, during and after “Wild Chicago.” (Including my “Bed of Bosoms” – an ancient, infantile dream I honestly remember from childhood.)

Welcome to "How The Beatles Nearly Ruined My Life - And David Bowie Saved it!"

The show is about how music saved me, then and now. (I know you can relate.) It’s also a testament to the human spirit and our ability to reinvent ourselves – at any age.

Your contribution will enable me to mount this production which in turn will bring joy and hope and big laughs to all who come see it. But I can’t bankroll the whole thing. Naturally, my surgery and recovery has put a dent in my financial state.

Here’s the Skinny

I need to pay a director, pay for rehearsal time, pay to market the show and to cover other expenses.  Months and months of writing and polishing have gone into this show. We’re going for $9500 or better.

The Perks

I’m excited about The Perks – the benefits you get from contributing.  $48 gets you a ticket to the show. That’s huge. We need to sell out all 140 seats for each performance. Your perk covers the cost of the ticket ($22) and a nice chunk ($26) to our production needs. We thank you.

The $98 perk gets you a seat AND the Ben Hollis & The Resentments CD, “Live Your Life” which features songs from the show and John Siegle on guitar.

There’s even an opportunity to BE IN THE SHOW! And a chance to enjoy a meal together, and a chance to have John and I do a show at your place (or wherever you like), and a chance to get your hands on a rare "Wild Chicago" DVD.

You can even get a photo file of your own baby picture (or a loved one’s) on my Bed of Bosoms. That’ll make Grandpa blush, eh?

The Impact

 I’m going to get deep here. Deep, as in spiritual. I feel that this show is a calling for me. So many people are going to relate to it and be inspired by it. Even if they aren’t, they’re still going to enjoy the music and the stories and be happily distracted from their problems for a couple of hours. That's not nothing.

For years I undervalued my gifts. I thought the ability to make people laugh and smile was small potatoes, lightweight. Now I know otherwise, mostly thanks to hearing from people like you, especially during my medical adventures. You said I helped you. I was deeply moved. And now I get to give back again. It’s a circle. Lion King stuff.

Risks & Challenges

The initial goal is to raise this money and have a great opening weekend at The Skokie Theatre on January 21 and 22.

After that, we set our sights on a successful, long run in a theatre to be named. The show deserves it. Chicago audiences deserve it. But first we have to “crush it” at The Skokie on January 21 and 22.

We need you to tell your friends and share this campaign – and other pertinent info – on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram or other precious bodily fluids. (Think “Dr. Stranglove.)

I’ve done Channel 11 Pledge Drives before. Let this be one more. Let's sell out The Skokie on January 21 and 22. We’re counting on you.
story_txt:
Is it too late to become the person you were meant to be?
I’m Ben Hollis, best known for hosting “Wild Chicago” on WTTW. Few of you realize I am also a theater artist and performer who sings and writes songs. I love my TV work. And I am long overdue in showing another side of myself. Surviving a rare brain vessel condition gives me a chance to do so. I am so grateful.
This creative effort takes the form of a solo show (with support from master rocker John Siegle, formerly of the Insiders.) I’m singing songs and telling stories about my life before, during and after “Wild Chicago.” (Including my “Bed of Bosoms” – an ancient, infantile dream I honestly remember from childhood.)
Welcome to "How The Beatles Nearly Ruined My Life - And David Bowie Saved it!"
The show is about how music saved me, then and now. (I know you can relate.) It’s also a testament to the human spirit and our ability to reinvent ourselves – at any age.
Your contribution will enable me to mount this production which in turn will bring joy and hope and big laughs to all who come see it. But I can’t bankroll the whole thing. Naturally, my surgery and recovery has put a dent in my financial state. 
Here’s the Skinny
I need to pay a director, pay for rehearsal time, pay to market the show and to cover other expenses.  Months and months of writing and polishing have gone into this show. We’re going for $9500 or better. 
The Perks
I’m excited about The Perks – the benefits you get from contributing.  $48 gets you a ticket to the show. That’s huge. We need to sell out all 140 seats for each performance. Your perk covers the cost of the ticket ($22) and a nice chunk ($26) to our production needs. We thank you.
The $98 perk gets you a seat AND the Ben Hollis & The Resentments CD, “Live Your Life” which features songs from the show and John Siegle on guitar.
There’s even an opportunity to BE IN THE SHOW! And a chance to enjoy a meal together, and a chance to have John and I do a show at your place (or wherever you like), and a chance to get your hands on a rare "Wild Chicago" DVD.
You can even get a photo file of your own baby picture (or a loved one’s) on my Bed of Bosoms. That’ll make Grandpa blush, eh? 
The Impact 
 I’m going to get deep here. Deep, as in spiritual. I feel that this show is a calling for me. So many people are going to relate to it and be inspired by it. Even if they aren’t, they’re still going to enjoy the music and the stories and be happily distracted from their problems for a couple of hours. That's not nothing.
For years I undervalued my gifts. I thought the ability to make people laugh and smile was small potatoes, lightweight. Now I know otherwise, mostly thanks to hearing from people like you, especially during my medical adventures. You said I helped you. I was deeply moved. And now I get to give back again. It’s a circle. Lion King stuff.
Risks & Challenges 
The initial goal is to raise this money and have a great opening weekend at The Skokie Theatre on January 21 and 22. 
After that, we set our sights on a successful, long run in a theatre to be named. The show deserves it. Chicago audiences deserve it. But first we have to “crush it” at The Skokie on January 21 and 22.
We need you to tell your friends and share this campaign – and other pertinent info – on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram or other precious bodily fluids. (Think “Dr. Stranglove.)
I’ve done Channel 11 Pledge Drives before. Let this be one more. Let's sell out The Skokie on January 21 and 22. We’re counting on you.

story:
"What is the name of this dance company,

Siza?"

  • Pronounced see-zuh
  • lyndSI ZApata (Artistic Director / Choreographer)
  • "Si" is also "yes" in Spanish.
    • The word "yes" is an underrated word if you think about it. We use "yes" to give an affirmative response, or as a response to someone addressing one or otherwise trying to attract one's attention. This all felt very appropriate towards our mission.
  • Za, comes from the first two letters of the surname Zapata.
    • So? For those who may be unaware, the surname Zapata is a popular one in the Latino community, especially in the Mexican community. Emiliano Zapata was a leading figure in the Mexican Revolution in the state of Morelos, and the inspiration of the agrarian movement called Zapatismo.
  • In a sense: Yes to Revolution.
     

"Why do you need $7,500?" 

The Nitty Gritties of Bare Bones

  • Space to rehearse costs $30/hour
    • We will be rehearsing 2 hrs/week
    • =$60 a week
    • $60/wk for 8 months = $1,920
  • We have 8, fierce, strong, unique movers.
    • Ideally, dancers will be paid $10/hr of rehearsal
    • We will be rehearsing 2 hrs/week
    • Paying 8 dancers/week = $160
    • Paying 8 dancers/8 months = approx $5,120
  • Money to be distributed for collaborators = approx $460

        $1,920
    + $5,120
    + 460
    = $7,500
     

Challenges

Building a dance company from the ground up is no easy feat. There's the schedule of the dancers, finding affordable and healthy space to rehearse, that space's availability, applying for performances opportunities, creating our own opportunities. However, these are all very manageable with hard work, communication and compromise.

It is when we talk about finances that we hit our wall. Paying for space, dancers, collaborators, application fees, and should we have the privilege to perform, this will also cost a pretty penny.

We feel optimistic that $7,500 is a goal we can reach, but we can't do it without your help! Whether you can donate $5 or $500, we want to show our gratitude. From thank you notes to complimentary tickets, posters to season passes. Check out the perks you can receive!
 

"Listen, a cup of coffee isn't even in my budget these days."

Other Ways You Can Help

Some just can't contribute, and we are sensitive to that, but that doesn't mean they can't help!

  • Social media is such a powerful tool! Using platforms like Facebook, Instagram, Twitter...whatever you have, you have the power to share this IndieGoGo page or video with your  folks.

Meet Some Movers

   

   MaijaLisa Miltz                Lyla Palmer                  Bryce Moyer       

   

  Nate Odell                   Sarah Boyce               Arielle Creager

*not photographed: Kaiso Hill and Lexy Shimko

About The Artistic Director / Choreographer

Lyndsi Zapata was born in Portland, OR, where she studied dance throughout her childhood. In her high school years, she would spend her mornings receiving her high school diploma (Lincoln High School) and dance from mid-day into the evening (Jefferson High School) moving with dance companies; Jefferson Dancers II, as well as Urban Arts. Dance brought Zapata to further her training at California Institute of the Arts, where she invested in her passion for choreography. Her craft has also opened travel opportunities, such as studying in Seoul, South Korea (Korea National University of Arts) as well as Lucca, Italy (Dance Italia). After graduating in May 2016, Zapata looks forward to developing Siza as a movement platform for young artists who share complimentary interests in the Los Angeles area.

story:
History

"Soft Butter is what it means to grow up trans without the language to express it." - Éamon Boylan

Éamon Boylan is a trans queer theatre director and creator who, while attending the National Theater Institute at the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center, wrote and workshopped the first draft of the musical Soft Butter: a trans fantasia on edible themes. The following fall, Soft Butter was further developed with generous support by Musical Theatre Factory. Soft Butter is now headed for a very special premiere at Ars Nova, ANT Fest 2018. We absolutely can't wait to take on this new challenge and want to invite YOU to help make it possible!

Identity

"This is an opportunity to get a lot of people in a room together that don't often get to be in a room together. This is a chance to get a lot of people in a room together who are often alone." - Éamon Boylan

Soft Butter celebrates trans, queer, non-binary and gender non-conforming voices and as such, our cast and creative team for this production are trans, queer, non-binary and gender non-conforming theatre makers! Our voices demand more content created by us and for us: produced by us, designed by us, embodied by us. It is important to us that queer and trans narratives and experiences not be decided for queer and trans audiences and bodies. 

Performance

"Queer stories and trans stories, like any others, are grounded in experience. Experience begets experience and experience invites experience." - Éamon Boylan 

As theatre makers, our work is most exciting when something is being actively discovered. This presentation of Soft Butter marks the first time we will share Soft Butter in full. It's a very exciting premiere for us because the work is actively in process, inviting you, the audience, into that process. We will share a gesture of design, a gesture of the world of the play, and a rockstar cast at Ars Nova, a space which actively cultivates new, risk-taking, challenging, in-process, work that's innovative in both content and form. Just like Soft Butter! 

You!

"Soft Butter invites audiences to taste something new, in which Familiar meets Alien. It invites them to remember before they assume and to experience before they understand." - Éamon Boylan

To produce the premiere of Soft Butter this summer, we need your support. Your contribution, whatever the size, would be so valued by our whole company. This kind of project takes a lot of work from a lot of people and every little bit counts. Every dollar, every share, every visit to this page. In return, we will share our unmelting gratitude, some delicious and fun rewards, as well as a fantastic theatrical experience for all genders. Time and time again we've heard Soft Butter liberates people's need to understand or intellectualize their experience because it hits them in ways they don't expect; it moves them. Soft Butter invites and includes the experiences of those who witness it to be part of its meaning. We need you to make Soft Butter possible.

Budget and Risks

"The body is the pan, the gender is the meal, the pan gets cold, the meal’s still real
we genders hang and hang on and hang on to the body, we hang on after the body dies
you remember this" - Soft Butter

We are asking for $4600 to cover artists fees for the 22 theatre makers bringing the show to life, rehearsal fees so we have the space to create, designers funds so they can work to create the world of the play, insurance to keep everyone protected, and a contingency fund just in case.  

Once we start working, the only major risks for this project are the ones inherent in making any piece of exciting and vital theatre. We've assembled a team of experienced artists with whom we are so excited to collaborate. They are consummate professionals with an artistry and aesthetic that the Soft Butter team has been looking for. We have also already reserved rehearsal space for a fair number of the rehearsals and have signed up for insurance. The biggest risk is that we are not able to raise the money for the show which means we will have to find other ways of funding our work. 

Other Ways To Help

"Every character is a real gender, one of many. Infinite genders exist. The genders in this play intersect and complement one another, but are not representative of the whole gender universe."-Éamon Boylan

Other than donating to our campaign here, there are many other ways you can support Soft Butter. 

1. Spread the Message! Tell your friends and family about our campaign, post about us all over the internet, and let the world know that you support Soft Butter!

2. Share your Truth! We at Soft Butter recognize the whole universe of gender experiences. Some are singular, some certain multitudes, some are different every day. We invite you to share your truth, using #TodayMyGenderTastesLike, #TodayMyGenderFeelsLike, and #TodayMyGenderLooksLike on social media!

3. Engage with Us! What are your thoughts and feeling on gender? Are there things we aren't saying you wish we were? Are there things we are saying that you think don't feel right? We are open and enthusiastic to hear other voices!

4. Buy Tickets! Live now: http://arsnovanyc.com/antfest/6.4

We invite you to share your truth, using #TodayMyGenderTastesLike, #TodayMyGenderFeelsLike, and #TodayMyGenderLooksLike on social media!3. Engage with Us! story:
Drunk Donkey

-an ensemble devised clown show-

-kid friendly too-



What Theater Company Are You With?

This is the number one question our ensemble encounters! And it's the easiest to answer. Drunk Donkey is simply a show devised by an ensemble of three clowns. We are not going through any established theater company. We are three artists in the truest form. We are artists with an idea. And we want to make it happen. We want to share the joy of clowning with the city of Chicago. 

That's it. 


Wait.


There's Only Three Of You?

Sure are!
Nicole Dawn Jordan
 Sonja Lynn Mata 
and 
Richie Schiraldi

But. 

Are You Guys Funny?

We have never been asked this question before. How dare you.


Okay... 

But Why Should I Donate?

This is the best question! It is our hope that you would consider donating to our campaign to put on this show . One of the biggest expenses when putting on a theater show is renting out a performance space. A large portion of what we collect will go towards simply paying for our performance space, which is already one of the cheapest you can find in the city of Chicago ($2,550 for three weeks to be exact!). If could at least raise $2,550, we'd break our necks!!! We mean-- break even! Our space would be paid for! The remaining $1,000 would go towards paying all of our designers and actors. We believe that just like every profession our there, our artists should be paid for their work. 

Our space at Prop Thtr is very unique too! Expect to see some high flying two-highs (standing on one persons shoulders) or maybe even a three-high (standing on two peoples shoulders), as our space has a cat-walk thats only assessable by acrobatic forces. 

Not only that, but please consider donating as we are just three young artists taking on the Chicago theater scene. Fists raised to the air we want to be apart of the next surge to create ensemble devised work and that you don't need a certain status to create visceral and poignant work. 

You got me. TAKE MY MONEY! 

 HUZZAH!

But one last thing. 

Yes?

Why the title "Drunk Donkey?"

This is the toughest question to answer. But since you asked and since you are after all donating to our lovely campaign we will let you in on our secret. Drunk Donkey was coined after the discovery of a Wikipedia article titled "Death From Laughter." 

It tells of a story of a Greek-stotic- PHILOSOPHER named Chrysippus who witnessed a donkey having trouble eating figs. Thus Chrysippus gave this donkey some wine to wash it down. After a few gulps of wine, the sight of the wobbly legged drunk donkey sent Chrysippus into a fit of laughter causing his own joyful death.

It is with that image alone that plunges our clowns into the story of Drunk Donkey. It is in the aftermath of a shipwreck that our clowns wash ashore at the beginning of the end of The Great Wall of China. What lurks in the shadows is a dragon keeping them on the edges of purgatory.  What ensues is the exploration of the tragedies of life and the comedies of death. 

And perhaps the meaning of it all. 


***

More Perks TO BE ADDED!

story:
Short Summary

We, Marias of Brazil, are domestic workers who became actresses and engaged citizens 17 years ago through our participation in Theater of the Oppressed. In September 2015 in Patagonia, Argentina, the 1st Annual International Ma(g)dalenas Festival, an all-female Theater of the Oppressed festival, will take place with women from around the world. Our dream is to give voice to domestic workers at this festival and, in this way, give greater value to the role of domestic workers in our society. 

Who We Are

The group, Marias of Brazil, was created in 1998 by the Center of Theater of the Oppressed in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. The group began with domestic workers who studied at a night school in Rio de Janeiro and began singing, writing poetry, discussing their worker’s rights and performing onstage. Using the techniques and games of Theater of the Oppressed, we have created five theatrical productions that tell their life stories, the last one titled “I, Too, Am a Woman”. The Marias of Brazil have also organized petitions and handed them in person to the representatives of the Brazilian Senate, fighting alongside the Union of Domestic Workers of Rio de Janeiro for better, more just and egalitarian laws. In 2014 we were awarded the Honorary Medal by the City Council of Rio de Janeiro for their artistic and legislative trajectory. 

Marias do Brasil 2015:

MARIA José Góis – Paraíba, Brazil – 66 yrs. old

MARIA José Cardoso – Pernambuco, Brazil – 74 yrs. old

MARIA  da Conceição Santos – Bahia, Brazil – 65 yrs. old

MARIA Aparecida Silva – Minas Gerais, Brazil – 63 yrs. old

MARIA Izabel Monteiro – Campos, Brazil – 49 yrs. old

NILZA Maria Melo – Bahia, Brazil – 82 yrs. old

CÍCERA  Néri – Ceará, Brazil – 64 yrs. old

Artistic Director: Claudete Felix

What We Need & What You Get

In order to attend the International Madalenas Festival, we need help funding the following items:

  • airfare for all group members & Artistic Director
  • hotel stay
  • food
  • local transportation
  • travel to nearby cities to connect with local domestic worker unions
Because we are based in Brazil, most of our perks are digital-friendly and are easily transferable. They include:

  • digital download of photos of Marias do Brasil

  • digital download of photo & video of Marias do Brasil forum theater production 

  • original poetry by members of Marias do Brasil

  • digital download of Metaxis, original publication of the Center of Theater of the Oppressed

  • print of original photo of Marias do Brasil

  • exclusive in-person or Skype interview with Marias do Brasil group members & Artistic Director

  • attend a Marias do Brasil rehearsal and/or performance in person or via Skype 

The Impact

The group will bring our latest theater piece, “I, Too, Am a Woman”, to Patagônia, Argentina in September 2015 for the International Ma(g)dalenas Festival with women from all five continents who work with the methodology of Theater of the Oppressed. 

The objectives of the group in participating in the International Ma(g)dalenas Festival are three-fold:

  • to strengthen relationships with domestic workers across Latin America (networking and coalition-building) 
  • to give continuity to the “Attend the Woman Worker Program” that seeks to better understand worker’s laws through the use of Theater of the Oppressed and give leverage to women workers when dealing with their bosses in both rural and urban areas.  
  • to build towards the group’s 2015 goals, including the creation of a new Theater of the Oppressed group of domestic workers that will ensure the on-going struggle for domestic worker’s rights

Short Summary We, Marias of Brazil, are domestic workers who became actresses and engaged citizens 17 years ago through our participation in Theater of the Oppressed. In September 2015 in Patagonia, Argentina, the 1st Annual International Ma(g)dalenas Festival, an all-female Theater of the Oppressed festival, will take place with women from around the world. Our dream is to give voice to domestic workers at this festival and, in this way, give greater value to the role of domestic workers in our society.  Who We AreThe group, Marias of Brazil, was created in 1998 by the Center of Theater of the Oppressed in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. The group began with domestic workers who studied at a night school in Rio de Janeiro and began singing, writing poetry, discussing their worker’s rights and performing onstage. Using the techniques and games of Theater of the Oppressed, we have created five theatrical productions that tell their life stories, the last one titled “I, Too, Am a Woman”. The Marias of Brazil have also organized petitions and handed them in person to the representatives of the Brazilian Senate, fighting alongside the Union of Domestic Workers of Rio de Janeiro for better, more just and egalitarian laws. In 2014 we were awarded the Honorary Medal by the City Council of Rio de Janeiro for their artistic and legislative trajectory. 

Marias do Brasil 2015:
MARIA José Góis – Paraíba, Brazil – 66 yrs. old
MARIA José Cardoso – Pernambuco, Brazil – 74 yrs. old
MARIA  da Conceição Santos – Bahia, Brazil – 65 yrs. old
MARIA Aparecida Silva – Minas Gerais, Brazil – 63 yrs. old
MARIA Izabel Monteiro – Campos, Brazil – 49 yrs. old
NILZA Maria Melo – Bahia, Brazil – 82 yrs. old
CÍCERA  Néri – Ceará, Brazil – 64 yrs. old
Artistic Director: Claudete Felix
  What We Need & What You Get
In order to attend the International Madalenas Festival, we need help funding the following items:


airfare for all group members & Artistic Director
hotel stay
food
local transportation
travel to nearby cities to connect with local domestic worker unions

Because we are based in Brazil, most of our perks are digital-friendly and are easily transferable. They include:

digital download of photos of Marias do Brasil
digital download of photo & video of Marias do Brasil forum theater production 


original poetry by members of Marias do Brasil


digital download of Metaxis, original publication of the Center of Theater of the Oppressed


print of original photo of Marias do Brasil


exclusive in-person or Skype interview with Marias do Brasil group members & Artistic Director
attend a Marias do Brasil rehearsal and/or performance in person or via Skype 
   The Impact 
The group will bring our latest theater piece, “I, Too, Am a Woman”, to Patagônia, Argentina in September 2015 for the International Ma(g)dalenas Festival with women from all five continents who work with the methodology of Theater of the Oppressed. 
The objectives of the group in participating in the International Ma(g)dalenas Festival are three-fold:

to strengthen relationships with domestic workers across Latin America (networking and coalition-building) 
to give continuity to the “Attend the Woman Worker Program” that seeks to better understand worker’s laws through the use of Theater of the Oppressed and give leverage to women workers when dealing with their bosses in both rural and urban areas.  
to build towards the group’s 2015 goals, including the creation of a new Theater of the Oppressed group of domestic workers that will ensure the on-going struggle for domestic worker’s rights
